PROCTEXT.PARA: COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
PARLIAMENTARY DEBATES
SENATE
Hansard
FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SEVENTH PARLIAMENT
(THIRD PERIOD)

PARA.TAB: The Senate, on 22 December 1993, adjourned to 1 February 1994, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 22 December 1993, the Senate met on Tuesday, 1 February 1994 at 2 p.m.
The Senate met at 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that on 31 January 1994 Senator Sibraa resigned his office as President of the Senate. I lay on the table a letter from the Governor-General indicating his receipt of the resignation.

—I also inform the Senate that on 31 January 1994, prior to his resignation, the President received a letter from Senator Archer resigning his place as a senator for the state of Tasmania. Pursuant to the provisions of section 21 of the constitution, the President notified the Governor of Tasmania of the vacancy in the representation of that state caused by the resignation. I lay on the table the relevant documents.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Clerk, I remind the Senate that the time has come when it is necessary for the Senate to choose one of its members to be President. I propose to the Senate for its President, Senator Beahan, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That Senator Beahan take the chair of the Senate as President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further nominations for the office of President? There being no further nominations, in accordance with the standing orders, Senator Beahan is elected President and will take the chair.

PARA.TAB: Senator Beahan having been conducted to the dais—

The PRESIDENT (Senator Beahan)—I thank the Senate for placing this confidence in me and assure honourable senators that I am aware of the high honour that has been bestowed on me. I am also aware that I am stepping into large shoes. Senator Sibraa has made a reputation for himself as a very effective and competent chairman of this Senate. He has presided over it with fairness and dignity. He has also represented us in the various fora in which the President has to represent us as the Senate and as a parliament in a very distinguished way. The reports that we get from all over the world support that contention.

I wish Senator Sibraa well in the next stage of his career, for which he is admirably suited, and I look forward to the cooperation and assistance of honourable senators in trying to maintain the high standards that Senator Sibraa set.

I also want to mention that the Senate is undergoing fundamental change of an order and at a rate that it has not experienced in the past. This is not simply the product of the current disposition of numbers, which we are all having to adjust to fairly rapidly, as a result of circumstances. It is also a result of the fact that the community is placing very heavy demands on the process of review. It is demanding that it be accessible, more efficient, more practical and more down to earth. I look forward to honourable senators' support and cooperation in that incremental process of reform that hopes to build upon the good traditions that we had with good, innovative, practical ideas which make this a truly sensible and proper house of reform. With honourable senators' permission, I will now take the chair.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, let me be the first to congratulate you on behalf of the government on your election, uncontested, to this very high office. We are very confident that you will honourably fulfil the finest traditions of impartiality, commonsense and efficiency in your occupancy of that chair. Indeed, if we had not been so confident of that, we would not have supported you to occupy it.

PARA.TAB: You came into this place in 1987 after a very long background and set of experiences in education, the trade union movement and party administration. You quickly made your mark in this place as a very effective parliamentarian. I think in particular of your role quite recently as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities, but also of a number of other committee tasks that you have performed with great efficiency and effectiveness over the years, as well as performance in this chamber.

May I say on behalf of my colleagues that you have also been a very effective party politician. It is quite fair to say that one of the reasons that we in government have had such a calm and orderly time over the last few years—in spectacular contrast to experiences in some other places—is a function of the way in which you and others in this place have soothed and smoothed the way and created an environment in which the government can effectively govern with the minimum of distractions.

Now you are moving into a position that will have your talents very much more on public display than I guess they have been over the last few years. We have every confidence that you will perform these functions with very great competence indeed.

Mr President, I saw you described in one newspaper article not so long ago as bespectacled and cherubic. We can all see the bespectacled bit; the cherubic side of your nature is yet to be enjoyed by more than a small handful of your colleagues. But we have every confidence that, notwithstanding the way in which your cherubic nature will be tested from time to time by the rigours and cacophony of this place, you will do the job admirably. I wish you well in it on behalf of the government.

This is the occasion, as you said also, Mr President, for us to farewell our colleague Kerry Sibraa, whose last appearance in the chamber this now is. Kerry Sibraa has had, I believe, a quite outstanding career in this place since he first entered it in 1975—19 years ago. He has had almost complete continuity of service. There was a slight hiccup not so many years ago and on occasions he has found himself in the death seat, as it has been described in the political process. But each time Kerry, being the highly professional, highly competent and highly esteemed politician that he is, has overcome those difficulties and bounced back—and forward. He has had a very successful parliamentary and political career.

The culmination of that career has been his tenure as President of this Senate since 1987, involving re-election on three occasions to that post, which I believe is a measure of the confidence with which he has been regarded by all of us in this place, cutting completely across party lines, and a measure of the very great skills and competence he has brought to his occupancy of the chair.

It is not an easy thing to manage a house like this. We have not got quite the same reputation for rowdiness or impossibility in terms of discipline as, unfortunately, is enjoyed by the other place, but it is not an easy chamber to manage, particularly when there is not the automatic support of the majority of senators for actions that on occasions the presiding officer might be minded to take in order to re-establish order and discipline. I have no doubt that if that had ever been put to the test very squarely and directly Kerry Sibraa would have had that support but, nonetheless, it does create an environment of very great difficulty for any presiding officer in this place. That ought to be acknowledged. The role that Kerry played with such effectiveness ought to be appreciated.

Kerry's role behind the scenes as an administrator, in conjunction with his colleague the Speaker, is also one that I think ought to be acknowledged on an occasion like this. The movement of the parliament from the old building to the new one in 1988 was a huge managerial exercise. Kerry and the Speaker shared between them the administrative responsibility for this place—and did for that move. They did it superbly well. We ought to congratulate Kerry again for that achievement and for the many other management tasks, many of them of great sensitivity and difficulty, that he performed admirably over that long period.

Kerry, you have been a very hospitable President, as I think every one of us in this place can attest. You have used admirably the resources available to you for that purpose. We have enjoyed the very spirited and convivial way in which you carried out your duties in that respect. You carried them out so well on a number of occasions that you were faced with the difficulty that all of us have had from time to time of, after a very pleasant evening, having to deal with a quite complex and difficult situation in this chamber.

I think I will go to my grave remembering just a couple of occasions when Kerry Sibraa had forgotten to switch off the button and he had been plaintively heard to be saying, `Harry, Harry, what do I do now?' It was a perfectly understandable and human response to a situation of difficulty.

Kerry Sibraa, might I also say, has been a very effective ambassador in his job as President of this Senate. It is a job that has constantly involved playing that particular role, both here and overseas. He has not resisted the role of being a travelling ambassador for his country. Indeed, as I recall, he is the author of that now immortal expression that the most musical sound on this planet is the rattle of the first class drinks trolley on a Qantas Boeing as it climbs off over Botany Bay. That is a statement that has done him considerable honour around the world as people have nostalged and empathised with him, not least in some of the darkest hours we have been stuck in this particular chamber.

Kerry Sibraa's ambassadorial skills have produced, among other things, Australia's role as host of the CPA conference in 1988, which was a huge success and in which he played a crucial role as joint chairman and, of course, the very successful IPU conference just last year, which is regarded world wide as by far the most successful event of its kind ever held. Kerry Sibraa, as President of the Senate, deserves an enormous amount of respect for the role that he played in bringing that off.

He will be going to other things. It has been announced already, but subject to executive council formal approval—which I do not think will be denied—that Senator Sibraa will very shortly be taking up the post of Australian High Commissioner to Zimbabwe with accreditation also to six other countries: Zambia, Botswana, Namibia, Malawi, Mozambique and Angola. That reflects the esteem that I and his professional colleagues have for him for that ambassadorial role that he has played, and in particular the role that he has played in relation to Australia's relations with Africa.

It is a set of relationships that Kerry Sibraa has been developing personally with great effectiveness and assiduousness over quite a long period and he is very well known around Africa—as indeed he is in many other parts of the world—and very highly regarded. He has been the leader of Australian delegations to several South African development coordination conferences. He was invited by the Commonwealth to participate as an observer in Zambia and more recently by Eritrea, as indeed have some of his other parliamentary colleagues. He is very much a specialist in that area and I think in his occupancy of that position he will do Australia proud.

I know that I speak not only on behalf of Kerry Sibraa's party colleagues when I congratulate him on a job splendidly well done and wish him well for the future; I am sure I speak also on behalf of all the other members of this chamber.

I also take this opportunity to say a brief word about Brian Archer, who is also retiring from this place, as honourable senator's will have heard in the initial announcements today. Brian has been one of the longest serving members of the Senate. He was first elected to the Senate for Tasmania in 1975 and has served continuously since then. He came from a background of real estate and farming and his experiences in those professions or occupations always served him admirably in the kind of substantive contributions he was able to make to debate on a wide range of subjects, in particular economic, in this place.

Brian Archer was very active in committee work, having served on a wide range of committees; he chaired the Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce, Estimates Committee H, and the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. He served in the shadow ministry from 1985 to 1987 as shadow minister for science and shadow minister of state. He will be remembered, certainly by me in this place, as a formidable, effective and articulate advocate for Tasmania. The combination of Senator Archer and Shirley Walters was formidable. He was never as noisy or quite as aggressive as Shirley, but there was never any doubt about where his loyalties lay or about his capacity to communicate effective advocacy for his state.

He was a very pleasant man personally to deal with, notwithstanding any of the ideological differences, and they were legion, that one might have had with him so far as people on our side of the chamber were concerned. He was a comparatively quiet, and certainly very hardworking, member of this Senate and made a substantial contribution to this place over the many long years he was here. He will be missed. I for one, on behalf of the government, wish him well in his retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of the opposition, I congratulate you on your election. I take the opportunity to assure you of our support and respect, as we have supported and respected all previous holders of your high office. You mentioned that the precedent that has been set is that of a high standard and referred to Senator Sibraa, but I can take you back to before Senator Sibraa as well. I am pleased to hear that you intend to do your best to meet that standard because we would expect that of you as well.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I heard you say that you endorse the process of reform that is taking place in this chamber. We also support reform, although we are concerned that in many ways the government's definition of reform seems to be to further restrict the opportunities of the opposition. We hope that your endorsement is not of that sentiment. We wish you well in this new adventure that you have before you as President of this chamber and, as I said, we congratulate you and offer you our support.

I also want to take the opportunity to place on record some comments in relation to my friend Kerry Sibraa, who has retired as President and is about to retire as a senator. It is fair to say that he was not only respected in the office he held but also extremely well liked. He was regarded highly on this side of the chamber, and I think he can retire with the satisfaction of knowing that he held and served the office with distinction.

I guess we all reflect on different highlights of his period in office. I think one of the highlights certainly was the time that he sat Senator Cook down. We would have liked to have seen that occur a little more—

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes a bit of doing.

—I think he sat Senator Collins down once too, which could have occurred on more occasions. He was certainly reasonably impartial in his office, and we appreciated that and want to put that appreciation on record. In some ways it is a pity that, because of the factional deal that was made after the last election, he has to retire to provide the vacancy for the Labor Party to keep moving people up its ranks. But so be it.

PARA.TAB: In relation to Senator Sibraa's appointment, which we note, I know of his knowledge and interest in foreign affairs. I served under him when he was chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence—

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't learn much.

—I learnt considerably from him. I do not travel as often as Senator Sibraa but I recall a couple of trips to Africa that I have made with him. On one instance he demonstrated his diplomatic skills when we were in Ethiopia. Senator Alston and I had arranged a meeting with a very high official of the Ethiopian interim government—I think the vice president—and, because of some difficulty with planes, had to drop Senator Sibraa in at the last moment to take our place. What he said to us certainly was not diplomatic, but the way in which he handled the meeting I gather was exemplary, and we appreciate that.

PARA.TAB: Kerry, we wish you well in your appointment in Africa. I am sure that you will serve the interests of Australia well. You demonstrated here when you were President how you can put into practice diplomatic skills in furthering the international relations of not only this country but of this parliament as well, and I am sure you will continue that in your new appointment.

I also want to mention my friend and former parliamentary colleague Senator Archer who, as has been reported, retired yesterday from the Senate. Brian was never one to sing his own praises. I found one newspaper article about him which was headed `The quite achiever is life of Brian'. In many ways I think that summarises him. In that interview he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In politics there are workers and people that just talk about work. . .
You don't see my name in the paper every day but if you do I'm not talking about silly things.

I think there is a message for us all in that. When I look back at his record in this place, which was some 18 years as a senator for Tasmania, I look at the work that he did on numerous committees. I remember serving with him when he was chairman of the Select Committee on South West Tasmania, which was quite a difficult task. He had four years as chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Publications and seven years on the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce—he was chairman of that committee for two years. That gives a small indication of the type of productive work that he did throughout that long period of community service in this place. He served as a shadow minister from 1985 to 1987—he was the shadow special minister of state and shadow spokesman on science. Science was, and still is, one of his great interests.

PARA.TAB: He was also an innovator in his former business of real estate. He was the first estate agent in Australia to establish a franchise system. Again we see it in agriculture, one of his great loves and formerly his work. He is particularly interested in the genetics of flowers and livestock and putting his views into practice—planting experimental crops and developing one of Australia's best herds of Limousin French beef cattle. He is a great supporter of Tasmanian industry, Mr President, as you would no doubt know.

Before entering parliament he was chairman of the Australian Clothing Export Council and a member of the Timber Industry Advisory Committee. His strong interest in foreign affairs was also well known and I thought Senator Gareth Evans might have made mention of Senator Archer's constant prodding and poking on a more sensible economic relationship with Taiwan. Some of the changes and improvements in that relationship that have occurred in recent times I think can be attributed to the pressure that was constantly applied by Senator Archer—pressure in Australia's interests and, in some instances, finally taken up by the government.

But his work for constituents was really the highlight when I think of the work that he did for individuals in the fishing industry and in horticulture. When Tasmanian industry was having trade problems it was Senator Archer who was in there doing something for it—productive work that benefited individual Australians and particularly benefited business life in Tasmania. So he retires with a lifetime of community service behind him. He was a credit to his state; he was a credit to the Senate; and we certainly wish him well in a well earned retirement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Democrats I welcome everybody back to this parliamentary session and congratulate you, Senator Beahan, on your election to the role of President. One of the better things that happen in this place is that we all get to serve on Senate committees. Away from the party politicking of this place we get to know our colleagues as people. I had the opportunity to be a member of a small subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters of which you were the chairman. We trekked around northern Queensland, the Torres Strait Islands and north-west Western Australia together. In coming to know you, I always found you to be a firm but impartial chairman with just a hint of a twinkle in the eye about everybody else's agendas that were running. But notwithstanding some views you expressed—around a campfire, I think—about the role of minority parties, I expect you to bring those same qualities of firmness and impartiality to your role as President.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps, too, you will bring a little more of the arts and a little less of the football culture that we have all grown up with since I have been in this place. Mr President, we offer you our support and wish you well, especially with vexatious points of order.

In the short time allowed for this valedictory speech it is impossible to do justice to Kerry Sibraa's distinguished parliamentary career. It is also impossible to do justice to the equally distinguished way in which he carried out his duties as President of the Senate. Kerry Sibraa has stamped his own style on the Senate presidency, a style which we think has maintained and enhanced the dignity of the position. He has been fair, judicious and discerning.

Kerry Sibraa has also been a calming influence. When the temperatures rose in this place, he always—well, nearly always—kept his cool. Unlike others, he did not fall off his bike—he came close to doing so only once that I can think of since I have been here. That influence and that ability to keep his cool while all around him were losing theirs have been crucial to the good conduct of the Senate. As we all know, on many occasions he used his singular sense of humour to great effect.

Mr President, I know how difficult it is to be an umpire. This all awaits you out there in the middle of the pitch: keeping an eye on Senator Kemp at silly mid-on; turning down Senator Bishop's constant appeals; pouncing on those underarm deliveries from Senator Ian Macdonald; stopping the sledging from getting out of hand; and, even more difficult, getting the captains on this side to take orders—all the time waiting patiently for the twelfth man or woman to bring out the drinks.

It is not an easy task, but Senator Sibraa carried it out with grace and humour. When he became President of the Senate in 1987 the then leader of the Australian Democrats, Janine Haines, told Senator Sibraa that his predecessor, Senator Doug McClelland, would be a very hard act to follow. She warned Senator Sibraa that he would win the support of senators only if he emulated Doug McClelland's good humour, impartiality and firmness. I think that is good advice for you as well, Mr President.

We in the Democrats have had our disagreements with Senator Sibraa—small ones I think. But I think we can all well and truly say that he has met the criteria of good humour, impartiality and firmness. On behalf of the Democrats I say to you, Kerry, that you can be justifiably proud of your seven years as Senate President. We thank you for your even-handedness, for your willingness to assist and advise on procedural matters and for being, above all, an accessible and approachable president. We wish you all the best for the future, one for which you are personally eminently qualified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my National Party colleagues, let me be one of the first to congratulate you, Mr President, on your election to high office. I have been in this parliament with you for some years. I do not know that we have ever had a very close association, but in the times that we have met you have been a very pleasant person to know and to meet around the chamber. I am sure that you will carry out the duties of the office to which you have been elected today with the utmost standing, as is expected by the parliament, and that you will fulfil the role that was taken on by Kerry Sibraa over the last seven years.

PARA.TAB: Today, too, we are saying farewell to our previous President, Kerry Sibraa, who has distinguished himself as a hardworking and even-handed President. Kerry, I wish you all the best as you leave today. Another high office has been given to you. I know that you have always had a particular interest in international affairs and the continent of Africa, and that you will relish the duties that you will take over in the near future.

Kerry has worked very hard in this place and has guided this chamber through some very rough times. He has kept his head at all times. We have sat long hours in this place, and he always made his rulings fair and impartial. I believe he stood up for the rights of the minority parties in this Senate and respected them. We look forward, Mr President, to your doing the same.

Kerry served on many committees; they are too numerous to mention. He also served as whip. His hard work was recognised when he was promoted to the position of President of the Senate. I believe that Kerry, at the age of 49, was the youngest senator ever elected to the presidency. I am sure all honourable senators agree that the ex-President has been liked and respected in this place and will be missed sadly. Kerry, on behalf of members of the National Party, I pass on to you all our best, and we hope that you will enjoy your new post in Harare. We look forward to seeing you there from time to time when any of us visit there.

I would also like to mention my Senate colleague Senator Archer. I served on many committees with Senator Archer and I, too, had in my notes that he was the quiet achiever in the Senate. He was particularly knowledgeable about the fishing industry. If ever anyone brought forward to this place any problems on the fishing industry—our fourth largest exporter—the cry went up, `Where's Brian Archer? He knows about it'. His views on fishing were respected by both sides of politics.

Not only was he an expert on fishing; he was a great advocate for his state of Tasmania. He was a very outspoken advocate for his state of Tasmania. He also will be missed. I often enjoyed his company in the dining room and around the Senate; he was a very pleasant person to meet socially. He was a very hard worker. I wish him well in his retirement, and hope that he and his wife enjoy their new-found freedom.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate you, Mr President, on assuming your office. Senator Margetts and I have every confidence that you will fulfil your role in a worthy and competent manner. From the experience we have shared on the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, I know that you have the gifts and abilities to carry out this role and I am glad that you will now have the chance to do it.

PARA.TAB: I do not know you very well in the capacity of a fellow Western Australian, but I cannot let this moment pass without mentioning that there seems to have been a slight takeover by Western Australia of the roles of President and Deputy President. Maybe there is an appropriateness in the featuring of Western Australia in this way so that, even with our isolation on the other side of the continent, we do get represented. I know that you will fulfil your role with impartiality and do justice to the dignity of the Senate.

The roles of both President and Deputy President are designed to serve the parliamentary process and not the political parties. So I cannot but express disappointment and regret that the appointment of President has not followed a more realistic electoral process in that the opposition has failed to supply an alternative nomination. This means that, on two occasions now, the Liberal Party has failed to nominate a candidate whom it knew well had the support of the Greens (WA). I speak here of Senator Margaret Reid. I think the day will come when women will gain the recognition they deserve and fulfil the positions of President and Deputy President. I think we should put on record that, if we are to ensure that we are truly democratic, we need to have a gender balance.

As I said before, the Greens (WA) support the roles of the President and the Deputy President as positions which serve the Senate. Those positions need to reflect the constituency of the Senate and there is no reason why there should not be a Liberal Party President and a government Labor Party Deputy President.

The Greens (WA) senators would have been happy to do that and to support individuals who have demonstrated their merit for the office, and to use gender balance as an indication of the health of the Senate. It is high time that both major parties fulfilled their responsibilities to the Senate by providing worthy individuals for the roles of President and Deputy President for selection by the Senate, not by political parties. A country which espouses democracy deserves to give the parliamentary process the respect that allows that democracy to flourish. The Greens (WA) wish you well, Mr President, in the honourable new office that you hold.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you have a go at Labor for not putting up a woman?

—I think the gender balance issue is one that both parties can note. I would also like to express the appreciation of the Greens (WA) for the way in which our former President, Senator Sibraa, carried out his role as President over the two years that we have known him. As has been mentioned, he has been here for seven years. He has always been helpful and fair in his dealings with us. He had the novelty of having to adjust to looking over at these two benches during question time and during debates; he made that adjustment well. We are very grateful for the impartiality and fairness with which he exercised this role. We wish him well in his new role. We believe he is well suited to the position with his diplomatic skills and his familiarity with Africa. We certainly view his departure with regret and wish him the very best for the future.

PARA.TAB: As for Senator Archer, whose valedictory we are also noting today, I did not know him well enough to speak personally of him, and I will only speak briefly. I do remember his courtesy towards me on every occasion when we did have an interaction. I never heard him being mentioned in other than the most positive terms. Senator Margetts and I wish him well in his retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I should also like to congratulate you on your election to the presidency of the Senate. I have confidence that you will be able to act impartially in that position, taking due account of the standing orders. I noticed a little deviation in the last part of your address to the chamber during which you mentioned that this was the house of review. In the last part of your address, Mr President, you indicated that you would like to see the chamber cooperate with you in establishing procedures to make this a more effective house of reform. I assume that that was a slip of the tongue because reform could mean anything to anybody—
—So does `review'.

—No, `review' has a specific meaning in the context of the Constitution and of the standing orders of this place. I will be very happy to cooperate with you, Mr President, in ensuring that procedures are instituted or enhanced in order that this chamber is a truly effective house of review. That is not to say that it has not been a good house of review at times in its history, including its recent history.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the farewell to Senator Kerry Sibraa. As I recall, Senator Sibraa came to this chamber at the same election as I did, in 1975. I have known him for a long time as I knew him before then. He showed his mettle and showed that he was a truly impartial, clear-sighted observer when in 1975 he described my expulsion from the ALP as having been executed by a kangaroo court, namely, the federal executive of the ALP. This person was a young official of the Labor Party and it took courage and far-sightedness for Kerry Sibraa to make those observations.

As everybody else has indicated, Kerry Sibraa has performed his functions as President of this chamber with a great deal of diplomacy, a great deal of humour at times, and with fairness. We appreciate that, Kerry, and wish you well in your appointment. You are still a young man and will no doubt, hopefully, have much more to contribute for the benefit of this country and other countries in the years to come.

To be appointed as Australia's representative to Zimbabwe and a number of other African countries is very important. I know of your interest in that particular area and, if ever there was a need for a true advocate of closer relations between Africa and Australia, it is now. As those honourable senators who are interested in, for example, ODA—official development assistance—would know, our record with Africa leaves much to be desired. The ODA for Africa this year is very disconcerting—one of the lowest on record. I wish you well in that post in Africa, and I am sure that your appointment will result in closer relationships between Australia and that continent.

There was a lot of speculation about whether you would be going—whether you would be retiring as President of the Senate—but the Palm Beach post office issue gave it away. On 16 December 1993, you did something from the chair which I had not seen any other President do.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did it very well, too.

—He did it very well—he entered the debate. Senator Bishop had directed a question to Senator Collins about the threatened closure of the Palm Beach post office and Senator Collins responded. I will not read what Senator Collins said, but the President said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably not the role of the Chair to intervene, but I thought I announced in the Manly Daily last week that it was not going to close.

I knew then that he was going to leave that chair because no President would have made that intervention if he was not going to leave the chair. That is when it was given away. I wish you all the best, Kerry, and thank you for your support for this institution and for individual members of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Briefly, I would also like to make a statement about Brian Archer. Brian Archer also was elected in 1975—I am losing all those people who were elected in 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a message there, Brian?

—The way I felt about coming back to this place after having been with the family for a little while, yes. Senator Colston is the last of that group. Over that period of time Brian was a great supporter of Tasmania, but he also had a broad range of interests including industry matters and foreign affairs—a whole range of matters. But the big thing with Brian over many years, from the earliest times, was the fishing industry.

PARA.TAB: Brian was so involved with the fishing industry that I can recall John Wheeldon saying to me, `Who is that Jack Mackerel that he keeps talking about?'. Brian used to get up time and time again and talk about jack mackerel. As somebody has already said, Brian was a man who did not say much, but what he said made sense. He made a tremendous contribution to the community. I wish him and his wife Dorothy all the best in their retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I also rise to congratulate you. Your qualities have been admirably summarised by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill). I am glad that you seek to live up to the highest standards of the office. You have referred to Senator Sibraa, but former Senator Douglas McClelland and my South Australian colleagues of the past, former senators Young and Laucke, could also be mentioned. You can expect the support of members of all parties in the administration of the Senate. Many senators in this chamber would be prepared to serve in such an honourable position. It is for the parties to determine these things.

PARA.TAB: I refer to my good friend Senator Sibraa and I wish him, through you Mr President, every success in his new role as Australia's representative in southern Africa—especially as High Commissioner to Zimbabwe. It is no surprise to us that he will be serving in that capacity. Senator Sibraa has experience in Africa and in foreign affairs, and on merit he is an admirable person to represent us in such a position. This area of Africa—along with South Africa itself—will be the powerhouse of the whole continent. The experience that Senator Sibraa will bring to this office will serve not only Australia but that region of Africa well.

I have travelled with Senator Sibraa to China and other places. I commend him on the admirable skills, abilities and loyalty that he has brought to this chamber, to this parliament and to Australia. I count him as a friend forever. Senator Sibraa has always been loyal to his party. He has always said what he believes in private and in public. That kind of integrity is greatly respected in this chamber and in every part of Australia. I commend Senator Sibraa in every way for the manner in which he has served the Senate.

I refer to my good friend Senator Archer, a colleague who was elected to the Senate two years ahead of me. I regard Senator Archer as an honourable senator, a friend and an excellent Liberal who had the state of Tasmania, which he represented, very much in his heart at all times—especially the north-west of that state. Even before I was elected to this parliament, I was struck by Senator Archer's commitment to primary industry, to real estate and to the fishing industry.

Over the last 15 years we have had many conversations about Taiwan. Brian was elected—or unelected—as the main representative in this parliament for building good relations with Taiwan. I, and some others I see in the chamber, had an interest in understanding not only China as a whole—including Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau—but particularly Beijing. Because of the frequent discussions I had with people in China, I found bona fide discussion with Brian Archer about Taiwan very constructive. He was very much a friend of the economy of Taiwan and always subscribed to the Liberal Party's foreign policy and principles in such matters.

I commend him because I know of no other who has had such an influence on the positive outcomes of Australia-Taiwan relations that have been adopted by the government of the day. I wish Brian and his good wife Dorothy every happiness following his retirement from the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is a pleasure to address you by that title. You have run the gauntlet in our party room, as so many have done before you, and to have done so successfully, for a job such as yours, is an achievement. I wish you well and I hope you will look upon me kindly on the occasions that I get excited and that you will overlook my occasional display of exuberance.

PARA.TAB: I did not know Senator Archer well. From my time as a minister for the environment and from other things I know that he has pursued an interest in the Antarctic and in science over the years. One can certainly say of him something that cannot be said of too many of us in this place—in him, there was an absence of malice. I wish him well.

I mainly wish to say something about Kerry Sibraa, who has served in this place for so long—indeed, since 1975. It should be said of Kerry that his career has actually been of great benefit to me. Every time he moved up he created a spot that I could move into. That was a great advantage. Honourable senators should know that I would not be here were it not for the fact that in 1971 I received a call from Kerry Sibraa, offering me a job in the ALP office as an organiser.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is responsible!

—He is responsible for it all. I have not forgotten that moment and I wish him well. I have known Kerry over the course of 25 years. In fact, I remember him when he was not thin. In 1975 when John Ducker was unable to attend the national executive, Kerry Sibraa was the one delegate who did not vote against Brian Harradine. That was a matter of courage, but New South Wales has often stood out against the rest and will continue to do so, stoically and in observance of our traditions.

PARA.TAB: I was asked by Senator Faulkner and Senator Childs to extend to Senator Sibraa the good wishes of the combined branches and unions steering committee. I was asked to say that they will continue to give him the same support over the next few years that they have given in the past—so good luck!

Having watched Kerry as an official of the Labor Party, through a thousand meetings in a hundred cities and a million towns, he has been a great son of the Labor Party. Not too many have achieved all that he has achieved or have made as many friends as he has made—and there have been many. He was to the fore in many campaigns and we will all remember that. We will remember his humour and I, for one, will remember his friendship and his loyalty. In conclusion, I am proud to say to him that he was my mate and that he will remain so for a long time to come.
