TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. To the background of the government's lie at the last election that there would be no new taxes, I refer to today's tax increase on leaded petrol and I ask the minister: how does the government justify a tax hike that particularly hurts low income earners? Is this the reward that the government gives to the true believers? What calculations has the government in fact done on the effect of this new tax slug on low income earners, regional Australia and small business?

—The increase in fuel excise, which takes place with the routine inflation adjustment, is an important part of the government's deficit reduction program. It will help preserve the low inflation, low interest rate environment that we obviously have at the moment that is so essential if the recovery is to be sustained. At the moment we are in the middle of a splendid recovery and the maintenance of it is obviously the key to reducing unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The CPI impact of today's increase is estimated to be 0.09 per cent. So, even after the fuel excise increases, Australia will still have the third lowest petrol prices in the western world, with prices being lower in real terms than they were a decade ago.

The different tax rates for leaded petrol and unleaded petrol create an incentive for many motorists to switch and so help reduce the amount of lead in the atmosphere. Many pre-1986 cars can use unleaded petrol without modification. As we know, lead emissions are creating major health problems. It has been estimated that over half a million Australian children have blood lead levels which may result in intellectual development being impaired. So that impact is addressed in that way.

As to the impact on low income earners about which I am specifically asked, nothing could assist low income earners more—as I hope even the opposition can acknowledge—than a sustainable recovery and that deficit reduction package of which I spoke at the outset is crucial to sustaining the recovery. The children of poor people are also affected by excess lead in the atmosphere, as I have said, perhaps differentially adversely affected.

Again, lower income earners would have benefited from the income tax cuts announced in the budget and/or the income tax rebate for low income earners and/or the increase in unemployment and job training benefits, all of which were part of the budget which we are now financing. Any CPI increase resulting from the increases in fuel excise will be reflected in increased pensions and other social security benefits. In addition, low income earners have also benefited from past budget measures, along with the government's rejection in the budget of the regressive impact of a broad-based indirect tax system such as the GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer to the announcement last week of the winner of the Australia Prize, which recognises outstanding achievement in science and technology. Is the minister able to provide the Senate with any information about the recipient of the prize, who I understand is an American ecologist, and can the minister explain why the Australia Prize was awarded to an overseas scientist?

—Mr President, as a colleague for many years I use this opportunity to congratulate you on your election to the position of President of the Senate. I also take this opportunity to express my appreciation to Senator Crichton-Browne, who proved himself a professional amongst amateurs in gaining numbers on that side, for helping with the election.

PARA.TAB: The Australia Prize is an international prize which was established to recognise excellence in a specified science and technology discipline and this year it was awarded in the field of sustainable land management. Last week on Australia Day I was pleased to announce that Professor Gene Likens, who is director of the Institute of Ecosystem Studies at Millbrook, New York, had won this year's prize.

Professor Likens has been a pioneer in his field. In 1963 he co-initiated at Hubbard Brook in New Hampshire what has become a 30-year study of forest ecology. It was a revolutionary whole ecosystems study which has brought new scientific rigour to the relatively new field of ecological science. The Hubbard Brook study has attracted young ecologists from around the world and a number of young Australian researchers have been privileged to learn ecological science with Professor Likens.

There is no doubt that Professor Likens is a very worthy recipient of the Australia Prize. But at the same time I am aware of some criticism. It is said that we should not have awarded the prize to a non-Australian. However, it must be said that when this prize was instituted it was to recognise excellence in scientific achievement at the international level and it is assessed against set criteria by an independent committee which includes eminent scientists.

The fact that the prize is open to scientists world wide raises its status and ensures that the winner will be recognised as having made an outstanding international contribution. So the Australian scientists who have shared the prize over the past three years can say that they have won in open competition and have been recognised by their peers as being leaders in the field internationally.

I have received representations from a range of different individuals and groups regarding the future of the prize. No doubt there will be continuing discussion and debate within the science community as to the best way of recognising outstanding achievement in the science and technology field. However, I think we have to concede that with the increasing transfer of technology and scientific knowledge between countries and around the world the benefits of research performed in another country do not necessarily remain isolated.

Professor Liken's work has certainly materially enhanced our knowledge of how best to manage and sustain natural ecosystems and will lead to a better understanding of the global nature of environmental problems. He is an appropriate winner of Australia's international science prize and I look forward to being able to participate in the ceremony in Australia in April this year to present him with that prize.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the minister confirm that the Australian Federal Police have uncovered alleged criminal activity at the centre of the Griffiths affair? What is the nature of the criminal activity which has been uncovered? Does it relate to an undisclosed ALP electoral fund, or does it concern staffing arrangements in Mr Griffiths' office?

—I know no more about what the AFP may or may not have uncovered than what has been in the press. All I am able to say is that all matters which could possibly form the base of criminal charges and that have come to the government's attention have been referred to the AFP. That investigation is proceeding and nearing completion. When the results are known they will be made public. Until then it is profitless to speculate as to what the nature of the criminal activity might be, or who might end up being charged—if anyone.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate that Senator Gareth Evans has said that this has been referred to the Australian Federal Police and we await the answer from the police—and I notice Senator Evans is loath to pursue this question any further—but I think the supplementary question is of interest and one to which the government will certainly have the answer. When did the government become aware of the ALP BB account linked to Mr Griffiths, and what action does the government propose to take to investigate this account for possible breaches of the Electoral Act?

—Mr President, I am loath to pursue this question further because it is quite inappropriate to do so while the police investigation is proceeding. Mr Keating has made perfectly clear that there will be a properly constituted independent inquiry to look at any remaining matters of a non-criminal character that go to propriety or that go to other matters bearing upon capacity to perform ministerial duties effectively and properly, and that undertaking holds. But it is quite premature to engage in any speculation about any possible subject matter of such an inquiry until we get to that particular point.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating has made perfectly clear that he was only aware of any of the issues relating to Mr Griffiths as late as Friday evening, 10 days ago—that is when he first became aware of it. So far as the party is concerned, I do not think there is any reason whatsoever to believe that anyone else was aware of these particular issues before that date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Can the minister inform the Senate of the status of workplace bargaining in defence? How will this process further micro-economic reform in the public sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Defence has completed negotiations for an agency agreement with unions covering defence civilian staff. This agreement has been certified by the Industrial Relations Commission to take effect from Friday, 28 January 1994. The two-year agreement, which provides for a two per cent increase payable upon certification and a further two per cent payable in December 1994, covers a wide range of productivity and efficiency measures being initiated within the context of the force structure review, the commercial support program, the defence regional support review, the defence logistics redevelopment project, the civilianisation of military positions, the devolution of personnel and financial administration and the introduction of defence quality management.

PARA.TAB: The agreement provides for a streamlined process whereby more flexible hours may be introduced in defence workplaces. Further improvements in existing industrial relations practices will be pursued through joint reviews. The agreement contains a no extra claims clause aimed at protecting the department from claims by the unions which would lead to a significant increase in labour costs during the life of this agreement.

The cost of the pay increases should be exceeded in each year by estimated savings from defence's extensive program of micro-economic reform. These will be over and above the savings previously programmed to arise from these initiatives. The drive to improve productivity across defence places equal demands on ADF personnel and civilian staff. In many cases it would be impossible to distinguish the difference in the contribution being made to improve productivity between the military and civilian elements in defence. Hence ADF productivity reforms have been developed along similar lines to the civilian agreement.

The Australian Defence Force has applied to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal for a pay increase similar to that contained in the civilian agreement. The matter is expected to be heard by the tribunal on 4 February this year. The defence agreement is a notable achievement, particularly given the size and complexity of the defence department and the fact that there were 18 unions involved in this agreement. It will be the first agency bargaining agreement to be certified by and for the Australian Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I congratulate the minister on his important new portfolio and refer to his statement that there would be `no handouts to industry'. Clearly, that would not be responsible industry policy. Does the minister's statement mean that he is not going to pursue a strategically supportive industry policy, as has been foreshadowed by his predecessor on behalf of the government? In particular, is he going to proceed with the sector specific strategies for 13 industry sectors, again as foreshadowed by the government, at a cost of $200 million?

—Thank you, Mr President. I, too, would like to extend my congratulations to you. I support the remarks that others have made in this chamber, but for me personally it is of great satisfaction to see you in that chair.
—It is so fitting for a statesman to be recognised.

—That is right. To the question: I think one ought always to be precise, when quoting one's statements back to one, about exactly what one did say, and exactly what I did say was not what Senator Spindler alleged I said. What I said was that, consistent with the view taken by my predecessors, the era of handouts is dead. I was simply seeking to make the point that industry policy has to be conducted in a responsible way and not the way in which it was in the McEwenist era in which high protection and handouts were the order of the day.

PARA.TAB: I am asked to confirm a position associated with that of my predecessor Alan Griffiths. I say, first of all, that I believe Alan Griffiths, in the unfortunately short tenure that he had in this post, to have been an excellent minister for industry, and the plaudits that I have had passed on to me by industry testify to that.

In terms of the question I am asked, however, I will adopt the answer that I became familiar with in foreign affairs and trade. I will neither confirm nor deny what my intentions are. I am at the present time deep in the brief of the department. I am giving consideration to a forthcoming industry statement and I have committed myself to exhaustive consultations in order to see that the industry statement reflects the true partnership between government and the private sector and the states and the unions in this country so that we facilitate in an appropriate way the opportunities created for Australian industry by the buoyant circumstances of the Australian economy, the international recovery, the completion of the GATT round and the opportunities created by Australia increasingly becoming of the export culture.

I do not want to confirm or deny what I propose to do. The statement will be coming down later in the year. While it may be a trial to honourable senators, I simply ask for a bit of latitude and a mite of patience and, on the night, we will see what the government proposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the minister advise whether any recent progress has been made in gaining access for Australian growers to the Japanese rice market, which has been banned in the past by the Japanese government?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that the first shipments of Australian rice have arrived in Japan. That is a very significant event for the Australian rice industry. In September last year the Japanese government announced that it would allow emergency imports to maintain supplies following shortfalls in the Japanese rice crop. The Australian shipment from the current crop is the result of an agreement that was reached last year between the Ricegrowers Co-operative Ltd and a Japanese importer as part of the emergency rice import program. These sales will put Australian rice growers in a very good position to take advantage of the permanent opening of the Japanese market, which is part of the Uruguay Round outcome.

PARA.TAB: Australia is a reliable supplier of high quality, clean rice. I am confident that Australian rice can be competitive with any other world supplier. The Australian rice industry is export oriented, with forecast production in 1993-94 of 1.15 million tonnes and a forecast value of exports of $336 million.

Rice growers have put considerable effort into developing the Japanese market over the past few years. The government has worked closely with the rice growers to gain access to this market. The current shipment provides an opportunity to demonstrate the quality of Australian rice and the reliability of supply and it should form the basis for the further supplies of Australian rice to Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer the minister to the revelation in last Sunday's Sun-Herald that a $1.25 million study, commissioned by the former minister, Mr Alan Griffiths, into impediments to development in certain regional areas may be used to pork-barrel in ALP marginal seats. Will the minister kindly establish how it is purely coincidental that, of the regions selected, one is centred on the marginal seat of Herbert, held by Mr Griffiths' Parliamentary Secretary, Mr Ted Lindsay, and another near the marginal seat of McMillan, held by Mr Griffiths' caucus portfolio chairman, Mr Barry Cunningham? Is it also a coincidence that another region under consideration is centred on the marginal seat of Adelaide, lost by Mr Bob Catley, who is listed as an adviser to Mr Griffiths, and a further region is near the seat of Hinkler, lost at the last election by Mr Brian Courtice, who is listed as a consultant to Mr Griffiths?

—A degree of cross-chamber bonhomie descended on this place earlier today in the congratulating, rightly, of many people. One person who was significantly overlooked is Senator Bishop, who has asked this question. She has been elevated to the front bench of the Liberal Party and I am pleased to see that her colleagues have moved up to make space for her. I take this opportunity, in the spirit of the earlier mood of this chamber, to congratulate Senator Bishop. I have a feeling that great things are in store for her in the opposition and I wish her well in her ambitions.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I would have thought that, in view of the reminder that we have already had about the need for Senator Cook to address the issue or sit down, this is an opportune moment for you to direct him to stick to the relevance of the question.
—I think Senator Cook made it clear that what he is saying is in the spirit of bonhomie and I think he is getting to the question.
—Thank you, Mr President. I am surprised that a point of order should be pulled when I am trying to congratulate one of Senator Alston's colleagues, but then I guess we know where he will vote.

PARA.TAB: My predecessor, Mr Griffiths, announced the consultancy on business investment in regional Australia, to be done by McKinsey and Company, on 6 October, following an exhaustive consultancy selection process. On 17 November and 12 December he further announced the 14 regions to be covered by the study. The regions to be targeted by the study are—and we did not get a complete list; let me now correct that error—Cairns-Townsville in Queensland; the Illawarra in New South Wales; the Latrobe Valley in Victoria; northern Adelaide; northern New South Wales; south-east Queensland; Emerald in Queensland; Wagga Wagga in New South Wales; Canberra in the ACT; Queanbeyan in New South Wales; Geelong in Victoria; south-east South Australia; south-west Western Australia; the Pilbara area in Western Australia, and a very fine area that is; north-east Tasmania; and Darwin in the Northern Territory. The selection of those regions was not in any way associated with the minister or his office. The selection of the regions was made by officers of several departments on the basis of how best we establish criteria and then identify regional Australia for the purposes of conducting a study.

The report in the newspaper to which Senator Bishop has referred is interesting. That report is about Senator Bishop's allegations. It is passing odd that a newspaper report generated by Senator Bishop is waved around this chamber as if it were independently generated by investigative journalists. It was not. It consisted of a series of allegations made by Senator Bishop to undoubtedly prop up the ambitions she has to go higher in her own party.

The regions were chosen by a project steering committee in consultation with McKinsey and Company. The committee comprised SES officers from the Office of Regional Development, the policy area of my own department, the Bureau of Industry Economics and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The committee is chaired by the assistant secretary, policy, in the Office of Regional Development.

The regions were chosen so as to be consistent with the original study brief which was submitted for open tender on 28 and 30 August 1993. The structure of the survey proposed by the successful tenderer excludes Sydney and Melbourne as metropolitan areas. I can go on, Mr President, but the allegation that has been clearly made here is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is absolutely true.

—It is not true. It is based on fanciful politicking in a shameless effort at self-aggrandisement and will be proven to be empty under further investigation, if anyone is foolhardy enough to want to go and challenge the bona fides of these very fine officers.

—I have a supplementary question. That answer was indeed worthy of Mrs Kelly. Could Senator Cook tell the Senate whether, as the new minister, he intends to retain the services on his staff, as consultants or otherwise, of Dr Catley and Mr Courtice?

—I take it as a compliment that I am associated with Ros Kelly. I think she is a very fine minister in this government. Mr President, I am asked about my personal staff—who will be on my personal staff and what roles they will play. This is indeed not a question on the portfolio which I represent in this chamber; this is a question regarding my staffing arrangements and is therefore probably out of order. Let me say that I am in the process of settling down my staffing arrangements. They are not concluded at this stage. When they are concluded I will be happy to provide the information to the chamber.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Senator Cook. I refer to the minister's announcement on Sunday about the forthcoming industry statement, which will be a critical element in the government's continuing commitment to increase the competitiveness of Australian industry. Can the minister inform the Senate what steps he will take to ensure that the interests and the priorities of the Australian business community are fully reflected in the development of this statement?

—I said on Sunday, immediately upon being sworn in as minister for this portfolio, that my first priority was to prepare the industry statement, a statement that was initiated by my predecessor, Mr Griffiths. I have already acknowledged Mr Griffiths in an earlier question.

PARA.TAB: The statement is and will be important. There is a lot of work in the very short timetable now for completion of the statement, but I do expect to be able to complete it on time. I think it is necessary that the statement reflect the views of the broad business community and to that extent I intend to undertake extensive consultations. I think it should also extend to the views of the Australian union movement and any other industry policy makers. I would be delighted if any members of this chamber wished to offer ideas too. I think it is an important statement and therefore should reflect the close working relationship that this government has developed with the Australian business community.

On Friday I will commence consultations with the automotive industry and then, later in the morning, with the environmental industry in Australia. Environmental technology has been a fast growing export, I might say, and I think there are many fine environmental companies that will carve a place for themselves in the world. Their views will be quite important.

Later, at a time that I can accommodate in my program, I will meet the fast growing communications industry, the processed food industry and the industry that has grown up around information technology. We will certainly be interested to know the views of these industries as to how the government can assist their exports, which are quite significant, to grow further. I intend, with Senator Schacht, to meet the small business community—an important lifeblood to industry in Australia—and I will be interested to hear the views it might have on access to capital to fund its development and place in the market. As well, I will meet the metals industry, the aerospace industry, the maritime and shipbuilding industry, the construction industry and the agrifoods industry.

As I said to Senator Spindler in answer to an earlier question, we are operating in an economy that is looking at revising its growth prospects upward and that has notched upward in terms of its general economic growth. Export growth has significantly increased too. The global economy is, while patchy, showing signs of recovery and some of our main markets are exhibiting more demand. In all of those circumstances, the issue that I am keen to pay attention to is the solving of the question: how can we, as a government, help Australian industry capture the opportunities in those growing markets?

TALK.START.PARA: —Welcome, Mr President, to the chair. My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Does the minister agree that it is important to protect the privacy of sensitive data on children, parents and child carers? Does the minister agree with the Australian Law Reform Commission and the Australian Privacy Foundation that the NCAC, as an incorporated association and not a government agency, is not subject to an appropriate set of responsibilities and sanctions to protect such sensitive personal data? Will the minister withdraw the child care accreditation guidelines in order to reform this devious corporate device which has taken important private data outside the protection of the Privacy Commission?

—Mr President, I also offer my congratulations to you on your appointment as President of the Senate. I take this opportunity to remark, in support of one of my other colleagues, that Western Australia is indeed doing very well. We may be raising you to the presidency but we also look forward very much to welcoming Carmen Lawrence from Western Australia to join the ranks of good members on this side.

PARA.TAB: In answer to Senator Newman's question, the matter of privacy has been raised and brought to my attention as a concern about the accreditation committee. I point out to Senator Newman that this matter was brought to my attention by an article in the Australian about the Australian Privacy Foundation's concerns. I can assure Senator Newman that appropriate protection of information collected by the National Child Care Accreditation Council has been the subject of discussion with the Privacy Commission and the Australian Law Reform Commission. Indeed, I can assure Senator Newman and the Senate that necessary protection, handling arrangements, storage and release of information are currently being negotiated. It is expected that those arrangements will be implemented before the system becomes fully operational on 1 July 1994 and will mirror privacy principles applying to government agencies.

It is also important to know that the intention is that the National Child Care Accreditation Council will become a company limited by guarantee and will, therefore, be subject to the provision of corporation law governing improper use of information. So I can assure Senator Newman and the Senate that the government is aware of the concern raised about privacy. The Privacy Commissioner has had discussions with the National Child Care Accreditation Council and is meeting with it. The matters that have been raised as a possible concern ought be laid to rest. There is no reason for concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her response, but I ask the minister again: will she withdraw the child care accreditation guidelines while these additional guidelines are put into legislative form for the Senate to approve?

—There is absolutely no need to change, withdraw or amend the accreditation guidelines, despite the fact that I understand those opposite intend to have a second run at it tomorrow. Every time one thinks of something new, Senator Newman comes up with the same old response to it. Protection is guaranteed under the arrangements and there is no need to change those guidelines. Arrangements will not be necessary to amend the guidelines; there is no need for that further debate on accreditation.

—I add my congratulations to you, Mr President, on your election. Can the Minister for Health advise the Senate of developments concerning the patient-to-patient transmission of HIV which was revealed by the New South Wales health department late last year? Can he advise the Senate of the outcome of the review of infection control procedures?

—I informed the parliament late last year that I was asking, firstly, the Australian National Council on AIDS and the NHMRC to look at the existing guidelines on infection control to ensure that they are adequate and consistent and, secondly, to review the investigating and reporting procedures on the incidence of disease transmission. The joint ANCA/NHMRC infection and control review group met twice in January. It has started a process of reviewing the guidelines to which Senator Chris Evans has referred. On that committee and its associated working parties there are representatives of the AMA, surgeons, gastroenterologists, nurses, general practitioners, dentists, and Standards Australia, and health administrators from both the Commonwealth and the states.

PARA.TAB: The early indications are that at this stage there appears to be no need for a radical change to our infection control guidelines. However, it is pretty obvious that, wherever possible, autoclaving of all reusable instruments will be strongly recommended by this body.

As a result of the review, some amendments will obviously occur to ensure that the highest possible standards of infection control procedures are put in place and adhered to nationally. Those standards need to be revised periodically in the light of new knowledge. This is not the kind of new knowledge that any of us would have liked to have been appraised of, but the apparent patient-to-patient transmission that has now been highlighted is obviously a matter of concern to us all.

The review group has issued a statement summarising the key principles and a list of existing infection control guidelines which will follow these principles. They will be brought to the attention of all organisations representing medical practitioners and surgeons around the country. In the next few months the review group will go on to produce detailed guidelines and will report its findings to me on a regular basis. I expect that the whole procedure will be completed within three months.

However, the review of investigations and reporting procedures is more complex because it involves not only public health issues but legal ones as well. Consequently, that part of the review will take a little longer to finalise. Our current policy of adherence to universal infection control, with HIV testing as a decision to be made on clinical need between individual doctors and their patients, does not at this stage appear to need changing. There is certainly no recommendation to that effect, and I doubt very much that I will get such a recommendation. While we will not change that basis, obviously all practitioners will need to be made more aware of the dangers that this episode has so graphically highlighted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Family Services. Independent accountants commissioned by the state child care associations of Queensland, Victoria and New South Wales to implement the government's child care accreditation scheme put the cost increases per week for child care at $18 in Queensland, $35 in Victoria and $69 in New South Wales. As the government has not refuted these costs, will the government absorb the costs, reduce the number of places available in child care, or will this additional cost be passed on to the parents? I seek leave to table the independent costings.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that Senator Boswell wants to table that information because it will at last give the government an opportunity to see it. We have had terrible difficulty getting hold of the private claims of costings. It is not a matter of whether I will refute the costings—I did that last time, and the line remains exactly the same. One would have to worry about exactly the same guidelines producing costing variations of $18, $35 and $69. Somehow, whoever is doing these costings is not looking at the same things and not comparing like with like.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Different states have different regulations.
—State costs.

—Senator Newman claims that different states have different costs. That is absolutely correct but that is the point that all opposition senators refuse to acknowledge. These costings incorporate state requirements, in particular, labour force and staffing requirements and state regulations. That has absolutely nothing to do with accreditation.
—You are a centralist!

—Senator Newman may accuse me of all sorts of things but she will not acknowledge the facts which are the issue of this question. Senator Newman's interjection highlights where the opposition is wrong—these costings incorporate state costs, in particular staffing requirements, and have nothing to do with the costing of accreditation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell asked me whether I would refute these claims. There is no change in what I say now from what I said last year—indeed, we have refuted those claims from the beginning. I will gladly look at the documents tabled by Senator Boswell because at last we might be able to look at what the people doing these studies are incorporating in those costings.

According to the private consultant who has done the costings for government, it comes out at 88c or thereabouts, compared with the opposition's costings of $18 or $69. As I said in this place last year, a child-care centre in South Australia went through the accreditation process off its own bat because it was interested in finding out the substantive issues of accreditation. That centre reported that it found the process and the outcomes very successful and positive for the centre, the parents and the staff. That centre came up with the costing of 55c.

So Senator Boswell should continue to be cautious about those evaluations. I am delighted to look at the costings tabled by Senator Boswell—I will certainly cast an eye over those costings to see what is causing this discrepancy.

TALK.START.PARA: —About time!

—It is not about time. We have been waiting on whether or not any of these claims would provide this evidence for us. Until now we have not had the details of those claims, so I will be very pleased to look at them. I am also concerned that anybody examining exactly the same requirements could produce discrepancies of $18 to $35 to $69. One would have to be very worried about exactly what the people doing these studies are incorporating within their estimates. On all the evidence given to us, they are incorporating, as Senator Newman so succinctly interjected, state costs which are not part of the accreditation.

PARA.TAB: If training costs are involved, the government recognises those by setting aside $700,000 this year and $1 million next year for training necessary staff. That is not part of the costing; if it has been included, that is another fault. I am happy to look at the information and provide Senator Boswell with any further information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note Senator Crowley's answer. However, Senator Crowley may not be aware that some of the states have already started to implement some of the accreditation programs, and that is what is causing the difference. Because of the serious consequence of the government getting it wrong—an enormous disparity between the government's estimate of $88 and the cost as determined for each of the child-care state associations—will the minister refer the various assessments to a qualified third party, like Coopers and Lybrand, for arbitration as requested by the child-care associations? Until that arbitration is finalised, will the minister withdraw the regulations?

—No, I will not withdraw the regulations. I note again for the record that Senator Boswell says—and I think with all innocence—that state regulations are now being introduced in child-care centres. Indeed, they may well be, Senator Boswell, and they may well be the cause of the increased costs. It is not accreditation costs; it is state regulations.
—You still have not understood, you duffer!
—Order, Senator Newman!

—If Senator Newman persists with that, she will be persisting in convincing people that she does not know what this is about. The need to have an independent arbiter look at these things is very much to jump the gun. These are no more than estimates of what the accreditation process might cost. It is far more important to see the accreditation process begin to be established, as is now happening with centres already registered. Once those processes are beginning to happen we will have real data about the real cost of implementing the accreditation process. I can assure Senator Boswell that already more than 400 centres have registered with the National Child Care Accreditation Council and it is in the process of being implemented. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook, whom I hope can live up to the standards set by Senator McMullan. I refer to recent press reports regarding the McDonnell & East department chain store in Queensland. Those reports suggest that the company is in severe financial difficulty and that the superannuation scheme for the company's employees does not now have sufficient assets to meet its $1.1 million superannuation liabilities, despite the fact that the fund had $2.8 million of assets just 19 months ago. I ask the minister: firstly, is this shaping up to be Australia's first Robert Maxwell-style superannuation fund rip-off and, secondly, can the minister assure the chamber that all efforts have been made to ensure that employees recently retrenched or soon to be out of a job with the company will receive their full superannuation payouts?
—I do share Senator Kernot's hope.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take on board Senator Kernot's interjection.
—How gracious of you!

—That is right; it is the day of graciousness. As Senator Kernot has said, there have been public reports about an alleged shortfall in the funding of defined benefits in the superannuation fund for the employees of McDonnell & East. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission—ISC—is aware of the circumstances of that particular fund. The provisions of the current legislation are limiting as to what measures the ISC can take, but it is following its usual approach of seeking to protect the interests of the fund members. That is the fundamental concern of the ISC. The Queensland Industrial Relations Commission is also investigating this matter.

PARA.TAB: In response to the Industrial Relations Commission's request, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer approved an ISC recommendation that the ISC give relevant information to the Industrial Relations Commission to help that commission's considerations. This was judged by the Treasurer to be in the public interest. There are no legislative provisions in the Commonwealth legislation now for any shortfall in the funding of defined benefit funds to be made good. The question of any obligation that might arise to fund members may be a matter to be resolved by an administrator, whom I understand has been appointed by the controlling company, North Quay Ltd, or in legal processes. New Commonwealth legislation for the prudential supervision of superannuation is intended to give more protection to fund members and greater powers to assist members' interests, which should generally assist cases such as the McDonnell & East case. That legislation—the Superannuation Industry Supervision Act—comes into effect on 1 July this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to a letter I received from Lynn Ralph, acting chairperson of the Australian Securities Commission, advising that following its investigation into the affairs of the Prime Minister's half-owned Brown & Hatton group of companies, resulting from my formal complaints about its false financial reports and breaches of the corporations law, the group has responded by correcting its previous inaccurate financial statements. The letter also advises that penalty notices for late lodgment of annual returns have been issued against various companies of the Prime Minister's piggery group. As the Prime Minister and his apologists in this chamber have continually and falsely claimed that my revelations about his company are unsubstantiated muckraking, will the Prime Minister now explain how and why these false returns were firstly submitted to the ASC, and why they were not corrected until, on my initiative, the ASC required it?

—It is hardly surprising that Senator Michael Baume and the opposition would want to start a diversionary manoeuvre yet again on pigs and Prime Ministers because of the appalling difficulty that they are in at the moment. So, far from there being allegations of unsubstantiation in Senator Baume's muckraking, might I just remind the Senate of how many times Senator Baume has been plain wrong over the last year or so when he has been seeking to make an issue of this particular contribution by the Prime Minister to the economic health of this nation. From a litany of errors, let me just describe the following four highlights. In the first one Senator Baume claimed—
—I rise to a point of order.
—It goes to the credibility of this particular claim, Mr President, and accordingly it is highly relevant.

—Senator Evans has just conceded that this is not relevant; he says it goes to the credibility of the questioner. That is certainly not the basis for providing an answer to a question. The question asked specifically about returns. It has nothing to do with Senator Evans's imagination about any other earlier answers that might have been given. Mr President, I ask that you direct him to answer this question only.

—I make a short point on the point of order. Make a specific substantive allegation and it will be responded to; go trawling and fishing around and raising questions which the honourable senator says demand answers, but do not amount to that, and the honourable senator will not get answers any better than that which he will get from me now, which is a demonstration of just how wrong he has been whenever he has set out on this particular trail before. I go to that now, Mr President.
—There is no point of order.

—Could I remind the Senate that the first time Senator Baume opened his mouth on this was to claim that in the One Nation statement in February 1992 the Prime Minister had lifted the Foreign Investment Review Board threshold $20 million so that the—

—I rise to a point of order. Mr President, I made a submission to you. Senator Evans made no attempt to respond; all he did was abuse Senator Baume. You summarily dismissed the point of order. I ask you, in the interests of all parties in this chamber understanding the basis on which you intend to deal with these matters, whether you would please explain why it is relevant to have someone's credibility attacked as an answer to a specific question?

—On that point of order, Mr President: you correctly ruled. You do not have to give a reason for your ruling; that has never been the practice in this chamber. Senator Baume himself, in his question, has complained of the fact that he has been attacked over his previous claims on this subject. He has set himself up. Now, if Senator Evans wants to have a go at him, he can have a go at him; Senator Baume will note the question, and we will go backwards and forwards. Senator Baume himself invited this line of criticism in his question.

—It is always a very difficult thing, and it has been a very difficult thing for Presidents in the past, to rule on the relevance of answers, but it seems to me that in this case the relevance was clear, and I ruled accordingly.
—I am indebted to you, Mr President, for that statesmanlike initial contribution to the jurisprudence of this place. In the limited time available—

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. On 18 December 1990 your predecessor, to whom everyone has paid great homage today, upheld the ruling of Sir Magnus Cormack that if a minister chooses to answer a question, the minister should confine himself to points contained in the question with such explanation as will render the answer intelligible. Senator Baume has asked a very specific question as to why returns were filed in a manner which was wrong and he mentioned that nothing was done about it until he raised the matter in this chamber. That was the question. Mr President, would you uphold the ruling of your predecessor and those of former Presidents and ask the minister to either answer the question or else remain seated?

—I am not sure whether Senator Bishop was intending to move dissent from your ruling, Mr President; it sounded rather like it, but I am sure that was not what she meant to do. I refer to the point of order that she raised. In the terms in which she raised it she provided exactly the confirmation of Senator Ray's point and your ruling, because she referred to the minister's requirement to reply in response to the terms of the question. It is not Senator Evans's fault if Senator Baume so expressed his question—
—I did not say `terms' at all.

—She quite explicitly endorsed the entitlement of a minister to draw upon the wording of the question in phrasing the response. Senator Evans is merely doing that. Quite clearly, even if that were not the case, he is responding to the context in which the question was asked as well as the question, and that has traditionally been—and must logically always be—a legitimate entitlement of anybody answering a question in any forum.

—Mr President, I rise to speak to the point of order. I am glad that the government has pointed out that it relates to the text of the question, because part of the question says that `they have continually and falsely claimed my revelations about his companies'. It does not refer to the Prime Minister's other activities; it does not refer to the Prime Minister and his legislation. The question was specifically related to my revelations about his companies. That was the text of the question and that is why I totally support the propositions being put by my colleagues. I would therefore be grateful if you would explain to me where they are wrong.
—I have listened to the points of order raised by Senator Bishop and Senator Baume, and, despite precedents, I see no reason for altering the ruling I made in the first place.

—Mr President, I am indebted to you. In Mr Keating's consideration of whether he wants to add anything to what I say in response to the question, he will no doubt have regard to just how often Senator Baume has been wrong in the past in making these various allegations about particular aspects of this particular matter.

PARA.TAB: The first occasion I want to highlight on which he has been wrong was the claim that Mr Keating had lifted the Foreign Investment Review Board's threshold to $50 million so that the piggery in which he has an interest could enter into a joint venture with a Danish company without the need for FIRB approval. Senator Baume was wrong there because the joint venture was approved by the FIRB under the original guidelines months before the changes announced in the One Nation statement. That was strike one. Strike two was when Senator Baume and a number of other honourable senators alleged that AQIS was told to expedite its consideration of requests—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, having had a further opportunity to listen to Senator Evans, I also rise on a point of order. The question related to the fact that errors were found in the accounts filed with the commission. The ASC has substantiated the allegation that the returns were incorrect. The question is: how does the Prime Minister explain lodging returns with errors, and how did these errors occur in the first instance? That is a simple, straightforward question but it is not the question being answered by the minister. Mr President, I suggest that you direct him to answer the question asked, not the one that he has invented.

—I ruled earlier that, despite any precedents raised by other honourable senators, the responses Senator Gareth Evans was giving were relevant in the context of the general question asked. I must say that it is difficult to respond in any other way when questions are asked in a provocative manner, and that is the problem. I ask Senator Evans now to get to the nub of the question.

—Mr President, if I get time to do anything I would be delighted to do just that. I would like to make four quick points about where those opposite have got it wrong in the past. The first, as I have already mentioned, relates to the FIRB. The second, as I started to mention, relates to the AQIS affair, where they got it absolutely wrong.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order.
—I am entitled to do so and I propose to do so. I am not going to put up with anything that honourable senators opposite might say to the contrary.
—Order, Senator Evans!
—I have the support of the President in doing it, and I am indebted to you, Mr President.

PARA.TAB: The second illustration was the AQIS affair, where the honourable senator got it absolutely wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Evans! A point of order has been raised.

—Mr President, you made it very clear in your ruling that Senator Evans was to return to the question. He then got up and said that he wanted to add two further points. I believe that he was directly flouting your ruling. I ask you to again direct Senator Evans to get back to the question and, if he refuses to do so, that you direct him to sit down. We have heard this bluster before with the Brian Burke affair and I would urge you, Mr President, not to be fooled by it.
—I have asked Senator Evans to get back to the nub of the question. I do so again.

—Mr President, I am confused. With your first ruling, the very matter at issue was whether I could spend a little bit of time in addressing the ways in which Senator Baume has been wrong in the past and, accordingly, why he is likely to be utterly wrong again. You ruled in my favour on that occasion but then you sat me down. However, we will find plenty of other opportunities to draw attention to the AQIS mistake, to the mistake those opposite made about the change in the value of Mr Keating's interest, and to the mistake they made this time, without cover of parliamentary privilege—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Even ignoring for one moment the calculated and deliberate offence given to the Chair by Senator Evans, the fact is that you have twice directed him to get to the nub of the question, and that means answering precisely what Senator Hill said should be answered. You accepted that. In effect, Senator Evans is again flouting your ruling, and I invite you to sit him down or tell him that he will be given a further opportunity by way of an extension of time to get to the nub of the question.

—You need not worry about the Chair; I have a thick skin. Senator Evans has been asked to get to the nub of the question and was starting to do so. It makes it very difficult if there are constant interjections from the opposition.

—Mr President, as I was saying, there will be ample opportunity to draw attention to those mistakes and the other mistakes that I was going to mention—such as the taxation issue, which the honourable senator got fundamentally wrong and which he will have to answer for to the courts, as he well knows—and those mistakes will be taken into account in any consideration we might otherwise feel minded to give to any sleazy, scurvy allegation that those opposite might be minded to make in the future.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has made it absolutely clear that he is not personally involved in the day-to-day management of this particular company. There is a managing director. There is a general farm manager. There is a series of other specific farm managers. All of these people are responsible for the submission of the accounts and the operational management of the company. For the Prime Minister, it is an arm's length exercise; it always has been and will remain so as long as he is in his present job.

The Prime Minister understands the proprieties involved in running a business. I suspect he understands them a darn sight better than the 20 or 30 honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who have businesses of their own—not all of them very successful businesses. On the contrary, the Prime Minister's venture, as acknowledged by Mr Greiner and Mr Armstrong in substantial and affirmative public statements they have made about it, is contributing something to the economy of this nation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from Senator Evans's response that he has no intention of finding out, firstly, why these false returns were submitted to the ASC and, secondly, why they were not corrected until, on my initiative, the ASC demanded corrections. Judging from his response, Senator Evans feels that the Prime Minister is not responsible for a company that he half owns—that he has no responsibility whatsoever. I therefore ask Senator Evans, if and when he eventually gets around to deciding that there is some sort of responsibility on the government's side, whether he will ask the Prime Minister what sorts of penalties for these breaches have been levied against the Prime Minister's companies.

—I have nothing to add to my previous answer. The Prime Minister will give such further information as he thinks appropriate. However, it needs to be recalled that he is operating at arm's length from the day-to-day management. Financial accounts are often subject to correction or amendment, often at the request of the ASC or similar bodies. That is a very common, recurring factor in corporate management. Those opposite should be aware of that. Those of their colleagues who have dipped their fingers in corporate affairs should know something about it as well. Perhaps they should remind Dr Hewson of something about the management of companies because, with all his background and experience, he does not seem to know much about it.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the decision taken earlier, honourable senators may now resume their remarks concerning the retiring President and Senator Archer.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston—Mr President, in the spirit of what was resolved prior to question time, I suggest it would be more appropriate for the valedictories to proceed after taking note of answers. It is more logical to take note of answers immediately after they have been given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In informal discussions between myself, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Hill about this matter, we discussed the need to have question time at an appropriate stage. An understanding was reached that in bringing question time forward we would, on the cessation of question time, go back to congratulatory speeches and valedictories. In so doing, Senator Sibraa would have an opportunity to make a contribution to the debate. That was the spirit in which the decision was taken: we wished to assist Senator Hill in his desire to bring question time forward. When informal arrangements like this are made it is appropriate that we operate in that spirit and I suggest that the earlier decision be adhered to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I do not disagree with the spirit of that. When we negotiated to bring forward question time because we thought that was in the interests of everybody, I did not immediately reflect on the question of taking note. Senator Evans came back during question time and raised it. It does seem to me that taking note is, in effect, attached to question time.
—You have passed a motion. Come on, let's get on with it!
—I am, but it is not sensible that taking note should come on in another hour or hour and a half. I do not know how many senators will speak on the matter of the President's resignation.
—What difference does it make?

—Because taking note will simply not be attached to question time. There are matters arising out of question time.It is all right for Senator Evans to say that because it is not of his interest. It is of our interest and I do not think it is unreasonable to dispose of those brief interventions that arise out of matters that have caused us concern during question time and then get back to the long debate. I do not want to hold up Senator Sibraa. I know that he is waiting to resign and wants to speak in the chamber before he resigns. Obviously, we want to facilitate that.
—You are not doing so.

—We are, but a maximum of half an hour will not affect that in any material way at all. We have tried to develop these procedures today on the basis of something sensible and reasonable in the circumstances. I would have thought that disposing of taking note is sensible and reasonable.
—All right; it is not worth having a suspension of standing orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume this day, relating to the Prime Minister's investment in a piggery.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will be aware of the fact that Senator Gareth Evans gave no response whatsoever, apart from an attempt to blackguard me, which is typical and advances the issue nowhere. The question I asked related to a very serious matter. The serious matter is that companies half owned by the Prime Minister of this country have been found, as a result of an inquiry, to have filed returns very late—illegally late—with the Australian Securities Commission.

PARA.TAB: The companies have also filed returns which were false in material particulars. They massively overstated the value of the assets in the companies and they massively understated the volume of financial losses incurred by those companies in trading. The fact that these accounts also misstated in a serious way various liabilities and various assets in those accounts simply compounds the problem. These annual accounts were supposed to have been audited at this time.

It does the ASC no credit that it appears not to have noticed that these accounts should have been audited and that it allowed unaudited accounts to remain on its register as the appropriate accounts when they were ultimately filed years late by the Prime Minister's half-owned companies. The substance of those changes is just enormous. When, as a result of my pressure, the ASC required the Prime Minister's half-owned companies to have audited accounts, the ASC and its creditors found out for the first time—creditors like the Commonwealth Bank, which is owed $17 million and whose credit committee recommended that $4.5 million of that be written off as irrecoverable—that they were falsely advised by these accounts that basically these companies had some kind of financial health.

The fact is that, when they were audited, five of the seven companies in the group—and Senator Gareth Evans will no doubt regard this as unsubstantiated muckraking because it does not suit him—were found by the auditors to have a substantial, and in some cases very substantial, surplus of liabilities over their assets. They were technically insolvent. They could only remain in business—and they were audited on the basis that they were continuing in business, otherwise the assets would have been worth a lot less—with the continued support of which bank? The Commonwealth Bank; the bank that the Treasurer himself was responsible for. I remind the Senate that the Prime Minister bought his interest in this company while he was Treasurer.

The auditor's report said that these companies could continue in existence and continue to trade only with the support of their bank and also with the support of their ultimate shareholders. Who are the ultimate shareholders? On the one hand there is a Mr Constantinidis and on the other a Mr Keating. Where are the ultimate shareholders shown to have any kind of formal `responsibility' for these debts? It certainly does not appear in the Prime Minister's declaration of interests. That is why these reports—these false, late, misleading reports—were the central issue that I have been raising for two years. There is no doubt, as Senator Evans said, that there were some other peripheral matters that I raised in passing. I will be only too happy to debate them at some time, but the minister lacks the stomach to face up to the false declarations. These declarations were found to be false and have now been corrected only because of pressure from the Australian Securities Commission as a result of the pressure I put on it. It is only because of those corrections that we now know what the situation is. The Prime Minister was content to see those false declarations remain on the books of the Australian Securities Commission because he was not responsible. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in question time, the Prime Minister may or may not wish to respond further to the specific matters that have been raised by Senator Michael Baume today. If he does not respond, I would find that entirely understandable in the light of Senator Baume's extraordinary record of false and malicious claims made on a number of occasions about the nature of the Prime Minister's investment.

—I raise a point of order. I understood that it is normal for the chair to intervene when the word `malicious' is applied to an honourable senator. It imputes motives and I would have expected you to have taken action, Mr President.
—I am sorry. I did not hear the word used, but it is generally regarded as unparliamentary. I do ask Senator Evans to withdraw.
—At your request, Mr President, I withdraw. However, I make the point that Senator Baume's allegations—
—An unqualified withdrawal.

—I make the withdrawal at the President's request. I do so unqualifiedly, because he has requested me to do it unqualifiedly. Senator Baume's allegations, however, have been demonstrably and consistently wrong on all sorts of key issues, particularly on every occasion where there is some element involved of alleged misuse of public office or some taking advantage of a position of public trust to secure an advantage which might not be given to people in similar commercial circumstances. Senator Baume is nodding his head because that is exactly the nub of his allegation again today, because he is now making the issue the role of the Commonwealth Bank.

PARA.TAB: But what I was seeking to say in question time was that the whole community could be entirely forgiven for treating Senator Baume's allegations—or issues that he raised again—with complete contempt, given the record that he has already established. Let me remind the Senate quickly of that record. He claimed in the One Nation statement in February 1992 that Mr Keating lifted the FIRB threshold to $50 million so that the piggery in which he had an interest could enter a joint venture with a Danish company without the need for FIRB approval. However, that claim is wrong. The joint venture was approved by the FIRB under the original guidelines months before the change announced in the One Nation statement.

Senator Baume and other opposition senators have alleged that the Australia Quarantine and Inspection Service was told to expedite its consideration of requests by Danish interests for live pigs and live pig products to be imported into Australia. The insinuation was that Mr Keating had brought pressure on AQIS, misusing his office in the process, because of his personal financial interests. That again is wrong. The company in which Mr Keating has an interest has developed its pigs in Australia. It has never had any interest in importing pig or pig products from Denmark. By definition, Brown and Hatton was involved in the joint venture with Danpork because of the ban on importation. So Mr Keating would hardly derive any benefit from a relaxation of the quarantine restrictions. AQIS officers moreover told the Senate estimates committee hearing that they had never been approached by the Danpork-Brown and Hatton joint venture, nor would one expect them to have been under any circumstances.

Senator Baume has consistently and deliberately misinterpreted the accounts of Brown and Hatton and other companies. On 12 November last year he claimed that Mr Keating's investment had risen in value inexplicably from $430,000 to $4.2 million within six weeks. He said that Mr Keating appeared to have been allowed to buy shares at an extraordinarily favourable price. Senator Lewis later suggested under parliamentary privilege that that was a bribe. But the audit accounts, which those opposite are so willing to talk about today, were a demonstration that the value of Mr Keating's investment has not risen at all. On the contrary, it has almost certainly fallen. In January this year—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read what I said, Gareth.
—Senator Baume made his biggest mistake—
—Order! Senator Baume, you have been heard in silence.

—His biggest mistake this time was getting it wrong outside the Senate, without the protection of parliamentary privilege. He claimed that a company in which Mr Keating had an interest applied for a taxation benefit under a policy introduced in the One Nation statement. Among other defamatory imputations he implied that Mr Keating had broken the obligations of his office as Prime Minister by introducing a policy measure so as to provide for himself a private financial benefit.

PARA.TAB: He is wrong again, because no company associated with Mr Keating had applied for any such taxation benefit. Senator Baume was caught absolutely cold in this respect—100 per cent wrong. On 26 May the New South Wales Supreme Court, against his objections, held that imputations contained in Mr Keating's statement of claim for defamation were appropriate to be drawn from what Senator Baume had to say and should go before a jury. That is where the matter lies. Accordingly, it is not appropriate to comment on that in any more detail.

But what I am saying—and it is relevant to the response to these imputations, sleaze and innuendo—is that Senator Baume's track record is absolutely appalling. He is out there with his trowel, his trawl. He is muckraking, trying to raise by innuendo over and over again some imputation against the Prime Minister of misuse of public office, or irresponsible or inappropriate behaviour. He is wrong. He has been wrong every time in the past; and every time in the future he seeks to go on with this he will be proven wrong.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Senator Cook) to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day, relating to regional development.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take issue with some comments made by Senator Cook in his answer to me concerning the inquiry costing $1.25 million into impediments in relation to the development of certain regional areas and the fact that those regional areas are Labor marginal seats.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook attempted to tell the Senate that this was all done on strictly impartial and established guidelines. Just as I said his answer was worthy of Mrs Kelly and her sports rorts, we are now entering an era of regional rorts. Mr Cunningham, who is the caucus portfolio committee chairman in Mr Griffith's previous position, has become a pleader for political patronage. In the article that I referred to, which Senator Cook tried to say was generated by me, he failed to mention that Mr Cunningham is quoted as saying that he had lobbied hard to have the Latrobe Valley included in the survey, and that he made no apology at all for that.

In other words, Mr Cunningham is admitting that he had pleaded for political patronage. Senator Cook's statement that somehow these regions were chosen with proper motives and in accordance with properly established standards is not true; Mr Cunningham has said that he pleaded to be included in the study. It was not done as a response to a proper and orderly administration of criteria, but as a result of the chairman of the caucus portfolio committee pleading for political patronage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably I was between my office and the chamber for most of what Senator Bishop had to say, but I was here for the concluding remarks. I know that Senator Bishop is fleeing this chamber in pursuit of her leadership ambitions. It is a pity in a way that the timing may mean she is able to take part in her celebrated victimisation of public servants at estimates committee proceedings. But the estimates committees are the logical place in which this would be pursued.

PARA.TAB: The slur I have just heard her conclude on is indeed properly described as that. It is a slur. But what she has done seems to me to knit together a couple of half-baked ideas in order to create some sort of controversy, hopefully on which she can ride to greater public notoriety.

That is not surprising from the Liberal Party, because in its period of government it was attended by a whole range of controversies and allegations of manipulation. One of its Senate leaders was required by the Prime Minister at the time, Malcolm Fraser, to resign under such a charge. People coming from that background might see manipulation in everything—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not come from any background.
—The honourable senator comes from the background and culture of that party. I answered truthfully and from my brief, and nothing that Senator Bishop has said can change that.
—You have just admitted you didn't hear it.

—I said I did not hear Senator Bishop's last remarks in full. I did not hear the middle of her intervention on this occasion. But the question she asked me contained an allegation of manipulation of this study for electoral purposes—and that is a fraudulent allegation. If she makes it, she is being fraudulent.

PARA.TAB: The answer I gave, which is the truth, is that the regions were selected by a group of public servants representing a diversity of departmental interests, properly representing the interests of industry, the Prime Minister's department and regional Australia. They made those decisions without reference to the minister—as they were empowered to do—or, as I am advised, without reference to his office.

It is a calumny on those people and their integrity that the honourable senator should raise this slur and it is a calumny that will reflect back on her. But they are the facts of the matter, and while the facts can be manipulated they cannot be overturned and must remain as the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —It remains to be seen.
—They do remain as the case.
—Members of this party lobbied hard.

—People lobby in a political process. I am telling Senator Bishop the truth of how the decision was made. Senator Bishop lobbies all the time but whether anyone pays any attention to her is another matter. It may be of great bitterness that less attention is paid to her than she would like—certainly by the government. What I have said is the truth. This was an arm's length decision by the government made by public servants discharging an obligation to arrive at the right criteria and select objectively the best areas.

PARA.TAB: The truth is, on almost any mosaic of regional Australia, some marginal seats will be caught up. It is a perversion of logic to say that therefore the whole thing is done from that perspective. It is not and was not. The McKinsey organisation, which is conducting this survey and is shortly to complete it, is a reputable organisation, internationally and in Australia. I think its participation in this ought not to be subject to the sort of allegation that Senator Bishop has made either because it damages it commercially. Politicians make allegations from time to time which bring this place into disrepute and give rise to the allegation that this is cowards' castle, because they hide behind parliamentary privilege in doing so. I suspect this is one such occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I commence my remarks by congratulating you on your election to the position of President. I would also like to comment on the issue of the important question raised today by Senator Bishop and the fact that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Senator Cook) has now walked out of the chamber. He obviously came in purely to engage in a slicing up process because he heard Senator Bishop making a response.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we address this issue that affects a coterie of mates in a particular area of Labor Party largess. As Senator Bishop very rightly mentioned in her original question, this involved not only former minister Griffiths and his officers but also current members, Mr Cunningham and Mr Lindsay, and, of course, several other former members who are currently on the payroll as consultants.

In this important area of regionalism it is important to note the close linking of all of those particular players. Whether it is the former member for Adelaide or whether it is the former member for Hinkler, they obviously have to be called to account and will be pursued actively, I would say, by honourable senators on this side of the chamber in the estimates with regard to their participation. It is also important to note the role of Mr Lindsay in the Townsville region. He should therefore necessarily be called to account.

But Senator Bishop just raised a few minutes ago the important area of Mr Cunningham's involvement and where he has actively courted and sought the funding in this particular issue. I would like to remind the Senate of questions that I placed at the estimates some time ago about the role of Mr Cunningham when he was out of the federal parliament for one term during which time the government, as part of the mates' deal, appointed Mr Cunningham as the administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in the Indian Ocean. During that period Mr Cunningham enjoyed the office of privilege as the administrator—I think his salary was in the order of $70,000 or $80,000 per annum—with extensive travel rights and entitlements for his family. The information that was made available then to the Senate was important and called into question his continuing role.

Mr Cunningham was important in the commissioning of the ship R.J. Hawke that was put into the lagoon at Cocos Island at very great expense. There was involvement of members in and out of this parliament. Mr Cunningham, when he was out in the position that he occupied on the Cocos Islands, was important. The question now of the former member for Adelaide and the former member for Hinkler and their supposed involvement in the regional development portfolio needs to be actively monitored and pursued by this Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, made four allegations against me in which he claimed I had done various things. Firstly, I want to say that most of them are simply not true. I did not do the things that it is claimed I have done. I did not, for example, initiate questions about the quarantine service and pig semen. I have to say, whether it is good for me or not, that I am not an expert in the matter of pig semen and I have no intention of becoming such an expert.
—That is hard to swallow.

—I acknowledge that interjection. It merits inclusion in Hansard. The next matter I want to raise is a delicate matter and I am astounded that Senator Evans should raise it. It is a matter which is sub judice. I stress that it is wrong to ascribe to me a claim that Mr Keating's companies had sought a tax benefit. What I had said—and this is central to the issue—is that the New South Wales government had issued a press statement saying that the group was to apply for a tax benefit under the new arrangements. I said that if this is so it would raise questions of potential conflict of interest.

PARA.TAB: It is just intolerable that I should be misrepresented in this place at a time when this matter is before the courts. I am astounded that a lawyer, albeit an academic one of Senator Evans's stated status, should in fact behave in such a disgraceful manner. I would like the opportunity at some stage to deal with the other accusations he made in which he wrongly alleged I was wrong. No doubt an appropriate opportunity will arrive in debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I extend my congratulations to you on your election to the high office of President of the Senate. I am confident that you will provide the dignity and impartiality applying to this office. The hallmark of your predecessor, Senator Sibraa, apart from his presidency, was his stoic work in relation to the international arena, particularly the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. It is therefore fitting that Senator Sibraa has been given the diplomatic post in Zimbabwe with wide responsibility for a number of countries in Africa. I ask that he extend his enthusiasm to perhaps the smallest country in Africa, Zambia, where my daughter has a personal interest. I believe that Senator Sibraa will carry out his diplomatic tasks with distinction.

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Archer entered the Senate in 1975—associated with the landslides of that year—together with his colleague Senator Walters. Many of the party successes in Tasmania have been attributed to Senator Archer. They are due to his foresight in planning strategies. My colleague Senator Hill has actually outlined a lot of his parliamentary contributions to the Senate. Rather than traverse those remarks, I will concentrate on his community interests, which spread widely along the north-west coast and won him great respect.
