For a number of years the seat of Braddon has been the heartland of liberalism in Tasmania at both state and federal levels. I would like to remind the Senate that this success is in no small part due to the work of Brian Archer. It will not be easy for the Senate selection committee to replace a man of the capabilities and sincerity of Senator Archer.

As shadow minister for science from 1985 to 1987, Senator Archer travelled widely within Australia and brought the Canberra scene much closer to scientists across Australia. At the end of his tenure he was certainly well known within the science community across this country for his very close interest and pragmatic approach.

In his professional capacity he was widely respected by the Real Estate Institute of Australia. He was a member of the federal executive of the Real Estate Institute for a number of years. In fact, he was president of that institute in Tasmania on four occasions.

In another interest, he actually pioneered the Limousin breed of cattle in Australia and was the Tasmanian delegate to the Australian Limousin Breeders Association between 1972 and 1986. His interests were not confined to cattle because he was a pioneer in the sheep industry. Here he also rose to distinction as a notable and very successful prolific sheep breeder. In fact, he was an executive member of the prolific sheep breeders between 1981 and 1986.

In conclusion, I would like to wish Brian Archer a long and happy retirement. I wish his wife all the best because it was Dorothy who so strongly supported him on so many occasions. The words of a rough fisherman when addressing our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on one occasion perhaps should be my parting remarks. He said that the worth of a politician is in the quality of his representation. That quality was certainly the hallmark of Brian Archer's parliamentary career.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I congratulate you, Mr President, on your election to the presidency. I am sure that with your skills and background you will be a successful President.

PARA.TAB: I rise to refer to two colleagues, the first being Senator Sibraa. I first worked with Senator Sibraa in 1971 and was a work mate of his for many years. I then joined him in the Senate from 1981 until now. I can honestly say that we have never exchanged a harsh word, even under often difficult circumstances when we have had to represent different points of view in a whole range of circumstances.

The thing that characterises Kerry Sibraa is his complete professionalism in all his duties. He pays great attention to detail. In the days when we were assessing electoral results or whatever else was happening, we both approached problems carefully and in a rather conservative way. The other characteristic that Kerry Sibraa has brought into the parliament is that of looking after the little people in both the Labor Party and the cities and country towns of this country, and also in representing the people of New South Wales. Once again, it has been his attention to detail in looking after and representing people that has been very effective.

I have been fortunate to go overseas with Senator Sibraa to Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conferences. It has already been said how well known and how well respected he was—indeed, he was synonymous with Australia for a long period at CPA meetings. I believe that all his life's work now prepares him for the next phase of his career, or even the next career that he is going to follow. I wish him well in that career. I think he is ideally suited, with all the experience that we have all described today, to be a successful ambassador for this country.

I turn to a person of a similar type in Brian Archer, because Brian Archer has done something very similar for the Liberal Party. I first joined what was the current industry committee under a slightly different name, in 1981 when Brian Archer was its chair. Former senator Ruth Coleman was also a chair of that committee for a period, but we have had continuity on that committee. One of the characteristics that Brian Archer contributed to that committee was a very practical approach to all the problems that come before it. That rather sums up Brian Archer's character, which is to approach things with great dignity and skill.

Recently we received a fishing report. I think Brian might have felt that, having disposed of a report in the last days of the last week of December, he might well now give away his need to represent the fishing industry. I cannot say that he will now eat fish because I do not think he has ever been able to eat fish.

He has also been a representative of a whole range of other industries—the clothing industry, agriculture, sheep and horticulture—that have been referred to. I think he can well go into retirement realising that I, for one, and I know other people, have recognised the attention to detail and the skills that he has brought on behalf of the Liberal Party to the problems that he has faced. I wish him well in his retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, at the outset I congratulate you on your election. I am sure that we will work well together. Might I say with humility that I am happy to offer whatever goodwill and assistance I can to you. If our working relationship is as effective as that between your comrade Senator Sibraa and me, I am sure we will get on famously.

PARA.TAB: I had the distinction of working with Senator Sibraa as the Deputy President for but a short period. I do not know whether it has been observed today but, save for six months, Senator Sibraa would have been the longest serving President that the Senate has experienced. Senator Sir Alister McMullin, I am advised, is the longest serving by six months or a little more.

I have had the distinction of working with Senator Sibraa. I will not claim him to be a friend because I would not wish to taint his future career or his relationship with his colleagues, but perhaps I can modestly describe him as a close acquaintance. I always found him to be impeccably fair in the discharge of his duties and responsibilities, both in the chair and outside it. I believe he enhanced his reputation as a most distinguished President by his thoroughly impartial manner in the way in which he dealt with not only his colleagues but also all other senators.

While the conduct of the Senate is the public face of the President, as you no doubt know, Mr President, there are many obligations, duties and responsibilities outside the chamber which daily cause you to be in personal contact with senators. Much of this goes unobserved and unnoticed, as senators from both sides—very often from our side—complain to the President about the conduct of events and matters affecting them in the parliament. To my knowledge, Senator Sibraa was impeccably fair and very decent and honest in his dealings with all senators who went to him with their trials, tribulations and problems.

I am sure that he has the respect of senators from both sides of the chamber. I think the way that his appointment to Zimbabwe has been reflected on this side of the chamber—a political appointment to a diplomatic post—says something not about the principle of appointment but about our judgment of Senator Sibraa's appropriateness and fitness for that position. I am sure we all wish him well in his new position and in his new career.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to join the Senate in congratulating you on your election to the very high and responsible office. I do that with all sincerity. You would be aware that I was not one of the people who voted for you when this matter was discussed and determined within our party this morning. It would not come as any surprise to you, Mr President, that that was the case. We have known each other for very many years now—I think we are all getting long in the tooth on these things—and we have known that from time to time we can disagree with each other, and disagree very violently. Nonetheless, when decisions are made, we know that the respect from either side is passed on to the next one.

PARA.TAB: I stand here publicly and state that, despite the views that I expressed this morning in support of a different candidate for your high office, you will now have the total cooperation and loyalty that one would expect from this side of the chamber and, indeed, from the chamber itself. It is a very responsible task that you have taken upon yourself. You have discovered in the last hour or so that it is a very difficult job from time to time. I am certain that you will get the cooperation of the majority of senators in this place to ensure that this chamber works well and does its job on behalf of the people whom we are elected to represent in this place.

Mr President, it is unfortunate that our colleague from Western Australia, Senator Chamarette, introduced a bit of a sour note into the congratulations to you this afternoon. I take it as being a sour note in her complaining and blaming everybody else for the fact that there was not a woman candidate for the position of the high office that you occupy. I suggest that, if the good senator felt so strongly about that, she had it within her hands to put forward a person of that gender for that position. She chose not to and she should not blame everybody else in this place for not doing so.

Mr President, I ask you to dismiss the rather sanctimonious advice that the good senator gave to you in talking about the representation from our state of Western Australia. She has not been elected to this place; she is a replacement senator for a previously elected senator who resigned. Her personal vote was a matter of a few hundred. I do not think that she is really in a position to be offering advice as to what the views of the citizenship of Western Australia are on matters. At least with the other main parties in this chamber, we see and hear from constituents and lobby groups which have expounded a range of views—not all of which we agree to from time to time, but we necessarily see them and we are able to make decisions, balance them, take them further within our respective parties and arrive at decisions.

I am sorry that I too had to introduce a sour note into the congratulations this afternoon, but I felt that those matters should be on the record. I believe it is the first occasion—and I have not had time to check the record—that a member or a senator from Western Australia has gained either of the high offices of presiding officer of the Commonwealth parliament. That being the case, double congratulations are due to you, Mr President, on what you have achieved here this afternoon.

I also take this opportunity to pass on my congratulations to the retiring President, Senator Sibraa, and wish him well in his new and equally challenging position as a diplomatic representative of this country. Many fine words have been said about Senator Sibraa's work in foreign affairs. Many of the people who have spoken know of his work much better and much more so than I do, but I certainly join with them in wishing him well in his future career.

Senator Archer has also been mentioned in the debate. I, as chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Publications, will be losing my deputy. That was one of the positions that Brian cherished. He boasted to me some time last year that he was the longest serving member of that committee. Certainly, when any advice was needed on the committee he was able to refer back in his memory to previous decisions of the committee. You, Mr President, as a member of the committee will vouch for what I am saying. Brian will be missed on that committee, as, indeed, he will be missed from the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which Senator Childs spoke about earlier.

I would like to test your patience, Mr President, on this afternoon when congratulations have been offered to all and sundry, to add to the list a further senator who is deserving of congratulations, although not in the same framework as those who have been previously mentioned. On Saturday Senator Nick Bolkus entered a new phase of his personal life when he got married. I think that all four senators who have been mentioned—Mr President, Mr Archer, Senator Sibraa, and Senator Bolkus—have taken on additional challenges. I would not like to try to distinguish which of the challenges each individual has taken on will be the hardest, but I certainly wish each and every one of them well in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to congratulate you on your appointment to the position of President. My only sadness is that we will lose you from the corridor. I hope that your office does not get filled with bureaucrats, since I am beginning to feel isolated with only Senator Troeth left in our corridor. The rest of the offices seem not to have members of parliament. I am hoping that somebody will replace you there, perhaps the new senator from Tasmania. It has been an interesting corridor with Senator Walsh as an occupant, but I will particularly miss you. I also wish to congratulate Senator Sibraa and wish him all the best.

PARA.TAB: My colleagues have mentioned the achievements of Senator Brian Archer in this chamber and in the various committees. I wish to recall the time in which he was of personal assistance to me in my first year in the old Parliament House. I found the chamber a rather intimidating place. I spoke far too quickly, which is one of my problems. Brian decided that he would take this new tyro under his wing and offer his support and advice. I knew that when I got up to speak in the chamber, within a minute or so I could turn around and see Brian in the chamber. For just over 12 months, every time I spoke Brian was there. He would give me encouragement on the content and speed of my speech. Any other advice that he thought necessary was always positive and always very supportive. A person does not often get that support in politics and for that I am very grateful.

Brian was a great friend and would offer me wise counsel and wise advice. His presence will still be reflected in those of us here who will carry on using the skills that he helped develop quietly behind the scenes in many of the new senators. I wish Brian and his wife, Dorothy, all the best in the future and thank him for his contribution here. It was a contribution based on his integrity, his faith and also his sense of humour and his sense of commitment to other people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to congratulate you on your elevation to this high office. I point out that in my only parliamentary trip in this parliament, you and I, led by Dr Klugman, went to the Philippines and Korea. It was intended, at the time, to go to Japan, but at that stage the Emperor was dying and there was some confusion about that and so we missed going to Japan. But I am sure you, Mr President, and I would certainly remember our trip to Korea and to the Philippines and that Dr Klugman did not like travelling by aeroplane. As deputy leader of that delegation, I ended up having to lead the delegation in northern Samar and Davao. We travelled in a clapped out old aeroplane and you might recall that we had to go up and stand beside the pilot so that he could leave the airstrip at Manila. Subsequently, we found our way through a rainstorm into northern Samar. When we left northern Samar, I think there was one metre left at the end of the runway before we took off in the plane. Landing back in Manila during a tropical cyclone added to the joy of the trip!

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you might also recall that we intended to charter an aircraft to travel to the naval and air force base, but Dr Klugman insisted on driving. The plane we intended to charter in fact crashed. So it was an interesting experience and an opportunity for us to personally get to know one another. The openness with which you addressed yourself there and the bipartisan way in which we all conducted ourselves was a lesson to all delegations.

Mr President, you follow in the footsteps of two other presidents whom I have served with in this place—Senator Douglas McClelland and Senator Sibraa. They have given a great lead by way of fairness and justice to all concerned on all sides of the chamber. They have set a precedent which I am sure you will follow. I think their example explains the relatively better behaviour of this chamber compared with the other place. I wish Senator Sibraa well in his new diplomatic career.

I would like to talk about Brian Archer. It was typical of Brian that he elected to leave this place without any fanfare. Brian retires from the Senate after years of service to Tasmania and to the people of Australia. He has had a very distinguished parliamentary career which has been recorded by my colleagues on both sides in this place.

When I first became a senator, the Senate in the old Parliament House was a little different from what it is today. At that stage the person who was put beside me—now the Leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate, Senator Hill—was doing a lot of overseas travel. I well recall that at that time he had a passion for plant variety rights, which I had never heard of. He was most disturbed that I did not have the same passion to leap to my feet to speak about it. However, those days were very different from what happens today. Little assistance was given to newcomers, who were expected to learn by experience. As Senator Patterson indicated, Brian went out of his way to give freely of his knowledge and guidance.

We have heard about Brian's interest in fishing, but science was one of his most compelling interests. He had an abiding enthusiasm for science and scientists. He believed that scientists in Australia were neglected compared with those in other countries, and that this was to the long-term detriment of Australia. His interest was in both pure and applied science. He was a great proponent of increased expenditure on research in both the private and public sectors.

I recall that on one occasion Brian was agitating for an increase of a few hundred thousand dollars in a particular area of interest. He would badger anyone who had his particular interests, and I was one of those people. I unearthed an article from a magazine which highlighted projected expenditure for research of some billions of dollars—billions, not millions, of dollars—in Korea. I sent him a copy of the article with a note attached saying, `Brian, I think you should just put up the white flag now'. He was delighted as it highlighted his very worthy cause.

Another one of Brian's compelling interests—this was mentioned by Senator Hill—is Taiwan. Through its representatives in Australia, he encouraged parliamentarians—of which I was one—to visit Taiwan. As a result of his efforts, many have. As was indicated, I think by Senator Hill, there is no doubt that Senator Archer's lobbying helped diminish his perception of what he felt was unfair treatment of a country with which we had so much trade. A development of great satisfaction to Brian which occurred not too long before he retired was the introduction of direct flights between Taipei and Australia.

Finally, Brian is a person of great principle who admired greatly those he perceived as having integrity and honesty. He was absolutely unforgiving of those he believed had acted in any way dishonourably. Knowing this, I might say that I was honoured that Brian saw fit to let me know in advance of his intention to resign.

Brian leaves the Senate with many friends on both sides of politics. He will be missed not only by his colleagues but particularly by members of the science fraternity who knew that Brian's door was always open to them. I would like to thank Brian for his friendship to me personally. I am sure that he and Dorothy will make the best of his retirement from the Senate, and that he will continue to pursue his interests with vigour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join other senators in congratulating you, Mr President, on your unopposed election to your high office. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I would like to say a few words about Senator Archer, who was an assiduous representative of the north-west of Tasmania, in particular, and an effective senator for the whole of Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: Senator Archer's committee work has been well documented, and is well appreciated, if perhaps unheralded. Similarly well appreciated is Brian Archer's capacity as an advocate on a personal level for individual constituents, particularly those with problems in trade, transport, small business, primary industry and, as has been mentioned often, especially the fishing industry. In fact, during the debate on the future of Australia's prawn fisheries I was quickly introduced to Brian's comprehensive knowledge of that area.

Brian was generous in sharing his technical knowledge, and his helpfulness has been mentioned by two of his Liberal Party colleagues. From personal experience I know that that helpfulness extended across party lines, and I for one appreciated that. His interest in and dedication to certain issues was also pursued across party lines. He demonstrated this when he crossed the floor to vote against his party on the issue of tobacco advertising, demonstrating not only his courage on certain issues but also his breadth of interests.

As many others have reminded us, Brian Archer's range of interests was fascinatingly wide. An area of interest which illustrates his capacity for innovative thought and practical benefits for all Australians is the use of aircraft for firefighting. It was more than 10 years ago that Brian Archer asked sensible questions about using aircraft to dump water on bushfires. This matter was raised in the news media very recently. Almost a decade ago Brian Archer joined people such as Norm Sanders and Colin Mason in expressing an interest in this subject. Senator John Coulter has pursued that interest in recent years.

Brian Archer will be well remembered for his persistence in following many issues. I particularly remember that, late one night, Brian Archer revealed to the world that the proposed new user-pays charges to be levied upon primary producers for the conduct of the national residue survey would be applied in a disproportionately unfair manner. I am sure it is not unfair to remind Minister Cook that at that time, as the minister representing the minister for primary industries, he was unable to satisfy Senator Archer with an explanation as to why onions would cost considerably more to survey than potatoes, carrots or any other vegetables for that matter. The minister tried several times to brush off Senator Archer's concerns, but he was confronted with evermore basic, plain and unequivocal demonstrations by Senator Archer that the straightforward, commonsense of his argument should prevail. In the end I think Senator Cook just gave up, saying that he would provide Senator Archer with an explanation at a later date.

That is what Brian Archer was about. He was consistent and innovative; he was polite and persistent; and he was perceptive and productive. I know that these qualities will continue to stand him in good stead in his retirement, how ever he chooses to pursue it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to express my congratulations to you on your election. You have a very important role to carry out which will require firmness and fairness and I am sure you will be judged on how you assert those two qualities. I am confident that the judgment will be a good one and will reflect very favourably on you.

PARA.TAB: I have been impressed by Senator Sibraa's fairness and, at the same time, his firmness when dealing with issues in this place. I think he has had a very practical approach to his role as President of the Senate. I have seen Senator Sibraa's patience tested on many occasions but he was always, with some sense of humour, able to handle a situation. There never appeared to me to be any nastiness exhibited by him.

I have known for some time of his interest in Africa. I express a great deal of confidence that his role in Africa will certainly be a plus for this nation because of his dedication to getting a good result in that area, both for people in Africa and for people in Australia. I have great confidence in that regard. I also express my best wishes to Senator Sibraa for his future in that role.

I would like to talk about Senator Archer. I once said to ex-Senator Peter Baume that, when I came to this place, I had a fairly jaundiced view of the opposition, which is not unexpected from a militant trade union official. I set out to dislike everybody on the other side of the chamber. I found that some people on the other side of the chamber made it very easy for me to continue to dislike them. But there were those who made it a bit more difficult because they were really decent people whose views differed from mine. I said to Peter Baume that Senator Archer made it absolutely impossible to dislike him because of the way in which he behaved and the sense of fairness and objectivity he brought to this chamber.

Senator Archer was one of the first people with whom I worked on various committees. He indicated to me at a very early stage that he was both forthright and helpful, that he had a lot of knowledge that was useful to committees and which translated into good recommendations to this chamber, and that he weighed up evidence by looking for truth and objectivity, not in terms of self-interest either for him or for the opposition, which he served so well. I am sorry he has gone but, more importantly, I will be glad to see him again when I cross his path in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I, too, congratulate you on your election to the office of President. I would also like to place on record my appreciation of Senator Sibraa in his role as President. When I came into this place, filling a casual vacancy, apart from Senator Reid, the first person I saw was Senator Sibraa in his role as President. He certainly made what was then a strange place much easier for me to come into. On various other occasions I have had cause to agree that Senator Sibraa fulfilled the role of President with dignity and fairness.

PARA.TAB: I particularly want to direct my remarks to my colleague Brian Archer who, when I first came to this place, took me under his wing. I was appointed to the committee that he served as deputy chairman and had previously served as chairman, that committee being the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, as it was called at that time. Like Senator Patterson and Senator Parer who spoke before me, I must say that Senator Archer's role in this place seemed to be to look after new members as they came into this chamber and to make sure that, firstly, they did not get lost; secondly, they knew exactly what was on the agenda of whatever meeting they were going to; and, thirdly, they were shepherded through those early stages of being on a committee. He did it with a sense of fairness which has been acknowledged by Senator Burns and Senator Childs, particularly in relation to the industry, science and technology committee. I do not know whether or not it is something to do with Tasmanian senators, but the other committee I happened to serve on was chaired by Senator Watson and I think he has those same qualities of fairness that Senator Archer had.

During the past 18 months of serving on the committee with Senator Archer, I have come to appreciate the efforts that he put into committee work and certainly the guidance that he gave me, as my senior coalition colleague on that committee. His advice has been invaluable. Certainly on that committee I came to know the extent of his knowledge, particularly of the fishing industry which we seemed to spend a long time on, as Senator Burns well knows.

I remember Senator Archer particularly for one thing that he said probably on the first or second occasion that I attended a committee meeting. I remember walking with him to the committee hearing when there were a couple of decisions to be made in relation to an inquiry into tariff structure or some imposition of tariffs. Brian said to me, `There is one thing that you have to learn here, young fella. The important thing is that, whatever the politics are, we have to make sure that the result we get is the right result, that it is a good result and that it is good for everybody. It is important that we get it right'.

I think Senator Archer worked towards that. On every occasion that I ever sat with him on committees, he was always concerned about the outcomes and that the deliberations made by those committees resulted in the right decisions that were in the best interests of everybody concerned. I hope that I have learnt from him and that I will be able to put some of his good attributes into practice as I continue on that committee. I certainly thank him for his help and wish both Brian and his wife, Dorothy, who was wonderful company whenever we went anywhere together, all the best in their retirement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, congratulations to you. I think everyone has said it all, and I join with all the other people in congratulating you. As you said in your acceptance speech, you have very big shoes to fill. I am quite sure that has been said about every other President who has taken the chair. You will obviously be judged by your whip on your ability to control this chamber, the discipline you impose and your fairness. I wish you well because I believe that you have the capacity to do all those things.

PARA.TAB: When the previous President, Kerry Sibraa, took over from Doug McClelland, I remember everyone said that nobody would be as good as Doug. I believe Senator Sibraa has been fair and helpful when he has been in the chair. I imagine trying to run this place, especially after the move up here, is not very easy to do. The new Parliament House has not been an easy place to run, but I think he has tried his hardest and, in conjunction with the Joint House Department, has done it pretty well.

I wish to add a couple of things that I think he has done exceptionally well. One is the joint functions that we have had in the private dining room, which have been conducted with the Speaker. I am quite sure that all those who attended those functions would agree with me that the previous President, Kerry Sibraa, always spoke for only a short time, was always right to the point and was not quite as longwinded as some of the Speakers from the House of Representatives were over time. Honourable senators in this chamber will know who I am talking about when I say that. Senator Sibraa's work for the CPA, which I had a bit to do with on the executive, was excellent, as was his hosting of the IPU conference, which has already been mentioned.

Another area I would like to cover was mentioned by the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot)—that of rugby league. One of the highlights of the previous President was the fact that he brought such a popular sport into this parliament by way of the rugby league friendship committee and the way in which he extended hospitality to all those people who wanted to participate in that committee, which fostered goodwill between the people of this place and one of the premier codes of football in Australia. Senator Gareth Evans has already mentioned Kerry Sibraa's hospitality, which I also acknowledge. It was fantastic.

Kerry Sibraa has always been a political foe of mine. He was the President of Senate and, in that capacity, he was a friend. I believe he did the job quite well. Best wishes to Kerry and his new wife in his VIP appointment. We will let him know at every opportunity how Manly fares in the rugby league competition because I am quite sure he will want to know about that.

In relation to Senator Brian Archer, late of this place—he is not late, of course; he is still with us and will be with us for a long time—he was the Mr BP of this place, the quiet achiever. As has already been said, Mr BA of this place was the quiet achiever.

One area that has not been covered is the fact that he was a great friend of Taiwan, especially in the days when it was not recognised as any sort of a country. Tonight we have an unofficial visit from the President and the Vice-President of the legislative yuan of Taiwan. I am quite sure that Brian Archer would have loved to be here for that. He was the instigator of the friendship group and did an exceptional job in keeping it going in those tough days when nobody wanted to know about a country which was so important to us as a trading partner.

Mention has already been made of Brian Archer and the fishing industry. I commend him for the work he did. I was on different committees with him—for example, the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and, when I first came into this place, the Publications Committee. He was a top committee person and we owe him a lot for what he did. As a Limousin breeder he did a lot for that breed in the country. Even though he is not going back to breeding he will obviously be able to give advice to a lot of people.

He did so much behind the scenes. He left this place without a lot of fuss—he did not want anybody to say `thank you' to him; he just wanted to repair to another place—unlike many other people. I wish him and Dorothy a very happy retirement and say, `Brian, when you were here you did much for many'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I begin my brief remarks by congratulating you on your election to office. It gives me real personal pleasure to extend my congratulations to you. As we enter our second decade of government, you and I enter our second decade, or better, of friendship. It really is a great honour for me to be able to say `congratulations' to you on your election. I know you will perform in a first-class manner, as you have done when you have taken on all other tasks in public office. That is very much in the tradition established by your recent predecessors of fairness, commonsense, and going out of their way to make certain that the chamber works effectively.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to be associated with the comments made about Senator Archer. I got to know him through his very great interest in foreign policy, especially in respect of relations between Australia and Taiwan. It is fitting—following on from Senator Brownhill's observations—that I should have come into the chamber having chaired a meeting of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which met with the President and Vice-President of the Taiwanese parliament. Ten or 12 years ago people would not have believed that possible. In no small measure it is due to the work of Senator Archer. His formation of the Australia-Taiwan parliamentary friendship group and his continual interest and energetic advocacy of improved political ties between the two countries have meant that over recent years the linkages have grown and prospered.

Having made those observations, I would like to say a few words about my friend Kerry Sibraa. Like Senator Richardson earlier today, I can best put this in a personal context. In the latter part of 1975, not long after the defeat of the Whitlam government, I was approached by the then assistant general secretary of the New South Wales ALP, Graham Richardson, and asked whether I was interested in going to work for a new senator—Senator Sibraa—whose political interests were much the same as my own. He had been elected at that double dissolution general election. His particular interests were foreign affairs, defence policy and industrial relations.

After thinking it through for a week or two I put aside an invitation to write a doctoral thesis and went to work for Kerry. That was one of the best decisions I have ever made because it was a great experience working for him for a period of 18 months or so. Certainly I could have written a thesis on that period of 18 months looking at Australian politics from an entirely new perspective rather than from within an academic confine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Kerry would wish you didn't.

—As Senator Jones interjects, there are a great many stories I can tell. Unfortunately, I cannot put them all on the public record, but when the inevitable round of farewells start for Kerry I am sure a few of us will tell stories in a very good natured way. I learnt a great deal. I learnt a great deal about the history of the ALP from someone who knew it intimately through his work in the trade union movement and through his work in the ALP at state and national levels.

PARA.TAB: People have remarked on Kerry's interest in the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, his interest in the politics of Africa and his capacity to act as the patron for a number of community organisations. But perhaps one thing that is not really understood about him is that Kerry is also a formidable electoral campaigner. He has an encyclopedic knowledge of the Electoral Act. He was obliged to acquire that knowledge in that he ran on a number of occasions from the death seat—I think he coined that expression—being the final Senate seat in New South Wales. It now has a national application and applies across the board not only in the Labor Party but in all political parties. That death seat contest for the Senate is always a very tough one.

In 1975 Kerry was elected by only 2,054 of the literally millions of votes that were cast. So he acquired a very great working knowledge of the Electoral Act, election processes and how best to campaign for the Senate. In 1977 he was defeated and was out of the parliament for a short time before he came back to replace Senator James McClelland, who retired.

There are many stories that I cannot tell, but one I am pleased to be able to tell concerns Edward Gough Whitlam. It gives some idea of the working relationship in the office at that time. Kerry was always able to personalise political events. He told a story of the period of the ALP federal executive in the late 1960s shortly before Mr Whitlam brought Labor back to power. Kerry was responsible for organising the logistics of the ALP federal executive meeting one particular morning. Gough was always the first to arrive and he was there about an hour before the executive was due to arrive, just reading the daily papers. I think Senator Jones has heard this story over the years.

The leader of the ALP was looking at the international news and noted that there had been three or four new countries admitted to the United Nations as the result of successful independence movements. He looked up and said to Kerry, `My God, comrade, they are creating countries faster than I can visit them'. I do not know whether that remark had an undue impact upon the person who later, in 1987, would become President of the Senate, but certainly Kerry's interest in foreign policy and in visiting countries which had or had not been admitted to the United Nations is something approaching legend.

He is a great political campaigner; there is no question about that. I learnt a lot about campaigning in rural and provincial areas of New South Wales and beyond. I learnt a very great deal about scrutineering and about the history of the electoral process.

As Senator Brownhill mentioned, when Kerry assumed the presidency of the Senate he assumed the position of patron of the all party parliamentary rugby league group. Along with recent Speakers of the House of Representatives, particularly Speaker Martin, he quickly set about making sure that there was a national involvement, and that MHRs and senators from all parties from all states and territories of the Commonwealth were involved.

Part of the approach taken by rugby league in recent times in making the code more of a national code—along with soccer, Australian football and, to a lesser extent, rugby union—reflects the interest of people in this parliament. It ensures that teams compete in the competition not only from the east coast—Queensland, New South Wales and the ACT—but also from Perth and other parts of the country. The game has been taken consistently to Adelaide and Darwin, and the code has become truly national. That was the attitude that the President took during that time.

He is a very personable individual, as people have made clear. He has friendships right across the parliament. I know that stems from the late John Armstrong who, when he was first elected in 1975, said never to make the mistake of thinking that all one's friends were on one side of the political equation. Senator Sibraa came to this parliament with that view and it served him well. It has also meant that he is widely liked and regarded.

Mr President, in conclusion, I will miss your predecessor in a personal sense. I know you will take on the role of the presidency and serve this chamber extremely well. The Senate is the better for Kerry Sibraa having occupied not only a seat in the Senate but also the office of the presidency over the last six years or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate you, Mr President, on your new position. It is a position that many aspire to but very few actually make it. As a temporary chairman of committees, I look forward to working with you, as I did with the former President, Kerry Sibraa. I also agree with all the remarks made today about Kerry. As a temporary chairman of committees, it was certainly a pleasure to work with him. When one works with somebody it is a lot easier to understand what that person is about than it is when one works against that person. I was very proud to work with the former President and, as one of the delegates to the IPU, I was also proud to hear the glowing terms that were used to describe Kerry and to be aware of the high regard in which he is held by people from other countries around the world.

PARA.TAB: My former colleague Brian Roper Archer is a great and loyal Tasmanian who comes from that very well-known pioneering family in Tasmania; in fact, Brian's brother Dick Archer is a member of the Tasmanian Legislative Council. So politics runs in the family, as does agriculture.

It is obvious from what has been said here today by honourable senators from both sides that Brian's qualities are unquestionable. His hobbies and interests are many, but perhaps he is best known for his rural activities. I remember very well when I first came to this place advice that I was given by Brian—a lot of which I think I have taken. Around the traps in Tasmania, Brian was always a true friend to all of us. In particular, both he and his wife Dorothy would always make their house available if one were in the area. One always knew that there was a bed and a meal there—one really felt like one of the family, and I still feel that way.

Brian has many significant interests, including his Limousin cattle and his prolific sheep. I have seen photographs of Brian with his cattle and sheep at a beautiful farm he owned at Boat Harbour. I had interests similar to his in the Tasmanian Royal Agriculture Society. He visited many of the agricultural shows in Tasmania where we shared many happy times.

One saw Brian at his best on the campaign trail. I know that when one went to doorknock people in a town or village, nobody could beat him for speed. He would be up one side of the street and halfway down the other before one could go through two or three houses. If one set out on a day's campaigning, one had to make sure one was on time—he would keep one going all day. I enjoyed the few campaigns on which I worked with Brian because he always had a good sense of humour and always worked us very hard. It has been sad during recent times to lose to retirement both Brian Archer and Shirley Walters. They are two great Tasmanians and that state will really miss both of them.

Many anecdotes have been retailed in this debate about Brian's advice. I remember the first time I worked closely with him on the quotas for southern blue fin tuna, a topic that created a lot of interest in my area. I did not know what to do about it, so I contacted Brian and, within a day or so, I had all the information and was given the direction in which to go.

Surprisingly, I worked with Brian on only one or two committees in this place, one of which was the publications committee of which Senator McKiernan was chairman. It was one of the few committees where the meetings started on time and finished five minutes later. Brian was always on time and always offered the right advice. Brian did a great job of chairing the backbench primary industry committee, and his leadership made its work very worthwhile. We are all indebted to him for his leadership in that area. He has vacated to me his position on the federal rural committee and I hope I will participate in its deliberations as well as he has always done.

I pay tribute to Brian. I wish Brian and Dorothy the very best in retirement. I wish his family well now that they will have the opportunity to see a lot more of him. I know how much Brian loves his family, his garden and his roses. With those few words, I congratulate him on his great contribution not only to Tasmania but also to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I congratulate you on attaining the very high office of President of the Senate. I have great confidence that, as time goes on, you will measure up to what has been achieved by past presidents. Earlier today at question time you went through a baptism of fire.
—Don't you believe it.
—It was not a bad result for someone who had been in the chair for only five minutes. Therefore, Mr President, I also congratulate you on the way in which you handled your first question time.

PARA.TAB: I hope that the retirement of former Senator Archer will be a long and rewarding one and that he will enjoy his time with his family. Although I had no political association with Brian Archer, I knew him in this place and outside where I always found him to be a thorough gentleman—someone whom one would describe as a friend. Although I never knew him really closely, I wish him well in his retirement with his family.

I have known Kerry Sibraa for many years. In fact, I knew him prior to his coming here, although not as well as Senator Loosley or Senator Richardson knew him. The first time I met Kerry was in Brisbane where we had a state campaign. As Senator Loosley said, Kerry had a great knowledge of campaigning. Kerry visited Queensland to talk to a number of candidates about their campaign. At that time he carried with him an impressive pamphlet which featured a very young, fresh faced Kerry Sibraa. If I searched through my archives at home and went through all the pamphlets that I have kept over a number of years, I would probably find that pamphlet. Kerry spent some time discussing campaigns and methods with candidates. That resulted in his becoming a senator and later Senate President. Certainly the advice that he gave to those candidates in Queensland was of great help to them at that time.

When Kerry became President of the Senate, he had a very hard act to follow, namely, Doug McClelland, the previous President of this place. Doug had a great sense of humour and a fine turn of phrase. When we were all uptight about something, he could easily flatten the whole thing by a humorous turn of tongue that would calm things down. In my opinion Kerry has done as well as Doug, Senator Young and even the President before that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Laucke.

—Senator Laucke. In his own way, Kerry set a style that certainly showed his ability. He had the confidence of everyone in the chamber, not only members of the government but members of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Without wishing to reflect on you, Mr President, I believe Kerry will be sadly missed from this place. His appointment as Australian High Commissioner to Zimbabwe is one of the best appointments that could be made. Senator Teague will know as well as I that Kerry has taken a great interest in what is happening in Africa. I know that with his dedication and interest, Kerry's time as High Commissioner will reflect well on Australia. I am glad that Kerry has obtained that appointment. I only hope that at some time in the future I will be able to visit him as part of a delegation to Zimbabwe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to join with all the other speakers in congratulating you on your appointment to your very high office. I think the office of President of the Senate is the third highest in Australia, and in that sense it casts great responsibility on all its occupants. In Australia we have been blessed generally for very many years with excellent Presidents of the Senate. Senator Jones just mentioned some of them, and there have been many other notable ones as well. You follow a very illustrious line, and I know that all members of the Senate will wish you well in the huge task that faces you in the difficult times that lie ahead. It would be unreal to pretend that you will have an easy row to hoe over the next year or so. It will test your mettle and your skills in a wide variety of instances. I wish you well in that task.

PARA.TAB: Your immediate predecessor, Kerry Sibraa, was a President who had the universal respect of all members of this chamber. He was very competent and, as far as I was concerned, very fair. Looking at it as an outsider, I consider his treatment of my colleagues on both sides of the chamber was always very fair. He did his utmost to ensure fairness on all sides. He was a President of real integrity, and I join others in thanking him for that. I wish him all the best in his new diplomatic appointment.

I have known Kerry Sibraa since I came into the parliament in 1975 as a member of the House of Representatives. Like Kerry, I had a hiccup along the way, but his hiccup was a little less than mine. He was out of parliament for a while and then came back into the Senate. I was out for a longer time and I came from the House of Representatives to the Senate. During our lengthy association I have developed a feeling of warmth and friendship towards him, a feeling that is shared by all my colleagues. That is a great tribute to him.

I would like to pay particular respect to my retired Senate colleague, Brian Archer, who also came into the parliament with me in 1975. All those Liberals who were elected in the landslide in 1975 were known as oncers. There were 43 new coalition members who came into the parliament after the 1975 election, many of them on very skinny margins and from seats that had been held by the Labor Party for many years before. So we were called oncers. The oncers get together at an annual dinner. Some of us are still in the parliament. Very few oncers have had an unbroken line. I believe I am right in saying that with Brian Archer's departure the only two persons elected in 1975 on our side of politics who have had an unbroken period of parliamentary service are John Moore and Ray Braithwaite. Although 1975 is not that long ago, it shows what infinitesimal specks we are.

Brian Archer was a terrific senator and a great Australian. As Senator Calvert and others have said, he was a great Tasmanian. He represented his party so ably for so long, and if we look through the parliamentary handbook we can see the range of committee and other services that Brian provided to the parliament, and therefore to his constituents and to Australia. It is a very impressive record indeed.

He was a quiet achiever. He did not make a lot of waves. He was always very firm, always very principled and always very disciplined in what he said. Above all, one of the things that endeared him to so many of us on our side of politics was that he was always true to his basic Liberal principles. That is a great monument to him. He was universally liked and respected in all walks of life and from all sides of politics. He brought to this place a lot of wisdom and a lot of expertise, particularly in the areas of agriculture, rural industries and fisheries. He had a very broad depth of knowledge of agricultural and secondary industry.

I hope that we will not lose all of that in his retirement. I hope that he will find occasion to continue to benefit his nation through using that long accumulated expertise, wisdom and judgment. We will miss him here. I am sure that he is delighted with his decision, and I am sure that his wife Dorothy is even more delighted. I hope that Brian and Dorothy will, in this next phase of their lives, find many more years of happiness and fruitful activity ahead of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to associate myself with the remarks that have made about Senator Archer. His departure from this chamber came as a complete surprise to me. I hope that there will be an occasion when I can personally pass on to him my good wishes and my thanks for the friendship and wise counsel that he has given to me. He was a true gentleman; a man who was not, except when very severely provoked, a very fiery debater. He always spoke with substance and with good sense. He will be missed from this side of the chamber for those qualities, and certainly for the friendship that he showed to so many of us.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I would also like to make a comment on your role in the office that you have assumed. I join with my colleagues in extending to you my congratulations. I am one of those who believe that the offices of Speaker of the House of Representatives and President of the Senate are two of the great offices in this country. It is important to those of us who treasure the parliamentary system that the Presiding Officers set a standard. We all take responsibility for what occurs in this parliament, nonetheless my relatively short experience here has shown that the Presiding Officers do a great deal to set the tone for the conduct of this chamber. The authority that the Presiding Officers are able to wield is important in ensuring that parliament performs as it should perform. Television has given a particular eminence to your office. The TV cameras frequently focus on Presiding Officers each day that parliament sits, and in the to and fro of parliamentary debates their voices are often heard. In a fairly short period of time the Presiding Officers become public figures, and I think that is important.

I have a concern about the culture which surrounds this parliament. I believe that it is a culture which needs to be changed so that the Presiding Officers of this parliament are not only seen to be acting in an independent manner but are independent. That is a message with which not all my colleagues would agree. However, it is my belief that to the extent we increase the authority and standing of the office of President of the Senate we will also increase the authority and standing of this parliament.

I have no great complaint about the performance of the former President. I thought he was a little tough on me with a few of his rulings, but given the culture that surrounds this parliament and past practices, Kerry Sibraa was a good President, and I think each and every one of my colleagues would agree with me.

I certainly hope that you, Mr President, will further elevate the high office to which you have been elected. A few years ago—I would urge you, Mr President, to do the same if you have not done so already—I read a transcript of the conference that the Presiding Officers and clerks have every year. The transcripts are particularly interesting. I first started to read them when Mr Leo Mcleay was the Speaker in the other place—although his was an example which I do not think will be followed in the future. When reading of the experience of Presiding Officers from around Australia, it occurred to me what the potential of your office was.

Presiding Officers from the New South Wales Parliament have been prepared to make rulings on length of answers, and quite comfortably prepared to make rulings on relevance without any particular guidance. Time and time again we have heard from the other place how difficult it is for a Speaker to rule on matters of relevance. Indeed, the current Speaker seems to find it difficult. However, Presiding Officers around the country are ruling on relevance each and every parliamentary sitting day. Speaker Rozzoli in the New South Wales Parliament, as I understand it, is very comfortable about ruling on relevance. A former Labor Speaker from Tasmania, whose paper was given at one of these conferences, said that he was also very comfortable about ruling on such matters.

When Presiding Officers see themselves in an independent role, when they are able to rule fearlessly on such matters as relevance, they have passed two of the tests they need to pass in order to lift the standard of debate in this parliament, particular at question time. I realise, Mr President, that today was your first day in office but I was a little worried when you said that you found it difficult to rule on the relevance of an issue. I would urge you to look at what other Presiding Officers in this country are doing in that respect. I learned from a former clerk in the other place, a Mr Browning, that where standing orders are silent, the powers of a Presiding Officer are virtually unlimited. In that sense, standing orders are a restriction rather than guidance.

I hope that during your time in office you will help lift the standards of this parliament by the fearlessness with which you make your rulings, and by your willingness to stand up for the Senate when it is attacked. When the Senate was attacked by the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) I feel that the former President did not stand up for this chamber. I believe that that is another of the duties of a President of the Senate.

Mr President, I wish you well. I will certainly do my best to work with you. I hope that you will help establish something which I think is important: not only the independence of your office but also that your office is seen to be independent. A former Speaker from our party, Mr Snedden, decided that in order to buttress the independence of his office he would not attend party meetings, nor would he take part in tactical party discussions. I think that is a good precedent for a Presiding Officer to follow, and one which you may give thought to following.

I hope that the office of President of the Senate is one that will always be sought after. In the past it has been sought after for both good and bad reasons, but in the future I hope it will be sought after because it is one of the pre-eminent offices in this country and that it will be seen in that light. I believe that the office of the President of the Senate should be the highest office to which an individual in this parliament should seek to aspire. Once attained I have difficulty with the concept of an incumbent negotiating with the government for another job, particularly when it occurs over a period of time. Once that happens it places further pressure on the perception of the independence of the office. Mr President, I wish you well and I hope that in the months and years to come you will be seen to have added to the grandeur of what is already a very important office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I congratulate you on attaining the office of President and I wish you well in it. As time goes by, I hope we will work closely together. No doubt from time to time little ruckuses will occur.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Kemp has said, yours is a very high office. In assuming it you have undertaken to properly carry out its duties and functions, and that requires great sacrifice. You have to show a degree of independence which is not required in the hurly-burly of ordinary political life. I have no doubt that, in accepting the nomination, you have given that a lot of thought, that you will be able to demonstrate your independence and treat everyone here, no matter where they sit, with equality and fairness. I wish you well in your office and look forward to your period in the chair.

I would also like to express my appreciation to Kerry Sibraa and to wish him well in his retirement. I thank him for the assistance that he has given me and my colleagues in the nearly four years since I was elected to the Senate. Before I was actually sworn in we had two training days. The first session was a briefing—

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember the first day!

—I remember the first day, and the first night, and the next day—but not so much of the next day, as Senator Campbell reminds me. If I remember correctly, the first session was a briefing by the then President, Senator Sibraa, on the functions of the President and a general rundown on the way in which this place operated. I found that extremely useful and I have no doubt that under you, Mr President, that practice will continue. It certainly helped me and those others who attended that particular day.

PARA.TAB: The other person I wish to pay tribute to comes from a different perspective from you, Mr President. Brian Archer sat on the same side of this chamber as I do. After I was sworn in, Brian was one of the first senators to come to me and say, `There are a few things I think I can probably help you with'. He took me through a number of aspects. Some of those were of very close interest to me—rural matters and the wool industry in particular. As Senator Calvert and others have mentioned, Brian was then the chairman of our rural committee. At that particular time the reserve price in the wool market had collapsed. There was much heartburning among all members of parliament about how that was going to be addressed.

In relation to the wool debate I want to repeat, not verbatim but as I remember it, some advice that Brian Archer gave us that year. I think it is advice we could all heed with regard to the wool market; it applies to all market situations. He said, `Let the market work and it will gradually improve because confidence will return to all aspects of the industry'. Then he went on to say that it was very important in dealing with this particular problem to look at all aspects of the industry; from the production side, through transport to the final consumer.

Those were very wise words, from which we could all learn a lot, particularly when we see what is occurring now. He is absolutely right. The market is gradually improving. Confidence has returned to most, if not all, sectors of the industry. The price now, on a clean indicator basis, has moved up over 500c; and more wool is being moved from the stockpile.

The key to what he said related to the fact that we must let the market work. What happened in the wool industry, particularly in those later years from 1987 during which changes were made to the act and to the reserve price scheme, was that the market was interfered with and the producers were given the wrong signals. Through the process various people lost confidence in the whole industry.

I have no doubt that what Brian Archer said then is coming true. I wanted to place on the public record that advice, because sometimes we, and people in industry organisations and bureaucracies, tend to think we can do it better than the market can. The case that I make proves that in the final analysis, if we try to defy the market, it will catch up with us.

Brian Archer will be very sadly missed because of his straightforward thinking and the way he handled various issues. He has a great knowledge of fishing—which others have talked about—and the cattle industry. He has an interest in science and a whole host of things; and he addressed things in a very straightforward, sensible, often very simple way—I mean simple in the context that it could be understood. I hope that from time to time we will see him back here—or even catch up with him in Tasmania. I would like to put those comments on the record. I reiterate, Mr President, what I said at the start of my comments; that I wish you well in your position, and I look forward to working with you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I congratulate you on the high office to which this Senate has unanimously elected you. Perhaps the greatest praise I can give you, Mr President, is to say that I am confident that you will equal the way in which your predecessor, Senator Sibraa, performed his task. He did that with great dignity and, as has been said here again and again today, great fairness. I think he had the goodwill of everybody in the chamber. This was well illustrated by the fact that everybody wished him well in his task in Zimbabwe.

PARA.TAB: I remember when his predecessor received his appointment to London. Former Senator Chaney said that had he not been worthy of the task, members of the opposition might well have done something about it when they came into office; but that the then President had so well performed his task here that he was worthy of his position. I think the same can be said of Senator Sibraa. No doubt in some years to come we might be saying the same to you, Mr President. I endorse everything that has been said so far.

I also endorse the remarks that have been made about Senator Brian Archer. He was Secretary of the Taiwanese-Australian Association. He suggested that I become president—in my absence, may I say. I am indebted to him for that. In the short time we worked together, I found him to be a most gracious and generous person, a person who certainly did not promote himself as much as perhaps his ability entitled him to. I think the praise that has been coming from all parts of the chamber in reference to you, Senator Sibraa and Senator Archer has been very eloquent and very true; and leaves me with nothing to say—but I did want to make those remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join my colleagues in saying what a fine contribution Senator Brian Archer has made to this chamber. When I first came into the chamber and sat down to talk with Brian I found a kindred soul in matters of trade. He believed as I did that trade was a vital and driving force in the affairs of state. But he took it even further. He was always concerned with the small trade associations and their problems; and with representing them and understanding their industries. I found in him a wealth of knowledge.

PARA.TAB: I know that Brian in his retirement will spend a lot of his time with various members of his family who are of the utmost importance to him in the ordering of his priorities of life. I can only say that Brian has left this chamber as a distinguished senator; and I wish him great happiness in his retirement from this place.

I also want to congratulate you, Mr President, on your new elevation to office. I listened with great interest to the remarks of my colleague Senator Kemp and share his sentiments about caring for the institutions of our parliament. I know that when somebody takes on one of the great offices of the parliament the responsibility and onerous nature of the task can sometimes be daunting. Political and other pressures are brought to bear, but at the end of the day the importance and integrity of the office will—I know, through having known you in this chamber, Mr President—be important to you, too.

Concerning Senator Sibraa, I can only say that as I am going to another place, I think I will remember him and his rulings as being fair and benign in the extreme compared with what I am likely to hear in the other place. In all seriousness, I think Senator Sibraa tried, as much as he could within the constraints of the position of President, which still has a political connotation because of the way in which the holder of that position is appointed or elected, to be fair to all parties within this chamber and believed in the importance of the office.

He goes forth as an ambassador into a part of the world of which he has knowledge and believes to be important, and I wish him well. I wish him well from the point of view that he will be representing Australia. I always want officers who go from these shores to represent this greatest nation in the world—the best country in the world—to put their best foot forward. My remarks are very short but they are nonetheless very much firmly held views.

Brian Archer I will miss. Senator Sibraa I wish God speed and a successful ambassadorial position. To you, Mr President, I trust your position will be fulfilling for the institution and for you, despite the fact that I will not be here perhaps to see it for very much longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, really there is nothing left to be said about the three persons who are the subject of our good wishes today. So I will of necessity be brief. I simply want to place on record my appreciation for the advice and assistance given to me by Brian Archer in my 3 1/2 years in this place. I wish him and his wife well in their new life outside of parliament.

PARA.TAB: In relation to Senator Sibraa, I am not particularly proud of the fact that I was perhaps the cause of his losing his temper the last time—perhaps the only time since I have been in parliament. But I did want to say to Senator Sibraa that I certainly have no hard feelings. In fact, I wish him all the very best in his new role, which I am sure he will discharge with dignity and competence in the same manner as he exhibited those qualities during his presidency of this Senate.

I believe that Senator Sibraa genuinely tried to be fair. He had difficulties, which I appreciate, in this political business. As a member of the New South Wales Right it was always very difficult for him to ignore the directions which I know he often received from his mates. But I thought Senator Sibraa was at times perhaps a little too much focused on me. I cannot think why; perhaps I did deserve it.

But all I ask of presidents is that they be consistent in their rulings and deal with interjections from both sides in the same way. Mr President, I am sure if you conduct yourself in the same manner as Senator Sibraa did then we on this side will have not much to complain about. I wish Kerry Sibraa all the best. I do thank him genuinely and sincerely for the courtesy and advice that he gave to me during my time in the parliament.

To you, Mr President, I join with my colleagues in congratulating you on emerging through the Labor Party election process to achieve this very high honour of being elected as President of this very fine part of the Australian parliamentary institution.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Mr President, I congratulate you on being elected President. Over the last three years you and I have shared many meetings, most of which you have chaired. You have always had two principal distinctions: firstly, you have chaired the meetings very competently, with a sound knowledge of standing orders; and, secondly, you have displayed a very even temper. At times you have been under great pressure, which we know can exist within the forums of the party. So I am sure you will do a very good job as President. I congratulate you on your election.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I wish Senator Sibraa well in his new position in Africa. My first meeting with Kerry was during an induction week when he provided me, along with other new senators, with very valuable information. I have to disagree with Senator Kernot—I will miss the more sport oriented focus that he gave to the position. I enjoyed some of our evenings together. Indeed, I enjoyed the touch football matches we participated in, although I was generally playing against the New South Wales team that Senator Sibraa was proud to be a part of.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is also a Presiding Officer's trophy for tennis, which will continue.
—Good. He has had a very distinguished record over the last 30 years, both in the Labor Party and also here in the Senate. His is a very worthy appointment to the position that he has attained.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, I want to make special mention of Senator Archer because I come from the same part of the state as he does. I got to know Senator Archer I think reasonably well over the 3 1/2 in which I have been in this place as a senator from Tasmania. I have come to appreciate his knowledge of primary industry matters and fisheries, particularly since my appointment as a parliamentary secretary.

I do not think fisheries at times has had the attention it deserves. It is a major industry. I think Senator Boswell pointed out—and this is not commonly known—that it is the fourth largest primary export earner for this country. Senator Archer always made a very active and informed contribution in that area. I believe no-one else had his specialised knowledge and that will be missed. That specialist knowledge acquired in fisheries was always exercised in a balanced political way. I pay him tribute for that and I wish him well in his retirement.

I have from time to time had dealings with him in respect of the potato industry, the dairy industry and fisheries on the north-west coast of Tasmania. The body of experience and knowledge that he brought to the Senate will not only be missed by the opposition but also will be missed in terms of the contribution he made to the Senate committees and to the Senate as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my unhappy duty to inform the Senate of the untimely death on 8 January this year of Mr Rob Jones, a former parliamentary liaison officer to the Senate who was well known to many honourable senators. On behalf of all senators, I extend the Senate's sympathy to his family in their bereavement. I understand that any senators who wish to speak will do so on the adjournment.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned parents and friends of Stewarts Day Care Centre draws to the attention of the Senate that the Federal Government is seeking to link accreditation to eligibility for Child-care Assistance and in the opinion of your petitioners this link will only lead to higher fees for parents and no guarantee for improvement in quality of care for children. We know that quality care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. Please help us to help our children.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to reject accreditation being linked to Childcare Assistance.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows: That the Federal Government is seeking to link accreditation to eligibility for Child-care Assistance and in the opinion of your petitioners this link will only lead to higher fees for parents and no guarantee for improvement in quality of care for children. We know that quality care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. Please help us to help our children.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to reject accreditation being linked to Childcare Assistance.

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: VIP Aircraft
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our strongest opposition to the Prime Minister's intentions of purchasing new VIP aircraft, particularly given that the Prime Minister is responsible for the record unemployment and worst recession in sixty years, and calls on the Prime Minister to abandon his plans to purchase any new aircraft until Australia's economy picks up and unemployment falls dramatically.
Further, that the Senate recognises the Prime Minister's previous misuse of such aircraft, in particular, his using one to fly from Canberra to Melbourne and back to watch a football game.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the Senate to oppose any plan by the Prime Minister to purchase any new VIP aircraft.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with their existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history and heritage,
And that they condemn unwarranted attacks on their historic Australian Flag, whenever or wherever made by any Australian citizens.

So therefore do we call upon the Senate to ensure that the Australian National Flag, as publicly acclaimed in 1901 and confirmed under the Flags Act (1953), is not changed, replaced or diminished at any time, or in any manner whatsoever, without such a proposal being first voted upon and approved by a majority of Australian citizens in a national referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
