The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Mr President has received a letter from Senator Vanstone proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:
The disastrous impact on low income earners of Labor's broken election promises culminating today in yet another petrol tax increase.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to discuss this matter today, the day when the petrol tax price rises come into effect—the tax price rises that, according to Labor, we were never going to have. As Labor members opposite will recall, during March last year many of them went scurrying around the country and around every marginal electorate they could get to saying, `We are not going to increase taxes. Don't vote for a Hewson Liberal government because if you vote for a Hewson Liberal government taxes will go up and things will cost you more'. What do we find straight after the election—one long litany and saga of broken promises. This is yet another one which has come to fruition today. This broken promise is one of particular importance because the last election was primarily fought on the issue of broadening the tax base. The great scare campaign run by Labor was, `If you broaden the tax base, everything will go up; this will hit low income earners more than anyone else'. That was the argument run by Labor against the Liberal and National parties at the last election.
—It's true.

—I note that Senator Sherry says that it is true. He accepts then that broadening the tax base—that is the proposition he is putting—can negatively impact on low income earners. What he is not saying to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, is that the package the coalition was looking at took off a lot of taxes as well. Yet the proposal that this government puts forward, and has in fact implemented, is simply to increase tax without taking off any other taxes. That is the difference. The lie and the deceit of Labor's campaign were to say that a GST would put everything up without mentioning the decreases that were coming about because of taxes that we were taking off. That was the great deceit that people opposite either participated in or were so intellectually bereft of any political skills that they got sucked into not knowing what was happening, not knowing what their party was campaigning and not seeing the deceit that was being foisted upon the Australian electorate.

PARA.TAB: That was a deceitful campaign in which Labor said, `Don't vote for these people; they are going to put up taxes', without mentioning that we were bringing other taxes down. The Labor Party went further than that and said, `Vote for us; we are not going to put them up'. And here it is putting up taxes. This will have a disastrous impact on low income earners. The simple reason is that, firstly, low income earners spend a greater proportion of their income on petrol than do high income earners. It necessarily follows from that fact that this is going to impact on low income earners—the battlers, the people who Labor says it is meant to represent, yet for 10 years has failed to do so.

There is another practical reason why this will impact more heavily on low income earners than on middle and high income earners. Low income earners necessarily have older cars and necessarily, therefore, have the bulk of cars that cannot take unleaded petrol. This price rise is not just a straight price rise; it is a price rise to increase the incentive, according to Labor, to people to buy unleaded petrol—that is, unleaded petrol is going up by more. That means that low income earners, who necessarily have the cars that cannot take unleaded petrol, will be the ones who have to pay more.

It is all very well for Mrs Kelly to run around the country saying, `This is an environmental move; this is going to encourage people to use unleaded petrol'. That may be the case for people who have the opportunity—for people who obviously now have cars that use unleaded petrol, the high income earners, the people who have bought new cars. For them it is a bit of a windfall to be paying less, in a proportional sense, than people who buy leaded petrol. But the low income earners, those who do not have cars that take unleaded petrol or that cannot take unleaded petrol—and there are plenty of cars in that category—have to pay more. As yet Labor has offered no satisfactory explanation for this other than that lead in the environment is causing difficulty with health. We do not dispute that; of course that is true. But to pretend that this slight differential in price is going to make a difference to purchasing patterns when, in order to actually effect that difference, somebody has to go and buy a different sort of car, is simply ludicrous. The government has no understanding of how a market works.

Obviously if people have the choice, they may well make the change to use the cheaper petrol. But the case that we are arguing is for the people that do not have the choice—the millions who do not have a job and who are relying on unemployment benefits and who cannot simply change to another car. What about those people who have a low income job and cannot, at this point, change to another sort of car?

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the dinner break I was making the point that the coalition believes it is important to discuss today the absolutely disastrous impact on low income earners of Labor's broken election promises which culminate today in yet another petrol tax increase. I made the point that basically Labor deceived the electorate at the last election. It went around saying, `Don't vote for the coalition people; they will give you a GST, an increase in tax', without mentioning the decreases in tax that my party was proposing at the same time. It also marched around the country saying, `Look, we are not going to put up taxes; vote for us', yet here is another example of yet another broken promise from a government with a litany of them.

PARA.TAB: This is just another tax increase, and we say it will affect low income earners the most. Unlike the Fightback package, this measure provides no compensation for low income earners. The point was made that low income earners, as opposed to high income earners, will be doubly affected by this increase. Firstly, lower income earners spend a larger proportion of their income on petrol—that is obvious; and, secondly, lower income earners are least likely to have a new car that can take unleaded petrol. So it follows that they are the most likely people to be driving vehicles that take only leaded petrol and therefore they will have to pay much more for their petrol.

Labor has tried to say, `Look, this is an environmental move; it will discourage people from driving cars that won't take unleaded petrol'. The disincentive means nothing to those who cannot afford to make the choice. It is nothing more than another tax and another penalty. Those who can afford to make the choice of whether to buy a new car—and I think all new cars take unleaded petrol—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to.

—Okay. High income earners now buy cars that take unleaded petrol, so the only people to be affected by this increase are middle income earners who perhaps have a chance to swap over. The argument is that this is a real incentive for middle income earners, but we say that 2c a litre is perhaps not a big enough incentive. We are not the only ones to say that; plenty of other people say that as well. We particularly say that low income earners do not have the choice as they do not have the resources to change over. We want to know what the government says in this regard.

PARA.TAB: This not only affects low income earners, but it particularly affects low income earners in rural areas. As my colleague Senator Tierney pointed out, the Service Station Association of New South Wales said yesterday that retail prices in some parts of Sydney are obviously much lower than those in rural areas and that price discounting in the metropolitan area will soften the blow for metropolitan residents of Australia.

But no such discounting is happening in rural Australia, which is currently desperately affected. Thousands and thousands of farmers are not enjoying the incomes they used to enjoy. They are very much in what we might call the low income category with no chance to get the benefit of discounting. There are lots of old cars out in the country. We do not see brand spanking new cars purchased in rural Australia. Additionally, these people will not have the opportunity to benefit from price discounting as perhaps metropolitan people will.

When this price rise was announced, Mr Bruce Lunn, secretary-general of the Australian Automobile Association, also warned that people who drove cars that took only leaded petrol would obviously pay more. That is the point we are making. It affects the people who cannot afford to make the change. It is all very well for those people who can afford to make the change. That is fine. But what the government does not seem to understand is that thousands and thousands of people—low income earners, young people—cannot afford to make that choice. How many young people have a brand spanking new car that takes unleaded petrol as their first car? There are not many at all. They will be affected by this 2c a litre increase.

Then there is the effect on the business community. We cannot afford to say, `So what, that is the business community—it can afford it'. It does not afford it; it passes on the increase, and honourable senators opposite and I, as consumers, will pay for that through every product we purchase. Every business that uses petrol will pass on that increase; the price will be marked up. As a product goes through the production chain there is a cascading effect. So in the end the price of a lot of goods and services will go up because petrol prices go up.

Yesterday John Anderson, one of my colleagues from the National Party of Australia, indicated that he thought this would have a devastating effect. He actually calculated that it would cost Australia's commodity based export industries at least $65 million a year. It is all very well to laugh these things off and say, `Oh well, it is only 2c a litre', but lots of litres of petrol are used. The price keeps adding up all the time.

The Road Transport Forum said that the government had conducted a very slick PR campaign. It does not believe that the price increase in leaded fuel will deter people from using leaded petrol at all. It went on to say that in fact people did not seem to know that diesel fuel costs would also rise.

The Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce executive director, Mr Bob Davison, made the point that, according to the information he had, a 1c or 2c differential would not make much difference. He said there would have to be something like a 10c price gap to make a difference in any event.

I say that this measure will affect low income earners much more than anyone else as they do not have the opportunity or the money to make the change to a car which uses unleaded petrol. It is a relative benefit to high income earners who drive new cars which use unleaded petrol, but it is only a relative benefit because they also are paying more. It will allegedly make a difference to middle income earners. However, the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce tells us that it will not make a difference anyway, that this is just some form of dressing allegedly to help the environment, when in reality it is only a revenue raising matter. It will not make that much of a substantive difference.

Another of my colleagues, the shadow Treasurer, Alexander Downer, repeated what every Australian knows—that the petrol bowser is just a substation of the Australian Taxation Office. This is a revenue raising measure described as being something to help the environment. In some small way it may make a contribution, but only in a very small way. In any event it will have a disastrous impact on low income earners.

I notice that Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, says that the increase is calculated to be 40c a week. I do not know what sort of car Mrs Kelly drives, how far she drives or how many litres of petrol her car takes. No doubt, as she lives in Canberra, she probably does not drive very far at all. She is a minister, so I wonder how long it is since she has driven her own car. Plenty of cars take 60 litres. If we calculate 2c a litre, then filling up a car just once each week—plenty of people do not live in close-knit suburban Canberra and need to fill their cars more than once a week—will cost $1.20 a week. Therefore this will cost Australians at least $50, probably something closer to $55 a year. Low income earners in particular will be devastated by this change.

I will not take much longer. I understand the government wants an agreement on one speaker a side and we do not want to take up any more time than we absolutely have to. When I look across the chamber I see the specious and somewhat sickening smiles of people who openly stand up in this place and say, `You people are political ignorants; you don't know how to win an election'. What revolts me about that is that those people are basically smirking and saying, `The way to win an election is for a major party to lie to the Australian people, to deceive the Australian people as to the course of action it will take'.

Those opposite sit over there and are actually proud of that. They are proud that they have deceived Australians. They think it is smart because they have another term of government and they can do what they like in that term of government, including putting up taxes. Those people opposite either participated knowingly in that deceit or are so stupid that they could not see what was happening. They were so politically unaware as to what was being said that they did not see the deceit that their leaders were foisting on the Australian public. I think that is what is particularly galling.
Last, but not least, I think it is interesting to note that during the election a letter that Gordon Bilney—who is from my state—wrote to his constituents said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet in the end, elections are about more than `policies and promises'. For, too often, those `policies and promises' have a way of changing, after a government gets in. Maybe you've noticed.

Since the election Mr Bilney has had plenty of opportunity to notice how much policies and promises change because this government has the worst record for broken promises. This increase in petrol tax, this broadening of the tax base, is just another example. By doing this, it is doing the things that it said in the election were so dreadful—that is, broadening the tax base and putting a greater burden on low income earners. Now, all of a sudden, it is okay. I think it stinks, and the government deserves to be condemned, especially for what it does to low income earners, particularly low income earners in rural Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address two essential elements in this debate. I may get time to deal with some other matters but, firstly, I want to deal with the allegation that is continually made by the opposition that we gave a commitment not to increase taxes at the last election. We did not give that commitment, and I will go into that in some detail in a moment. Secondly, I intend to deal with some of the technical issues associated with the phasing out of leaded petrol which, unfortunately, were not mentioned by Senator Vanstone and certainly are not mentioned very much in this debate at all. I wish to deal with the problems that oil refineries have in moving from producing leaded petrol to unleaded petrol. I may get time to deal with some other issues.
—Why don't you talk about low income earners—that is the substance of the debate?

—I may get time to deal with that as well, but the technical problem with the phasing out of leaded petrol by oil refineries is critical and central to the problem we face. It is one of the critical reasons why we have to have a differential in petrol pricing, but I will get to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: I thought that, after Christmas and New Year, Senator Vanstone and those opposite might have switched their focus a little more from the well-worn record that the opposition was robbed at the last election—`We were robbed'; we heard that last year—to what their policies will be to try to win the next election and perhaps deal with the leadership disharmony. But they continue to say, `We were robbed', and the crocodile tears continue to flow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say we were robbed; I said you were deceitful.
—In the election campaign, we pointed out to the Australian people the consequences of a GST. Those opposite got it wrong. They should not blame us; they should blame themselves.
—What about no new taxes?

—I have a copy of what the then Treasurer said to the Australian people in the election. The government said that over the last decade Commonwealth taxation had averaged approximately 24 per cent of gross domestic product, that under a progressive taxation system the average tax rate rises as incomes rise and that, in a recession as people's incomes are reduced, the average tax rate falls. There is a cyclical effect on government revenues from taxes on consumer durables. I include tax from petrol in that. The government's commitment not to increase the overall taxation burden did not mean it would hold tax revenues at their recession-induced lows. It did not mean that. Over the four years of the government's medium-term fiscal strategy, the Commonwealth's total taxation revenues will remain below 24 per cent of gross domestic product. I can remember not just the then Treasurer's commitment on this issue but that of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that we would not be increasing the total level of taxation revenues in this country above 24 per cent of gross domestic product.
—You are deliberately deceiving.

—It was quite simply explained in the election. Those opposite are the ones who have been engaged in a deceptive argument to try to reconcile the fact that they lost the last election. That is their problem. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) explained very clearly during question time today that the government has redistributed taxation revenue, that we have honoured our commitment about the tax cuts and that the real level of government revenue from petrol taxes is in fact lower today than it was 10 years ago.
—You are not wimping out, are you?

—I suggest to Senator Vanstone that she go back and check what was said in the election rather than continue to perpetuate her interpretation of it. The second issue I want to deal with is the technical issue of the conversion of refineries from leaded petrol to unleaded petrol.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that Senator Vanstone listen to this because she put forward the notion. She agreed with the need to reduce lead in the atmosphere, and she agreed with the notion of reducing lead in petrol. I think everyone in this chamber agrees with that premise. If we agree with that premise, we then have to look at the practical difficulties of moving from refineries that refine leaded petrol to refineries that refine and produce unleaded petrol.

PARA.TAB: The oil refineries approached the government. They said publicly at the round table discussion that was convened by Ros Kelly that they needed a smooth phase-out period, that they needed a predictable phase-out period, because they needed to make investments in the range of $300 million to $500 million to update their oil refineries to cope with producing unleaded petrol. They argued for that very strongly. They wanted a smooth phase-out period. They argued that it is a matter of fact that, because of the recession—I am sure the opposition will argue and make comments about why we have a recession—the conversion of automobiles from leaded to unleaded was occurring too slowly and that, because of that, there were two options. They would be involved in $300 million to $500 million of investment that they should not otherwise incur or, alternatively, we would have to start importing petroleum products that contained no lead at a cost of $200 million or $300 million a year.

It was because of that technical reason that the government had to look at ways to ensure that the anticipated time frame for phasing out cars using leaded petrol to unleaded petrol had to be maintained. There is really only one way to do that: create a financial incentive for the users of leaded vehicles to move to unleaded vehicles and to look at ways of pre-1986 vehicles using unleaded petrol. We had to maintain that timetable.

The experience overseas has shown that we can encourage this conversion rate in a fairly predictable way by having a price differential on petrol. That is the reason why we have adopted this policy—a policy that we all agree with. We all agree that it is desirable, and we all agreed some years ago to phase lead out of petrol because of the well-known health risks. The problem is that it has not been occurring quickly enough.

This technical issue that was advanced by the oil industry is unfortunately not an issue that I have seen debated very much in the media or, indeed, by those opposite. It is a very important issue; it is a very critical issue. One interesting fact is that the usage of petroleum products is about 55 per cent leaded and 45 per cent unleaded. As the years go by, the proportion of leaded product used will decline quite dramatically. The interesting thing is that, if consumers were paying the real cost of producing leaded petrol, they would in fact be paying much more than the differential that is proposed by the government. I do not have the figures in front of me, but the differential would in fact become 10c to 15c to 20c because, as time goes on and the amount of leaded petrol produced by refineries becomes less and less, it becomes much more expensive to produce. So we are entering a period where, if there was not a cross-subsidy of leaded petroleum users, the costs of leaded petrol in fact will skyrocket beyond much more than the government is proposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Loosley quite rightly interjects. If the opposition agrees with the removal of lead from petrol, that oil refineries should not be required to spend another $300 million to $500 million in extra investment, and that we should not be importing petrol products that contain lead, what is its policy? Unfortunately, the opposition does not have one. It has pursued a continual negative approach since the election. The 1993-94 budget has passed through both houses of parliament, despite the opposition's useless efforts to undermine the government's strategy to repair the budget balance over the last four years. The opposition is incapable of putting anything forward in a positive way. This government, more than any other, has adopted policies to assist low income earners and to ensure sustainable economic growth. The opposition chooses to ignore these measures in this debate.

PARA.TAB: For example, we have enhanced health and child care arrangements and increased support for the unemployed. We made a number of positive measures in the last budget. This motion is a desperate attempt by a desperate opposition, led by a very desperate opposition leader who will not be here much longer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—Senator, do not `ha, ha'. We know what is going on. We can see it everywhere in the corridors of this place. Those opposite are gathered in little conclaves discussing the future of John Hewson.
—What are the Western Australians doing?

—Exactly. What is the future of the Western Australian Liberals and their support of John Hewson? That is another issue, and I will not digress. But we have a desperate opposition with no policies. What positive policies have come from the opposition since the election? None. In fact, those opposite boast about the fact that they do not need policies. They certainly will not get positive policies under the current Leader of the Opposition. It will be interesting to see whether they try in his place a well-known senator who is shortly to depart this place.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the increases in excise on leaded petrol will promote not just the health of Australian citizens but will also promote greater fuel conservation. Government policies are also aimed at encouraging the use of unleaded petrol by having that higher excise on leaded petrol. The excise differential between leaded and unleaded petrol is a response to the serious community health issue—the problem of leaded petrol—that we are all agreed upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we don't agree on is whether you are being deceitful.

—We are not deceitful, as I have already explained. There are literally hundreds of thousands of Australians, particularly young people, who are at risk of suffering brain damage—I know that those opposite have some problems in this area as well—through high levels of lead in their blood. There is no doubt about this. There is clear medical evidence on the issue. Lead emissions from motor vehicles contribute 90 per cent of the airborne lead in Australian cities.

PARA.TAB: We have had an argument from the opposition today, as well as on previous occasions, that it is a problem in the cities but not in the country; and that the government is discriminating against country people. But how can we have a differential in pricing between the cities and the country because if those opposite propose that seriously then there has to be a border where there is a different charge on one side for city dwellers and a different charge for rural dwellers on the other side—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested to see whether those opposite can advance that as a practical government policy because there would be people going across the dividing line to buy petrol at a cheaper rate. It is just a ridiculous, unrealistic proposition.
—Are they going back to Fightback?

—Even more absurd than Fightback, Senator Loosley, is the fact that we could have, as a deliberate government policy, a differential in pricing. Certainly there will be a market rate that is different around Australia. I certainly know about that in Tasmania. If honourable senators think petrol is expensive on the mainland then they should come to Tasmania and have a look at the price: it is the most expensive petrol in Australia. But the government cannot have a different policy on pricing between country and city dwellers. It cannot do that constitutionally, let alone practically.

PARA.TAB: The evidence from overseas suggests that a price differential will speed up the phase out of leaded petrol considerably. That is the basis of the government's policy. The cost of this measure is a small price to pay for the welfare of Australians. Taxes are not imposed simply to raise revenue. There are other reasons for having taxation, aside from the obvious need to raise government revenue. There are tax measures that can be introduced that have a positive environmental effect and positive health considerations. This is one of those issues where the health consideration outweighs other considerations. There is the need to ensure that we have a consistent phase out of leaded petrol because of the investment requests and considerations of the oil companies. I do not always subscribe to the requests of the oil companies, but I do not want to see the oil companies having to be involved in unnecessarily changing over their machinery used in oil production at a cost of $300 million to $500 million. It would be an absurd policy to impose on the oil refineries.

They are my contributions to this debate. The motion should be rejected. It is based on this continual false assertion that we gave an undertaking that there would be no increase in taxes at the last election. We did not give that undertaking. The assertion is based on the false assumption that all taxation is purely a matter of raising government revenue; that is not the case here. It is based on sound, medical and health grounds which we all agree on, except that the opposition, as usual, does not have a positive suggestion but purely a negative approach. They say that they agree that we have to get rid of lead from petrol. I pose the question through you, Mr Deputy President: how would those opposite go about it? They have no practical alternative or option. That is why they deserve to be in opposition, and that is why they will stay there.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the matter of public importance tonight, I want to deal with three issues: firstly, the environmental aspects of this price difference between leaded and unleaded petrol; secondly, to look at the reasons which lie behind today's petrol price increase and to ask of both the government and the opposition what contribution they have made to that increase; and, thirdly, to suggest ways in which the impact—I do want Senator Sherry to hear this—on low income earners may be overcome particularly in relation to that differential between city and country drivers. The case for a price differential, as a number of honourable senators have mentioned, favouring unleaded petrol is beyond doubt on public health grounds. Study after study has attested to the fact that lead emissions from petrol are directly related to neurological problems and to lowered IQ in children.

PARA.TAB: In Australia, children living in the inner city areas are most at risk. Children growing up in Sydney have been the worst affected because of the high population densities in the inner city of Sydney and because the lead limit in Sydney is higher than the lead limit in Melbourne, the other city of comparable size. Last year RMIT published a study into lead exposure in Australia. It said that it was easy to be complacent about lead exposure when it was thought that the adverse health effects were associated with a blood level of 25 micrograms per decilitre of blood or higher. If we take that measure, only about 2 per cent of Australian children have levels that high. However, the report goes on to say that the situation is now different.

Last year the National Health and Medical Research Council adopted a specific goal, to achieve for all Australians a blood level of below 10 micrograms per decilitre. The National Health and Medical Research Council stated that there is a particular urgency in reaching this level in children aged 1 to 4 years because of the adverse effects of lead exposure on intellectual development.

The RMIT report found that a staggering 44 per cent of Australian children aged between nought and four years have blood lead levels above 10 micrograms. This is appalling. Nearly half of Australian children under the age of four years have blood lead levels above the NHMRC goal. The report also said that adverse health effects occur at very low levels, so that even a level of 10 micrograms may not be safe. As the lowering of lead in petrol has been strongly linked overseas to a reduction in blood lead levels, the report called for a lowering of the lead limit in petrol to 0.15 grams per litre. For some time many European countries have set a limit of 0.15 grams per litre of lead.

The report also called for more accurate costing on lowering the lead limit to 0.026 grams per litre. This is the lead limit in petrol in the United States where it was adopted as far back as 1986. The report said that even if the costs of achieving this United States lead level are high in Australia, it may be considered justifiable on social justice or human rights grounds. After all, we are talking about the right of 44 per cent of Australian children living now to develop their full human and intellectual potential.

The Australian Democrats have pushed hard for the US standard to be adopted in Australia. However, last year the government negotiated for a lead limit of only 0.2 grams per litre. This still leaves many children at risk. Unfortunately, the introduction of a price differential was very badly handled by the government. What should have been a positive public health measure ended up as, and being seen as, a revenue grab by the government.

Today, a price differential of 1c per litre has been introduced. Every study indicates, and the industry knows, that this is simply not enough to encourage a switch by consumers to unleaded petrol. The differential should have been more distinct and should have been introduced in one go in order to cause the maximum effect on consumer behaviour. The incremental nature of the price rise means that consumers are less likely to notice the rise and therefore less likely to look for alternatives.

A well-funded and effective community education campaign will be needed to ensure that people make the necessary move to unleaded petrol, and thereby lower the risk of lead poisoning to Australia's young children. In the past few days the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, has launched such a campaign.

Before I leave my concern with environmental health, I also point out that the Australian Democrats were able to negotiate with the government late last year for a lead abatement package, a subsidy for the production of ethanol, so that an ethanol and petroleum mix—known popularly as gasohol—could be introduced so that people using leaded petrol could switch to unleaded petrol and thus achieve the goal that we all have.

At the moment Australia is facing a very attractive proposition in the record wheat harvest. However, the problem is what to do with our wheat, particularly that which we cannot sell. I compliment those who run the refinery at Manildra which has been able to increase production and use some of that wheat harvest to produce ethanol, which is non-pollutant and avoids the use of leaded petrol. That also creates jobs in value adding to primary industry, which is an objective of all of us.

I want now to address the reasons for the impact of today's petrol price increase. One central factor should not be forgotten. The petrol tax increase would not have been necessary if the Liberal-National Party coalition had not supported the government in introducing cuts in income tax. There is no doubt that the petrol tax rises were introduced because of the fiscal necessity to pay for the income tax cuts. The coalition must bear its share of the blame for increased petrol prices currently being borne by all Australians, including low income earners and particularly those in country areas.

The Industry Commission is currently conducting an inquiry on petrol pricing mechanisms and is due to report in July this year. The Democrats will certainly be pushing for a significant reduction in this unfair burden on rural people. Having said this, however, let us not forget the role of the government in foisting this tax on low income earners. Combining this with the government's record on further reducing the adequacy of our social welfare safety net, it seems that the Australian Labor Party has little interest in assisting those at the bottom of the heap.

We need to address the very real and quite unfair differences in petrol prices between the country and the city. This would tie in with another need to encourage development in regional areas and reduce the infrastructure burden in the capital cities.

I suggest three ways of looking at this differential: first, improved subsidising of petrol freight costs; secondly, compensation of costs through tax and the social security system; and, thirdly, direct petrol pricing matters.

Let me address the petroleum product freight subsidisation scheme which has been around in a number of forms since 1965. It subsidises the freight cost of petrol to remote areas. Currently it only subsidises those freight costs which are greater than 13.5c per litre, which helps virtually no-one. The PSA figures reveal that about 200 locations in Australia attract the subsidy. It currently costs the government some $3 million a year. At one stage in 1981-82 this differential was only 0.44c per litre and the cost that year was $147.5 million. If 5c were lopped off the differential, paralleling the 5c per litre unleaded petrol excise increase, a rough estimate is that the cost to the budget would be in the order of $20 million to $25 million.

A second method is an increase in the zone rebate for income tax and remote area allowance of DSS recipients. Zone rebates are currently $57, $338 and $1,173, depending on the degree of remoteness, plus a greater amount for other rebates, such as dependent spouse, et cetera. These amounts were increased by 25 per cent in the 1992-93 budget. In 1990-91, 364,000 taxpayers were eligible for one of these rebates.

Remote area allowance uses the same zones, with the exception that the people in zone B are not eligible, and is $15 each a fortnight for couples or $17.50 for individuals, with an extra $7 per child. Currently 44,000 people are in receipt of this. Very roughly, the areas covered are most of Western Australia and South Australia; all of the Northern Territory; parts of Queensland north of Mackay and west of Emerald; only the far west of New South Wales and Tasmania; and none of Victoria or the ACT. Zone B people are not eligible for remote area allowance.

Most of the people in New South Wales and Queensland, except for Cloncurry-Mt Isa and north of Mossman, would not be eligible for the remote area allowance. Rough costings provided by the library indicate that each 10 per cent increase in the base zone rebates would cost around $10 million. Increasing the remote area allowance by $1 a fortnight would cost $1 million to $2 million.

The third area in which we would see some possibility is in the pricing mechanisms and controls. With the Industry Commission inquiry under way it might be difficult to get any agreement to change anything before its report comes down. However, we should still put forward our position. I refer to the area of wholesale petrol prices. There are varying views about the role that current wholesale pricing mechanisms have in keeping rural petrol costs too high and city prices too low. Under the Trade Practices Act oil companies cannot set retail prices at service stations. However, the area pricing mechanism used at refineries now sets different wholesale prices for dealers, depending upon the region in which they operate.

Lately, we have received requests for rural organisations to support terminal gate pricing. Basically, this would mean a universal price for each customer buying from a specific terminal. Some people suggest that this should be extended to inland storage depots rather than simply coastal refineries. The oil companies do not like terminal gate pricing, and they say it would not be possible to maintain the integrity of the price. I am afraid that the same could be said about the current system. Surely no-one would want to say that the integrity of the price is being maintained at the current time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to support my colleague Senator Vanstone in this matter of public importance. I will be followed by my Victorian colleague Senator Troeth. The matter of public importance reads:

PARA.TAB: The disastrous impact on low income earners of Labor's broken election promises culminating today in yet another petrol tax increase.

SPEECH.PARA: We bring this forward because today leaded petrol will rise by 1c a litre, unleaded petrol by 2c a litre and diesel oil by 1c a litre. That may well sound like a small increase, but in fact it is one of three increases that will occur between August 1993 and August 1994.

PARA.TAB: I was pleased to hear parts of Senator Woodley's speech. No doubt he is the best face in the Democrats and that is why they have given him this challenge tonight. It is a challenge because Senator Woodley forgot to mention that the Democrats supported the government in this budget measure. It was a very good try by Senator Woodley. He brought forward some interesting points about the difference between rural and city pricing, but he cannot escape the fact that he is party to this budget measure increase.

Senator Woodley said that the 1c per litre increase in leaded petrol will not have a disincentive effect. I understood that Senator Woodley wanted further rises to increase the disincentive. Senator Woodley wants more taxes, but he is here tonight trying to criticise the government. Senator Sherry, do not take any notice of the Democrats' attack upon the government today; it is totally discredited. I hope Senator Kernot is watching this on television because her representative here tonight wants more tax on petrol. In contrast, the history of the coalition is simply that we have rejected any increase at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are not in government to do these things.
—I would like to address some comments that you made. I am quite disappointed in you—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! Senator McGauran, you should address all of your remarks to the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite right, Mr Acting Deputy President; I should know better. I would have thought Senator Sherry had a bit more honesty than some of his colleagues, but I am wrong. He seems to have joined the ranks of the dishonest because, quite frankly, in his defence of the government he made two fundamental mistakes, and I think they were dishonest mistakes—deliberate or otherwise.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry claimed that the government did not make any commitment not to increase the tax on leaded or unleaded petrol at all prior to the election. That is not true at all. What Senator Sherry tried to explain away was that the former Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, actually meant something completely different based on 24 per cent of GDP as the general tax collection. Mr Dawkins never said that prior to the election. Furthermore, I do not think anyone would understand what he was talking about. What is really important is what the Prime Minister said on Lateline in November 1992. That is the transcript from which Senator Sherry should have been reading. Prior to the March 1993 election the Prime Minister said that he was promising that there would be no increase in taxes.

What Senator Sherry has read is a transcript from the former Treasurer after the election, and that is a dishonest approach to this debate. Further, Senator Sherry tried to tell us that the tax cuts were delivered. The tax cuts were not delivered because the government changed its mind after the election. The government has given half the tax cuts now and will give approximately the other half in 1997. The government did not mention this arrangement prior to the election. Senator Sherry has joined the ranks of the dishonest in the government in presenting this case.

However, during the budget debate Senator Collins happened to admit—by mistake or whatever—that this tax increase on petrol has nothing to do with health issues, as the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, would have us believe. However, it has everything to do with a tax windfall benefit to the government at the expense of the consumers—the Australian rural community and Australian industry. I lament the fate of rural Australia if Senator Sherry has any say in government policy towards rural Australia. He admitted that he had absolutely no idea how to implement policies to reduce the price difference between country and city.

Senator Sherry should have been listening to some parts of Senator Woodley's speech. In fact, I invite Senator Woodley to submit some of his policies to the government because he will not get anywhere by introducing those sorts of policies in his own party. He is in the wrong party. He should submit them to the National Party and to the government and they may get up as policy. Senator Sherry was inviting Senator Woodley and me to explain how we can reduce the burden of petrol prices on rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I was inviting you to answer how you would solve the lead problem.
—I suggest a more important problem is the price of petrol in rural Australia, and that can be tackled by—
—They are both problems.

—They are both probably equally important. If Senator Sherry cares to investigate the terminal gate system, as it is called—not many people would understand what that means—he would see that that is how we would reduce the price of petrol to rural people.
—What are you going to do about the lead problem?

—There is no lead problem in rural Australia. Surely Senator Sherry is not going to take the same line as Mrs Kelly, when she looked down the barrel of a camera—I have never seen anything more false—and said, `This tax is for the children'. Surely Senator Sherry is not going to fall for that one. Let Mrs Kelly try and sell that one. It is unsaleable.

PARA.TAB: We are not seeking parity of pricing between metropolitan and rural regions. There will always be a difference in transport costs. But the price difference is over and above the transport costs; it is up to 20 cents a litre. People in rural areas are paying the price for the discounting occurring in the cities. The question is: why is the petrol price difference in rural Australia greater than the transport cost of the petrol? We need to introduce the terminal gate system, which reduces the price so that the difference is only that of the transport cost. That will provide a stimulus for rural and regional Australia.

That is something that the Kelty report should have tackled. And that leads me to ask: what was the use of the Kelty report? All it suggested was an increase in fuel tax. It did not even bother to investigate a system of price reduction. Kelty, probably under government instructions, came up with no more of an idea than a simple increase in tax; that is how he was going to stimulate business and create expansion in rural and regional Australia.

The Labor Government ran a read-my-lips no-tax-increases campaign, and nothing symbolises the dishonesty of that approach more than these increases in petrol prices. In the course of the last federal election the Labor government repeatedly claimed that there would be no tax increases. The last election campaign was an important one. As someone who was outside the parliament at the time, it seemed to me that there was a very real sense in the community of vulnerability; a feeling that people's livelihoods were really on the line at that election. It seemed that the country had gone into a deep depression: the labour markets had collapsed; industries and small businesses had toppled over one after the other. Families were desperately trying to hang on to some form of security, some thread of hope that they would not be next in the firing line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that why they voted for us?

—They took the government at its word. They weighed up the odds and took the government at its word. They accepted the undertakings of the government—a government which had been in power for a decade, and which had the resources of the Public Service at its beck and call. They believed that the government had some dignity of office and that it was speaking from that position. It was a desperate choice made by people on the brink. That is a situation that must be appreciated. If we do not understand the mood of the time—the brittle nature of the community's confidence in the economy—we will not grasp the dimension of the breach of faith that occurred when last August's budget was presented.
—Have you told your leader all this, about why you lost the election?

—Senator Sherry should address himself to what I have been saying. To set the scene one has to understand the breach of faith that occurred with last August's budget. In particular, one must appreciate the anger over the rise in community charges and taxes in areas such as those affected by this tax. The government exploited the vulnerability of the community and took advantage of its anxieties. That is a post-election fact.

PARA.TAB: If perceptions hold strong in politics, this government is labelled as dishonest. That is a perception that will not wear off. This is something that Senator Loosley, as a strategist, should listen to. It is a perception that will not wear off and it will be a winning factor for the coalition in any future election, regardless of any slick campaign that the Labor Party might mount.

Regardless of opinion polls and the way they roller-coaster up and down, that perception is ingrained in the electorate: we have a dishonest government. There will be many issues between now and the next election, but this will be one of them because it is a perception that has stuck.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened with Werriwa?

—I cannot answer that. Coming from the National Party, that is not my business. The community's perception will overshadow any supposed recovery that the government tries to ride to popularity. No matter how it tries to sell this recovery, the perception of this government as dishonest will be an election issue; it will not go away. In this new year the usual spin doctors have been predicting a recovery—the champion being the Prime Minister, predicting a four per cent rate in growth—
—Well, everyone is.

—No, they are not. I can assure Senator Sherry that the people of Australia have stopped listening to such spin doctors. They know that there will be no recovery while one million people are unemployed. Does the honourable senator think that those people are going to listen to the Treasurer (Mr Willis) adjusting his budget as he did today? They have stopped listening. They have stopped listening to the government because of its dishonest approach in all areas of policy since the election.

PARA.TAB: According to its post-election budget, the government is expecting the community to pay a number of increased taxes in addition to the one before us today. If there is to be a recovery the government is in danger of stifling it because recovery depends on nursing our economy back to health. Increased taxation on such a vital commodity as fuel affects industry, small business and households and will set back any possibility of recovery.

In the short time I have left I will not be able to address all the matters upon which I would like to touch. I conclude by saying that no argument put forward by the government, be it from Senator Sherry, or from Senator Loosley who will follow me in this debate, will convince the electorate that it has not been deceived by this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the propositions put forward by Senator Vanstone in raising this matter of public importance. I take it that the matter was intended to encompass more than a discussion of petrol taxes. In fact, it relates to broken commitments, so I would like to deal with questions of commitment.

PARA.TAB: In his contribution to the debate, Senator McGauran made reference to opinion polls. Opinion polls are useful tools from time to time, particularly as we draw closer to an election. I would have thought that we saw the results of a straw poll last weekend in the federal division of Werriwa. Every argument that the coalition has put in the chamber this evening could have been put to the electorate of Werriwa.

I have some experience of that division because it was my privilege to be John Kerin's campaign director when Gough Whitlam retired from parliament in the early part of 1978. I remember the Werriwa by-election vividly. In September of 1978, Labor was still in the political doldrums nationally as a consequence of the debacle of 1975 and as reinforced by the heavy electoral defeat of December 1977. There had not been much good news on the federal political landscape. For example, in the Cunningham by-election of 1977, Labor did not poll well. There was a movement to Labor of about one per cent when Stewart West replaced the late Rex Connor, but by any criterion Cunningham had not been a particularly successful by-election contest. All that changed when Werriwa came along.

The problem facing the coalition at the moment is that it is just not serious. If it were serious, Dr Hewson would have bid his position goodbye after the last general election. We have had to make hard decisions about leadership. Time after time we have been prepared to make those decisions—and we have made the right ones. The coalition has not been prepared to do that. The National Party cannot walk away from its responsibilities and obligations with a Pontius Pilate-like washing of the hands, saying, `This is not our problem'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't need to change ours.

—Are the two parties not forming some sort of coalition, unholy as it may be? It is just as much Senator McGauran's problem as that of any Liberal Party senator in the chamber at the moment. Well do I remember the Werriwa by-election of September 1978. I remember the campaign and the issues; I remember Mr Kerin starting at 5 a.m. and going right through to midnight. We took it very seriously. We proceeded to put an enormous hole in the Fraser government for the first time since Mr Fraser was appointed to office by Sir John Kerr on 11 November. People wrote about it as such and it was interpreted as such. The political conclusion was drawn that Labor was on the way back. And so it proved to be in the ensuing 1980 election when Bill Hayden made enormous inroads and laid the foundations for Labor to be returned to power in 1983.

PARA.TAB: We took Werriwa seriously. We fielded a good candidate. We made it count. We made the by-election a referendum on the federal government at that time. The coalition could have done that. All the bleating here in this chamber tonight could have been done then; but it was not. The candidate was arguably the worst candidate fielded in a federal by-election in the country's history. I note the nods opposite. I will say no more. I will not mention the Macquarie Fields ghetto remarks, and so on. I will not mention the fielding of a candidate who said at the start of the by-election, `We can't win'.

We have to look at the problems in the New South Wales division of the Liberal Party. The division did not want a candidate. Dr Hewson seemed at first to want one; then he did not. He finally said, `Yes'. What happened? The division decided there would be a candidate, but in name only. The Liberals did not take it seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —What on earth has this to do with the subject under debate?

—If Senator Short were taking his politics seriously, he would not be putting rubbish like this to us in the chamber because, as Senator Sherry said earlier, all it indicates is the total absence of any political platform or framework. Those opposite would do better to embrace Fightback again. They are absolutely silent on lead in petrol, revenue and taxes. There is no policy position evident in the coalition.

PARA.TAB: I was in Moree the other day opening some first-class library facilities for the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe. It would be of interest to Senator McGauran to hear what the Nationals on the ground are saying about the Liberals and about their leadership. In terms of commitment, the government consistently honours its undertakings. We saw that at the end of last year on industrial relations, Mabo and APEC; and the economy is coming good. The economy is growing strongly, exactly as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and everyone else in the Labor team said in March 1993.

Senator Vanstone continually asks, `What was the date?'. She asked that rhetorically 20 times of Senator Sherry. The only date that mattered in 1993 was 13 March. It would be better for the country and our politics if those opposite came to terms with the fact that they lost the election. They cannot refight it now in February 1994. All that will happen is that by 1996, when we go to the polls again, they will have the perfect formula for winning in 1993. I simply cannot understand why the coalition does not move on. There has to be more of a problem than simple matters of leadership. In Werriwa we had a contest in 1978. There was a swing against the government. The conservative government at the time was 12 per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think that the chair should act in that way when I stand on a point of order. My point of order is of relevance.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—What are you saying I am acting like?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you took a dislike to my point of order when I stood up.
—I am afraid you are reading something into it that was not there.

—I am sorry if I did. I raise a point of order of relevance. I have waited for Senator Loosley to make some relevant points on this debate and all he has spoken of is the by-election that occurred the other week, and what has happened in Moree and other places. I am interested to hear what he has to say on this matter. I stayed in the chamber to listen because I heard nothing from Senator Sherry. I would like you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to get him back to the subject at hand.
—I think matters of public importance usually range fairly widely, but I ask Senator Loosley to address the issue more closely.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I do hope you will look kindly on me during this debate, unlike Senator Panizza. The simple fact is that in terms of making judgments on whether or not the Labor government keeps its commitments, we had a by-election last Saturday in Werriwa. The coalition could have made these issues of some relevance to the electorate if there was any foundation to the suggestion that is inherent in Senator Vanstone's proposition; but there is not. What happened in the by-election? There was a very small shift in opinion such as will be found in any electorate in the country at any time. There was virtually no movement to the coalition at all.

PARA.TAB: If people were absolutely serious about making an issue of commitments, Werriwa was the opportunity. Werriwa has passed by. Mark Latham is now in the House of Representatives. All we are seeing opposite is an absolute fixation on leadership. The only broken promise that is of concern today, if we are talking about broken promises—and I say to Senator Panizza that this is of direct relevance—is Senator Bishop's failure to restate her earlier promise not to challenge for the leadership of her party. The honourable senator goes silent. He was in the party room today. Why did Senator Bishop not restate her promise? Is the promise broken? That is the only broken promise that is of any consequence today as we debate these matters.

The economy, in terms of the commitments given by the Labor government in the lead-up to the general election, during the election and subsequently, is growing strongly; as is employment. We are coming off a low inflation base; a base of low interest rates. Governments of different persuasions have endeavoured to achieve that for more than two decades. This has been accomplished exactly as we as a government said that it would be achieved. It is an excellent performance by any criteria devised and employed, and by any comparison within the OECD.

We kept our commitments on Mabo and native title—and I am very proud of that. We did not walk away from them. We were faced with absolute intransigence, truculence and obstruction opposite. There was absolute opposition; a fall into negativism. We kept our commitments on industrial relations. Every commitment we gave we honoured; right through to enterprise bargaining. We were absolutely determined to see the industrial relations system taking another step forward with Minister Brereton. We kept the commitments. Again, all we had was absolute opposition and negativism. No constructive alternative was given.

We kept our commitments on APEC. The Seattle leaders forum took APEC a step further. The Jakarta leaders forum will take it another step forward. We have kept our commitments on health. A restructuring is going on within the health portfolio at the moment that will mean a better delivery of health services for Australians, regardless of where they live and regardless of income. It is being achieved in a generally cooperative framework, exactly as we said we would do. These are commitments that have been maintained and honoured.

We heard from Senator McGauran, who followed Senator Woodley, the tired old rhetoric, `Ignore the issues and the government, just bash the Democrats'. At one stage he says that Senator Woodley's speech has served to totally discredit him. Five minutes later he is calling upon Senator Sherry to read the same speech closely. The honourable senator cannot have it both ways, even by the logic of the National Party. A document cannot totally discredit someone—and I would be interested in Senator Kemp's sophistry on this point—and five minutes later be worthy of the government's close and enduring scrutiny.

We heard that the Werriwa by-election was a test of whether commitments had been honoured. The government passed it with flying colours. It will be very interesting to see what happens to the Fahey government in New South Wales in a very short time in the North Shore by-election, and how the question of commitments will be judged by the people of the North Shore. In terms of the political health of the government, as a consequence of the March election it has seldom been better. The political health opposite is another story.

More importantly, the economic health of the nation is sound and growing better. Growth of four per cent, as the Prime Minister made clear, is now achievable. Not only is the Prime Minister citing a figure of four per cent, but also leading people in industry, such as Mr John Prescott of BHP, are saying four per cent is achievable. That has happened exactly as we said that goal would be accomplished within the cooperative framework that we established with the trade union movement, business and so on. So all those commitments have been honoured.

A complete dearth of coalition policy is again evident opposite. All we have is hollow rhetoric; all we have is political leadership that is hanging by a thread at the discretion of Crichton-Browne. Heaven help us—I am glad I am not in that circumstance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing this matter of public importance regarding Labor's broken election promises, I was particularly interested in the selective memories of Senator Sherry and Senator Loosley. I would refresh Senator Sherry's memory regarding the actual statements that were made about not raising taxes and not introducing further taxes. I refer him to some of these statements. At the Press Club on 19 August 1992, Mr Dawkins declared:

SPEECH.PARA: We will not be introducing new taxes.
Mr Dawkins told parliament on 16 September:

I emphasise that this will be achieved without resort to any new taxes, let alone the imposition of a crushing tax on the necessities of everyday life and almost everything else consumed by Australians and their families.
How does that add up to a new petrol tax? He also assured parliament on 15 September that:
We can pay for our personal tax cuts.
As was indicated by my colleague Senator McGauran, on Lateline on 19 November 1992 Mr Keating was categoric. He said:
What I am promising is not to put up tax.

What is this if not putting up tax? I am not surprised that Senator Loosley wished to hark back to the glories of the Cunningham by-election. He certainly did not have anything to relish in the results last Saturday in the Werriwa by-election where there was a swing against his party of 11 1/2 per cent on the primary vote. This can be compared with an average of a 4.7 per cent swing against the government in the last four by-elections. If those opposite call that passing the by-election with flying colours, I would be interested to see their version of a defeat.

PARA.TAB: I also refer Senator Loosley to Senator Evans's extremely interesting statements today during question time in reply to a question asked by Senator Hill. I will be dealing with some of these statements individually. Senator Evans said that the new tax is an important part of the deficit reduction strategy. He also said that the tax creates the incentive for people who drive cars which use leaded petrol to switch cars—that is, to move from using leaded petrol to unleaded petrol. For most of those people that is a fiscal impossibility. He also mentioned the health factor, which I will deal with in due course.

I would like to deal with this question from the point of view of the claims that have been made by the government and the inherent contradictions in what it is proposing. For instance, the government has claimed that the lead level is too high and therefore we should make the tax on leaded petrol punitive to stop people from using so much of this fuel. The health and community services department in Victoria says that the lead in the blood of Victorian children has halved since 1979, and that nearly 100 per cent of Victorian children have lead levels in their blood below that required by safety measures. Not only that, it says that the main danger to children from lead is through eating lead-based paints in pre-1960 homes.

In fact, the chief health officer of that very same department, Dr Rouch, said that as little as 10 per cent of the lead in people's bodies comes through the air. So it seems unlikely that our children are in great danger through leaded petrol. The lead content of at least Victorian petrol has been cut over the years. Since 1979 the average blood lead level for a Victorian child has more than halved to 5.4 micrograms per 100 millilitres. Lead is not as much of a problem in country and rural areas, yet rural areas are going to be hardest hit by the fuel tax increase.

I would like to deal next with Senator Evans's claim that by taxing leaded petrol, more owners will change to cars that use unleaded petrol. The contradiction in this is that taxing the fuel used by older vehicles will reduce their value. Therefore, it will be very much harder for the owners to trade them in on unleaded petrol vehicles. The cars used by struggling families will usually be older and therefore more likely to use leaded fuel. The market value of such cars will drop and fewer people will be able to trade up to a newer car. More than 50 per cent of Australia's cars on the road today are at least nine years old compared with only 35 per cent a decade ago.

If Senator Loosley does not think this is a fundamental problem, I can assure him that for more than 50 per cent of car owners it is. How are they going to trade in a value depleted car that uses lead fuel on a new unleaded petrol model? It simply is not possible. Leaded petrol will remain at least 20 per cent of petrol purchased until the year 2000.

A fortnight ago I pulled into a service station in Warrnambool—a very good representative example of regional Australia. While I was parked in my unleaded fuel car, three cars pulled into the service station. Each of those cars used leaded fuel. I can assure Senator Loosley and Senator Sherry that if they took the trouble to move around in regional Australia, they would find far more leaded petrol cars than unleaded petrol cars.

Stabilising the price of fuel and not taxing it further would make it much easier for consumers to save money and to switch to new cars. Rural Australians already pay more for fuel—in some places up to 15c more than those in the city. A further increase in fuel costs is not going to encourage them to buy new cars. So I hope that that disposes of what was said by Senator Evans today.

The section of the population that drives leaded petrol cars is made up of older people who need their cars to get to medical appointments and to make their weekly shopping trips. They are unlikely, on pensionable incomes, to be able to drive newer cars. It is these groups who are least able to afford new cars.

A third claim that has been made by the government is that it will use part of this tax increase to educate the public to use unleaded petrol where possible. The unleaded differential is supposed to bring in $100 million in a full year but something like only $4.5 million of this will be spent on education.

In addition, the education that is proposed may encourage drivers of older cars to use unleaded petrol in leaded cars and to unwittingly damage their cars. No less an authority than the chief engineer of the RACV, Mr Ron de Forest, was quoted in today's Herald-Sun as saying—and honourable senators will excuse my lack of mechanical knowledge:

SPEECH.PARA: The valves can start wearing into the cylinder head . . . and the valves will ultimately wear out.

So, people who are not aware of the finer points of using unleaded petrol in leaded engines may ultimately do great damage to their cars and end up having very expensive repairs.The executive director of the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce, Mr Bob Davison, also estimated that cars which have engine modifications will be unable to withstand the impact of unleaded petrol.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to some of the claims which have been made by the recent Kelty regional report which saw value adding in food processing—particularly in some key regions of Victoria, such as Bendigo and the Goulburn Valley—as being very important in the future to strengthen the farm sector and help exploit Asian market opportunities. If the costs that are inherent in the fuel tax increase are passed on, not only will consumers in those areas pay an extra $2 to $3 for the average shopping trolley of consumables, but also every 1c increase in the fuel excise costs the farming sector $26.8 million and adds $23.3 million to the cost of the food processing sector, $6.9 million to the mining sector and $9 million to the forestry industries.

Again, a fortnight ago I visited the shire of Deakin, centred on the town of Tongala in northern Victoria. That area in the Goulburn Valley was particularly pinpointed by the Kelty regional report as one that can see a glowing future in the area of food processing. How can that area progress if it is immediately hit by increased transport costs?

These industries have already been hit by the 3c increase in the budget and they face another 1c to 2c round of increases in August. Accounting for only the 5c increase in diesel and unleaded fuel excise this represents, it means increasing the cost burden on these industries by $330 million in just 12 months. The government feels that there will be only a 0.09 per cent inflationary effect from this price increase, but it does not examine the effect industry by industry or state by state.

The National Transport Federation has estimated it will cost an extra five per cent to transport a raw product such as fruit, vegetables or other grocery type products to the manufacturer. It will cost a further five per cent to transport the manufactured product to the wholesaler, and possibly a further five per cent from the wholesaler to the retailer. This does not augur well for our export industries, particularly in the area of clean food.

The last claim I would like to deal with is the myth that fuel excise contributes to road maintenance. In 10 years of Labor government the fuel tax has increased from 6c a litre to 26.5c a litre. From 1981 to 1982, the coalition government spent 70 per cent of excise on road funding, but the Labor government has diluted the excise to such an extent that this year only 12.1 per cent of the excise collected will be spent on roads. The amount of excise forecast to be spent on roads in three years time will to fall to only 8.7 per cent—disgraceful.

Senator Gareth Evans mentioned in his answer to Senator Hill today that the petrol tax is an important part of the deficit reduction strategy. For `deficit reduction strategy' read `new tax', and a new tax that will have a disastrous impact on low income earners. These low income earners cannot afford yet another hike in their living expenses. They are dependent on older leaded fuel cars to get to work and to transport their families. This tax is yet another blow to struggling families in their efforts to maintain a reasonable standard of living.

As a recent development, I draw the Senate's attention to the statement issued yesterday by the Assistant Treasurer, George Gear MP, which indicated that in the 1993 budget the government resolved to encourage the use of unleaded petrol. Accordingly, he has revoked the 1985 directive which indicated that leaded and unleaded petrol should be identically priced. By this stratagem, I would imagine that there is a further direction for the price to be increased without further reference to the Prices Surveillance Authority. In other words, it is setting this differential in concrete so that the government can move in this area without further reference to anyone. For those reasons, I consider that this petrol tax increase will have a disastrous impact on low income earners, and is yet another indication of Labor's broken election promises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B. K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the matter of public importance introduced by Senator Vanstone which reads:

PARA.TAB: The disastrous impact on low income earners of Labor's broken election promises culminating today in yet another petrol tax increase.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition's matter of public importance is very audacious because in one breath it links the election campaign of a year ago with concern about low income earners. That is quite incredible. It is almost a year ago that we were locked into an election battle at which time the opposition was proposing its consumption tax and a starvation wage for youth; it was seeking to smash the protection of the arbitration system with its industrial relations proposals; and a raft of dry, right-wing dogma was the platform of the Liberal and National parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Childs is the third government speaker we have had on Senator Vanstone's matter of public importance regarding today's increase in petrol taxes. In particular, Senator Childs—

TALK.START.PARA: —My point of order is that, in the normal course of debate, Senator Childs should be addressing matters raised by Senator Troeth and me in the form of debate. —I am making the link. —I was trying to say that the coalition parties have a hide to claim to speak on behalf of low income earners. PARA.TAB: Senator McGauran and other opposition senators want to concentrate solely on the petrol issue. But I read this MPI in a broader way to say that this Labor government implements its election promises. I assert that the beginning of the matter is such that we have implemented our promises to the people of Australia as a result of that election campaign. I certainly draw attention to the fact that the opposition is fixated on that election campaign and on the disaster that that election campaign was to the Liberal and National parties. It has not stopped because, as Senator Loosley pointed out, that confusion about policy that is characteristic of this resolution was reflected in the very last election we had. I refer to the Werriwa by-election only a week ago in which the Liberal candidate not only referred to Macquarie Fields as a ghetto—in other words, the place where underprivileged people live—but also he was still running on the consumption tax. The leader of the opposition in waiting, Senator Bishop, has a different policy formulation. The petrol situation consists of two issues. On the one hand we are talking about the environmental aspects and, on the other hand, about another part of our economic policy, namely, that if we are to control the deficit—and this government is doing that—then it has to do the difficult things. The opposition's difficulty is that it can only oppose; it cannot acknowledge that the government has to make difficult environmental and economic decisions.

This government is concerned with the lead levels in the environment, as is Australia's premier health advisory body, the National Health and Medical Research Council. The federal government is showing national leadership by developing and implementing a national lead abatement strategy in cooperation with the states and territories. A sum of $37 million has been allocated for this purpose over four years. A national education program begins today that will be coordinated by the Commonwealth Environmental Protection Agency. Ninety per cent of the lead in the atmosphere comes from vehicle emissions. The national lead and petrol round table conference, held in July 1993, agreed on a package of measures. These included reducing faster and to a lower level the amount of lead in petrol than had been previously planned. The round table conference also recommended a price differential favouring unleaded petrol, which is in line with successful practices overseas.

There are one million vehicles in Australia that could switch to unleaded petrol straight away without any engine modification. That is the particular area the government wishes to target. The differential is designed to encourage people to switch to unleaded petrol. Solutions are being sought for vehicles that cannot easily make that switch. The differential amounts to an extra 40c to 60c per week for a family car, while the tax rebate for low income earners announced in the last budget amounted to about $3 a week. The government wishes to be fair, to achieve its environmental standards, and to make sure that the lower paid people are compensated.

The simple fact is that in many different ways this government has protected low income people. I could list—I have the list here—the government promises that have been implemented since the last election. They stand as a record of achievement and that is why we are in government and why we will remain in government. Unfortunately, this matter of public importance shows the confusion of the opposition—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! If Senator Panizza wants to interject, he should be in his seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I ask you again, in all fairness, with the short time that Senator Childs has left—
—I have already ruled on the point of order that I think you are coming to.
