—Because of the lack of content of the matter of public importance, I will not go any further because I think there is more important business for the Senate to go on with than to spend time dealing with this poor proposal from the opposition.
—Madam Acting Deputy President—
—This is a surprise appearance.

—I am surprised that Senator Kemp is surprised by my appearance to speak on this issue because it touches very closely on a matter which I have been pursuing since the first day I entered this place. Contributions to a considerable part of this debate, especially by Senator Troeth but also by others, have perpetuated some of the myths that surround the issue of the fuel that is used in our cars in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator Childs accurately said in his remarks that there are approximately a million cars in Australia that could switch from using leaded petrol to unleaded petrol without damage to their engines and without any alteration in their performances. Since 1 January 1986 new cars have been required to be capable of running on unleaded petrol. In many cases that has meant that manufacturers have fitted catalytic converters as well as slightly differently tuned engines. In other cases the vehicles have been designed from the very start to use the lower octane fuel and they have had engine head designs which have not required the lubrication that is provided by lead in petrol.

What ought to be questioned immediately is the expression `a leaded fuel car'. There is no such thing as a leaded fuel car in Australia. There is not one motor vehicle in the whole of Australia that is a leaded fuel car. There may be a great number of vehicles that require the high octane that the additive lead brings to the fuel; there may be a considerable number of motor vehicles in Australia that require upper cylinder lubrication that is provided to the valve seats by the addition of lead. But lead is not the only additive that brings a higher octane rating to standard fuel.

The most useful and most convenient additive to provide a higher octane rating, such as is provided by lead, is in fact ethanol. That was recognised in the negotiations which the Democrats held with the government during the budget process. The Democrats negotiated a bounty of 18c a litre to be paid on the production of ethanol as fuel.

The negotiations that produced that bounty have spawned a considerable expansion in the ethanol producing industry in Australia. That must be recognised as a significant contribution to employment prospects in rural Australia. The harvest of Australia's largest single wheat crop has been recorded by the Manildra group just this season, and a considerable amount of that wheat will be used to produce the raw materials to produce ethanol fuel.

Ethanol fuel is mixed with unleaded petrol to provide a higher octane fuel which is suitable for use in pre-1986 cars and other cars which may require a higher octane fuel. That is the answer which has been ignored in this debate. It is the answer which should be immediately apparent to anybody who takes the trouble to find out why it is we are told that we need lead in fuel. We do not. We need a higher octane additive in some fuels for some vehicles. Ethanol has provided that.

It is about time that the people who wish to contribute to debates such as this take in the basic technical knowledge that will give them that enlightenment. I am disappointed that this debate has been predicated upon the notion that there are vehicles which require leaded fuel. There are none. They require a higher octane fuel.

The answer has been provided by the negotiations which were concluded by the Democrats, and I am proud to have been part of that. I just wish that those who criticise the situation that we have now where a differential has been provided in leaded fuel versus unleaded fuel would encourage people to switch to alternatives. My only disappointment is that on this very day it is difficult to find that alternative fuel throughout Australia. I will be trying to ensure that it is more readily available.

We should remind ourselves of what Senator Childs rightly said: there are still a million cars which could switch to unleaded fuel without danger today. While that does not solve the problem completely, I think the best solution is provided by the addition of ethanol to the fuel. It is working. There are many service stations throughout New South Wales where the fuel is available, and the number of service stations is growing.

The production of ethanol as an additive to fuel, as a gasohol combination, is increasing. I would encourage all honourable senators to make it their business to inform people that this is the best way of going about saving people from the additional expense of paying the differential between unleaded and leaded fuel and to encourage people to ask for it so as to increase demand throughout Australia.

The supply is increasing markedly in New South Wales and I suggest it will not be long before it will be readily available in Queensland. As a matter of fact, at various times over the past 70 or 80 years this fuel has been available throughout Queensland. It has proved to be a very satisfactory additive, one which gives an alternative market to sugar producers as well. But not only sugar producers benefit; rural Australia in its entirety benefits because many crops can be used to produce this fuel. The most promising one at the moment is the waste woody weeds which are such a problem in western New South Wales. The cellulosis material from those weeds has been successfully proven to be capable of producing a very low cost ethanol and that, combined with the waste material from wheat starch processing, really does give a promising situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the costs like?

—If Senator Kemp had taken the trouble to look at the availability in New South Wales, he would find that the gasohol mix is selling for exactly the same price as unleaded fuel. That means that all this rhetoric about disadvantages for people driving—

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this is the solution to the problem that has been created for people who drive vehicles with older engines which, we are told—and the myth has been perpetuated here tonight—require leaded fuel. They do not. The solution is here, and I encourage people to endorse that solution.

—Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 13 February 1991, I table the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Performance pay, which was presented to the President on 22 December 1993. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, the President authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the transcript of evidence and submissions by the committee relating to the report just tabled.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I presented this report to the President just before Christmas and it has now been formally tabled. The report is more critical of policy and administration than is common in committee reports. I regretted the need to be so critical but the criticism was fully justified on the basis of the evidence available to the committee.

PARA.TAB: I very much regret that the government adopted the policy of performance pay. I should point out, however, that it was also strongly supported in this policy at the time by the opposition, which made it difficult for contrary views to gain currency. I hope that the government will now pay particular regard to this report and decide to abandon the scheme as the committee has recommended. If it does make such a decision, it will be greatly applauded, and I believe there will be immense relief throughout the Public Service.

In short, the committee found that there were fundamental conceptual problems with the system of performance pay adopted in the Australian Public Service and the scheme was never likely to achieve the objectives set for it. The prospects for success were further reduced by serious design faults and by faulty implementation, especially on the part of the central coordinating agencies—the Department of Industrial Relations, the Department of Finance and the Public Service Commission. It should be remembered that serious warnings were given in advance of precisely the types of problems which occurred. Two reports of the finance and public administration committee in 1990 stand up very well in this regard.

The committee's conclusions in the present inquiry are summarised in chapter 7 of the report. Briefly, they are that the performance pay system is based on assumptions about motivation and the nature of work in organisations that are not valid or appropriate for much of the Australian Public Service. The system required a degree of precision in the measurement of individual contributions to organisational output which is not realistically attainable in many public sector agencies in either the short term or the long term. In the absence of that precision, the motivational effects sought from performance pay could not be achieved and, as a result, none of its objectives could be met.

As well as being unlikely to achieve its objectives, the performance pay system created a range of serious inequities and has been widely seen as divisive and destructive of team effort. Its link to staff appraisal detracted from the benefits potentially available from good appraisal systems in several ways.

The implementation of performance pay was also flawed. Appraisal systems were developed and implemented very hastily in most agencies. Typically, the appraisal systems were established in a matter of a few months and then immediately used to support the payment of bonuses, which was in contradiction of all the relevant theory and of common sense.

The central support for implementation was manifestly inadequate. Performance pay was said to be directed at a major change in Public Service culture. However, the central agencies coordinating its introduction were given no additional resources to manage its implementation. As a result, they accepted little responsibility for implementation, presenting as their excuse the usual slogans about devolution. The committee concluded that the central agencies had misrepresented the concept of devolved responsibility for management. Devolution is acceptable as a management strategy only if it is properly matched with accountability.

The coordinating agencies developed a system which was then compulsorily applied to all departments and agencies. In doing so, they failed to design a system that could be expected to achieve its objectives; they failed to ensure that departments and agencies understood the system that had been designed; they failed to specify effective reporting and control systems and therefore failed to detect widespread departures from the letter and spirit of the system they had designed; and they underestimated the need for investment in implementation.

The main result of poor system design and faulty implementation of performance pay has been a widespread lack of acceptance of the system. The extent to which the official submissions of departments and agencies were critical of the policy aspects of performance pay was unprecedented in my years of experience as a member of parliamentary committees. While there were some supporters, the response from individual public servants and from outside observers was overwhelmingly negative. The committee notes in the report that the willingness of so many to comment frankly on the problems posed by performance pay was in the best tradition and the best interests of the Public Service.

The committee's general conclusion was that nothing could be retrieved from the present scheme. If the government wishes to persist in seeking the objectives it sought through performance pay, it could do so more effectively by beginning again than by attempting to repair the present scheme. There are other ways of achieving the types of objectives sought through performance pay. The committee has provided a partial list of alternatives. The current round of agency bargaining provides an opportunity to explore such options.

I would like to express the committee's thanks to the staff of the Australian National Audit Office and to its own staff. This inquiry required the collection of a large base of factual information very quickly. The audit office, which had begun an audit of performance pay independently of the committee, worked with the committee in conducting a major survey of departments and agencies, collecting and analysing basic information on their implementation of performance pay. The full results of the survey are printed as an appendix to the committee's report, while the committee and the audit office drew on it for their separate reviews and reports.

Use of the audit office in this way gave the committee access to expertise on survey design and additional analytical capacity as well as resolving possible problems related to individual privacy. This was a model of cooperation between a parliamentary committee and the audit office in which the independence of both was preserved.

The committee was very keen to finalise this report as quickly as possible so as to have its views considered in the agency bargaining process. The inquiry was completed to an unusually tight deadline, imposing heavy pressure on all who were involved. In conclusion, I again urge that the performance pay system in the Australian Public Service be abandoned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition members of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration endorse the criticisms of performance pay contained in its report entitled Performance pay, which has just been tabled and summarised by committee chairman, Senator John Coates. We are strongly of the view that individual incentives are important and the Australian Public Service reforms should aim to create incentives for excellent performance. But our main concern with the performance pay system adopted in the Australian Public Service is that the incentives it creates will not have the desired effect.

PARA.TAB: What are the reasons for this? The reasons are that the system relies too heavily on subjective judgments of individual performance in the areas in which individual contributions cannot be properly measured. The whole logic of the system depends on its being widely accepted. There was never much of a chance that so subjective a scheme would ever be accepted. What little chance of acceptance did exist was lost through bad implementation. In fact, it is clear that performance pay was implemented as a backdoor pay rise in most agencies.

More than 90 per cent of agencies pay performance bonuses to more than 90 per cent of their staff. The three coordinating agencies and the Australian National Audit Office were among the few departments or agencies which applied the system in the way that was intended. As a result, many of their staff can legitimately complain about the way in which they were treated. Much smaller proportions of the staff of the coordinating agencies and the Australian National Audit Office received bonuses and smaller proportions were rated at the higher levels of performance than in the public service as a whole. This is not because the average quality of staff in those agencies is lower but because most of the Public Service implemented performance pay almost as a general pay rise.

The subjective element in the system has made it extremely unpopular. All members of the committee received many complaints from individual members of the public service. I can hardly remember a public service management change which has been so unpopular as this particular one. As the report makes clear, the committee received an unprecedented amount of criticism of the system from the heads of departments and agencies. I think it is particularly significant that agencies which have been generally well managed and which have implemented wide ranging, often painful reform in recent years were critical of the performance pay attitudes. And I have in mind here the Australian Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department in particular, and also the Treasury, which is surely the stronghold of economic rationalism. They expressed doubts about the theoretical basis for performance pay.

The committee reached the conclusion that the criticism of performance pay within the public service is not just a hidebound resistance to change or self-serving in its nature. It reflects a genuine and widely held belief that the performance pay system adopted in the Australian public sector will not work. Coalition members of the committee who are with me tonight—Senators Kemp and Campbell—believe that steps should be taken to increase the flexibility of public service pay and conditions and to reward excellence, but we do not believe that the system of performance pay can meet those desirable objectives. We also have grave concerns about the accountability aspects of the system. Performance pay has been implemented with such secrecy that some agencies believed they could refuse access to performance pay records by the Auditor-General. In fact, the Auditor-General had to issue precepts under section 13 of the Audit Act to secure access to some of the records. This is apparently the first use of this power in the 93 years since federation.

Several departments and agencies also failed initially to comply with requests to supply information for the survey conducted by the audit office for the committee and cited individual privacy as their reason. The Auditor-General has unquestioned access to taxation and social security records, to national security information and to the pay records of junior public servants. It is simply ludicrous to argue that the pay of senior public servants should be more secret than these. Reporting systems that were established to meet accountability concerns were also inadequate. The coordinating agencies eventually conceded this. When this is added to the resistance to proper audit scrutiny, accountability becomes a serious issue.

There are also important equity problems with the particular system of performance pay adopted in the Australian public sector. The scheme focuses on the individual rather than on the team, at a time when the Public Service Commission is emphasising teamwork as one of the most important management concepts. Most of the teams operating within the public service incorporate staff below the senior officer level who are not eligible to receive performance pay but who have contributed significantly to their supervisors' reward. Performance pay in such situations creates unfair differentials in the treatment of public servants in different employment classifications, in different work units within agencies and departments, and in different agencies. It is likely to be perceived as divisive and detrimental to the team as such.

I was absolutely outraged to learn that there are proposals to extend the system to the senior ranks of the Defence Force in the same year that most junior ranks have lost access to significant assistance through the social security system. The committee was told that Social Security Amendment Act No. 2 of 1993 had the effect of reducing payments to some members of the Defence Force at private or equivalent level by up to $1,500 per annum at the same time that it is proposed to pay large performance bonuses to officers at lieutenant colonel level and above. Overall, this is an object lesson in bad policy design and implementation. I hope the government will take account of the committee's very important comments and recommendations in moving to a system for improving public service performance that we could all support.

In conclusion, I would like to commend all members of the team. I commend Senator Coates on the fair and bipartisan way in which he chaired the committee, and to join him in thanking the audit office and the committee staff who assisted in the inquiry. The very useful survey that was conducted for the committee involved a great deal of extra staff time and work and was completed to a very tight deadline. It is a good example of how the audit office and parliamentary committees can work together. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this report. I concur with the remarks of my colleague Senator Watson and with many of the remarks of Senator Coates. There are only two points I wish to make because the other points have been well made. The first point is that this is an excellent example of what a Senate committee can do. Senator Coates was quite right to draw our attention to the way in which the committee worked. We took wide ranging evidence from many departments and individuals. The evidence, as Senator Watson and Senator Coates have said, was overwhelmingly against the system which has been imposed. The committee came down with a report to which all members were prepared to append their names. Perhaps given the wide disparity of views which exist on this committee, that in itself is some particular achievement. It is a good example of the way Senate committees can work. I also join in paying compliments to the staff of the committee and, in particular, Peter Hamburger.

PARA.TAB: My second point is one of the few areas in which I differ slightly from Senator Coates. He said that the Liberal-National parties supported performance pay. I do not recall them being a party before the election to the design of this particular scheme. This particular scheme was drummed up, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you know, between the government and the public sector unions. That the public sector unions ever agreed to this scheme, which delivered massive increases to the most senior and well-paid levels of the public service, and fairly minimal rises to the lower ranks, is something which I find beyond belief. I believe the evidence that was given by the secretary of the Public Service Union is interesting in this regard. He was critical of the government, and I think he was quite right.

Equally, I think its own performance was a very poor one. The scheme was rushed in. As Senator Coates so well said, it was a poorly designed scheme. As Senator Watson said, it was designed to deliver a rise before an election. As a consequence, we are left with a scheme which is unworkable. If left in place, I believe it has the capacity to corrupt many of the most worthwhile features of the public service, and that is what worries me. It is important that the government take on board the recommendations of this committee. Hopefully, we will see a scheme which deals with the problems we have raised in this report so that the traditions of the public service and its accountability are not compromised as I believe they have been compromised by this particular scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I want to make some brief remarks on the excellent and timely inquiry into performance pay, a system which has been rightly criticised by all political parties in this report. Undoubtedly, the performance pay scheme was introduced hastily. The committee report goes into some detail about not only the failure of the scheme, as implemented, but also the failure of the policy implementation process. The report makes it clear that, to have an effective performance pay system, far more time should have been allowed for its implementation.

PARA.TAB: Performance pay was implemented in such a way as to ensure its failure. Departmental managers were not allowed adequate time to ensure a process of assessment that encourages performance. Hence, performance pay has met with both success and failure across the Australian Public Service—less problems in some of the smaller agencies and greater problems in the larger departments. Performance pay has created enormous morale problems—rivalries set up between and in departments, which has not helped to create a more efficient and productive public sector, which all parties would like to see. I know that Senator Coates is personally committed to increasing efficiency in the public sector, probably for different reasons from me, but at least we both seek to achieve the same end.

All Australians are served by having an Australian federal government and a public sector that provides efficient and cost effective service to the Australian community. It is no use having a public sector that unnecessarily chews up taxpayers' dollars because not only does the public not get the service it is entitled to, but it also pays too much for it. The lower the taxation rate, the more jobs are created and the better Australia will be for it and the better we will be able to provide for Australians who are less better off.

One of the failures of performance pay is that it is totally internal—it is very much an inward looking scheme that fails to relate to the way the Public Service actually serves the public. I am pleased to say that, in its next inquiry, the committee will focus on how the Public Service serves the public—the interface between the Australian public and the Public Service. Parliament often spends a lot of time concentrating on the interface between the senior executive service and lower levels of the Public Service. While that is very important, in the end the interface between the taxpayer and the Public Service is often forgotten. So I look forward to the next inquiry of the committee.

I reiterate that the entire performance pay scheme seemed to pay no cognisance to the level of service provided. That was one of the performance criteria that was not taken into account. Also, the inquiry into performance pay showed that the implementation of performance pay was particularly expensive in terms of administration. Indeed, it is very hard to add up the administration costs because a lot of the costs were chewed up in normal administrative affairs. However, the administration costs were particularly expensive—as a percentage of the total cost of the scheme, performance pay was a lot lower than it could have been because a lot of the costs were chewed up by administration.

As a by-product of the inquiry in analysing its cost to the Australian taxpayer, another factor that came to my attention was an issue about which I made some public comments a couple of weeks ago in a press release which showed what had happened to public sector employment over the past few years. We have seen what happened with the performance pay inquiry. I was keen to pursue the related issue of pay in the public sector as a whole. Interestingly, I think it was the Australian Public Service bulletin that came out towards the end of last year that showed some very interesting employment trends in the senior ranks of the public sector generally.

On closer examination of those trends we found that the annual salaries of employees in the public sector had increased by $468 million in each of the last four financial years, even though the total number of employees of the Australian Public Service has decreased. During the last four years there has been a decrease of 13,712 employees at the ASO1 and ASO2 levels. However, there has been an increase in excess of 20,000 employees at the senior levels. So the service has dropped off 13,000 employees in its lower levels and reduced the salaries at those levels by $325 million but accorded its employees at the higher levels a massive increase.

So, to use a cliche, we are seeing fewer indians and more chiefs in the Public Service. As the Public Service drops its employees off at the lower levels, it brings in more employees at the higher levels and increases the salary bill, including performance pay of $43.8 million in the last financial year. The total salary bill in the Public Service, not including the SES level but above the ASO1 and ASO2 levels, was $468 million—nearly half a billion dollars in this financial year alone.

We hear the Keating Labor government talk about making cuts in the Public Service. Today we saw a strike in Senator McMullan's department, the Department of Administrative Services, because of this culling of people in the Public Service. However, the government is cutting the number of employees at the lower levels but increasing the number at higher levels. For every person the government puts off at a lower level, it puts on another one at a higher level, clearly increasing the salary bill.

We need to focus on efficiency in the Public Service. We need to ensure that performance is enhanced in the public sector, that we have the most efficient public sector. We need to focus the attention of the parliament and the executive government on seeking those efficiencies, on ensuring that service is enhanced. Undoubtedly, the government has made a number of good reforms in the Public Service—we cannot carp by saying that the government has stuffed everything up. There is no doubt that this government has made some significant advances in public sector management and reform.

However, after a lengthy and detailed inquiry, with the great assistance of the Australian National Audit Office, the unanimous decision of the committee was that the performance pay scheme has met almost none of the original criteria. As Senator Coates said, the committee strongly recommends the abandonment of performance pay and its replacement with a system that meets the criteria and policy objectives set out in the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 13 February 1991, I present the government's response to the November 1992 report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act which was presented to the President on 22 December 1993. With the concurrence of the Senate, the response will be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.EMPHASIS: THE REPORT BY THE JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE OPERATION AND INTERPRETATION OF THE FAMILY LAW ACT 1975

PROCTEXT.PARA: 1.The Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act (Committee) was established on 13 March 1991 and its principal report, making 120 recommendations, was tabled on 24 November, 1992. A total of 1031 submissions was received and 18 public hearings held. Major written and oral submissions were made by the Family Court of Australia, the Family Law Council, the Family Law Section of the Law Council of Australia, Council of Social Welfare Ministers, Marriage Counselling Organisations, National Committee on Violence Against Women and Legal Aid Commissions. In addition, evidence was given and submissions made by individual practitioners, and organisations representing both men and women.

2.On 16 September 1992, the Committee received a further reference on the funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia but had not finalised its consideration when the Parliament was prorogued. After the election, a new Committee was appointed to examine that issue and the operation and effectiveness of the Child Support Scheme. The new Committee is currently working on these two references.

3.The Report of the Committee will form the basis for the most significant changes to the Family Law Act since the introduction of no fault divorce in 1975. The scope of the Report is wide ranging and the changes it recommends offer a significant opportunity to remedy some of the intractable problems that plague the Family Law Act today. The Government thanks the Committee for its most comprehensive report.
4.This response is not considering recommendations where funding is required. Those are matters that arise for consideration in the context of the Budget.
5.The Report covers the following main areas.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mediation and Other Forms of Alternative Dispute Resolution

PROCTEXT.PARA: 6.The Government proposes to shift the entire focus of the Family Law Act from litigation to non-adversarial dispute resolution mechanisms, as practised by the Family Court and the community sector, so that partners are encouraged to develop and agree on solutions rather than have them imposed by others. When the Family Law Act was introduced in 1975 the then Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Lionel Murphy, stated that it would be a system which should not enquire into the cause of marital breakdown, would have simple procedures and be inexpensive. It is clear that this great vision has not been realised.

7.Today the system is complex, costly and focuses too narrowly on traditional litigation. Alternative dispute resolution (ADR), achieved at a greatly reduced cost, produces an agreed outcome, which is likely to be more acceptable to the parties, therefore also likely to attract greater compliance.

8.The Australian Institute of Family Studies estimates that one marriage in three will end in divorce. In the last calendar year, there were 45,665 dissolution applications, 24,174 of which involved children. It is therefore imperative that we develop a system which can provide an outcome that is more acceptable to the divorcing couple and also assists in the re-establishment of their lives after separation, whether children are involved or not. While there will ultimately always be a place for litigation in dispute resolution even in family matters, the Government believes that a far greater number of disputes can be resolved by mediation and other ADR mechanisms. This view was shared by the Committee. The separating couple should have a choice whether to resolve their difficulties by ADR or litigation. The Government recognises, however, that mediation is not appropriate where there is a serious power imbalance especially in circumstances where there is family violence.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Funding of the Family Court Counselling Service and Approved Marriage Counselling Organisations:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 9.The Committee has recommended that the Family Court Counselling Service be sufficiently resourced to provide both a range of new services and greater capacity to deal with its existing workload. The Committee also recommended the provision of additional resources to community based marriage counselling organisations for marriage counselling and endorsed the greater use of ADR in the community. The Government accepts the thrust of the Committee's recommendations as essential to achieving the shift of focus to ADR.

10.The Committee made a number of important recommendations addressing the issues of custody, guardianship and access. The Committee was not, however, convinced that a change in the existing terminology of `custody, guardianship and access' would reduce disputes between parents and it did not have sufficient evidence before it about a change in approach to the United Kingdom system under the Children Act 1989.

11.The Government believes that the current concepts and terminology are undoubtedly a source of many of the ongoing difficulties between separated parents as it fosters a notion of "property" in children. Under the Children Act 1989 (UK), each parent is assigned, through a parenting plan, specified obligations and responsibilities for the care and development of the child, such obligations diminishing as the child approaches the age of 18. The Court is only empowered to make an order relating to the child's place of residence or contact with a parent where parents have failed to agree. The Family Law Council in its report "Patterns of Parenting after Separation", tabled 25 June 1992, examined and reported favourably on the Children Act 1989 (UK) and similar developments in other overseas jurisdictions.

12.The Government is attracted to the UK approach but, in light of the Committee's reticence, believes a further assessment of the UK approach is required before making a final decision. The Attorney-General has therefore asked the Family Law Council to report by March 1994 on the operation of the UK approach so that an assessment of the desirability of a change along those lines should be made.

13.The Committee concluded that the Family Court is underutilising its powers to enforce access orders and that this is the cause of widespread community dissatisfaction. The Government accepts the Committee's recommendations for improving enforcement, including the proposal that the Family Law Council monitor the enforcement of access orders. To reduce the incidence of disputes at access handover, the Government will examine whether institutions unoccupied at weekends, such as child care centres, can be used for this purpose.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Equality of sharing of matrimonial property, farming properties and financial agreements

PROCTEXT.PARA: 14.The current property regime is entirely discretionary subject only to the principle of achieving justice and equity between the parties. This approach leads to litigation rather than settlement. The Committee recommended that a presumption of equal sharing be the starting point in the allocation of matrimonial property. It also recommended a limiting discretion to depart from that presumption in exceptional circumstances. Further, it recommended that farming properties be separately dealt with and that financial agreements be recognised and enforced.

15.The Government believes that the recommendations provide a balanced approach to a problem that has bedevilled the Family Court since its inception and endorses the Committee's approach with some variation. The Government accepts the Committee's central recommendation that a presumption of equal sharing be the starting point in the allocation of matrimonial property. Such a presumption will reflect the equality of contribution made by the parties to the relationship and the acquisition and preservation of matrimonial property. However, departure from the presumption should be permitted in a wider range of circumstances than envisaged by the Committee.

16.On the recommendations for farming property, there does not appear to be any basis for differentiating between farming properties and other businesses. The Government does not believe that farming properties should be distinguished from other matrimonial property. In all cases involving a farming or other business enterprise the Family Court should consider the desirability of preserving that business as an income producing unit.
17.In relation to financial agreements, the Government accepts the Committee's approach and will move to recognise financial agreements.

18.The Committee's approach to superannuation builds on the Government's retirement incomes policy by dividing the member spouse's benefit equitably between the parties—a matter that the Committee did say should be optional, but which the Government believes should be mandatory. The Government will continue to consult the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, the Family Court and relevant government agencies including the Office of the Status of Women in developing this reform.

19.The Committee recommended that the Commonwealth seek a referral of power from the States to deal with the property of parties of de facto relationships. The States, other than Western Australia, have already referred powers in relation to the children of such relationships. The Committee's recommendations are being considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

20.The Committee's forthcoming report on the funding and administration of the Family Court will address major issues for access to justice. However, the Committee has already made some important recommendations on costs. Almost half of the submissions to the Committee referred to the high cost of litigation. The recommendations propose an increased emphasis on ADR. Litigation remains an option of last resort. However, the Government believes there needs to be better means to inform prospective litigants about the total cost of litigation. Individuals will then be able to make an informed choice between ADR and litigation.

21.This is an important issue and needs to be considered in the context of costs for all federal courts and the Attorney-General has therefore asked the Access to Justice Advisory Committee, chaired by Professor Ronald Sackville Q.C., to examine these recommendations.

22.The Government recognises that particular difficulties may arise in dealing with circumstances where there has been family violence. In developing legislation and taking other action to give effect to the recommendations of the Committee as adopted by the Government, such concerns will be appropriately addressed.
1.The Government re-number and re-print the Family Law Act 1975 at the earliest opportunity. (paragraph 1.23)
Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and will implement it after all amendments flowing from the current review of the Act have been made.
2.An administrative review of the Family Court be undertaken. (paragraph 2.46)

Response: The Government notes that the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act is currently reviewing the operation and funding of the Family Court.
3.The review be undertaken by the Joint Select Committee on certain aspects of the operation and interpretation of the Family Law Act. (paragraph 2.46)

Response: The Government notes that the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act is currently reviewing the operation and funding of the Family Court.
4.The Family Court Counselling Service should be sufficiently resourced to enable:
4.1.the demand for self or solicitor referred counselling to be met;
4.2.a reduction in waiting times for all appointments;
4.3.the provision of a limited after hours service in all registries;
4.4.an extension of Family Court visiting services to outlying areas that are currently infrequently serviced; and

4.5.capacity to deal with the full additional case load generated by the enactment of s70BB and s112AD(5), and the reference of powers from the States in relation to ex-nuptial children. (paragraph 3.25)
Response: The Government notes that the appropriate level of service and funding of that service is a matter of competing priorities that needs to be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.
5.The establishment of filing registries and sub-registries where necessary, eg, at Geelong, the Gold Coast, and Coffs Harbour. (paragraph 3.25)

Response: The Government agrees in principle with the recommendation and understands that the Court will soon be in a position to proceed with the Gold Coast registry. The Government recognises, however, that the funding of filing registries of the Court is a matter that needs to be considered by the application of the agreed workload formula.

6.The Family Court Counselling Service review its staffing levels and training program, to ensure that all counsellors have an opportunity to regularly update their knowledge and skills, particularly in the areas of domestic violence and child sexual abuse. (paragraph 3.48)

Response: The Government agrees that counsellors should have the opportunity to regularly update their knowledge and skills but that the funding of the counselling services of the Court is a matter of competing priorities that needs to be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.
7.An interpreter service be provided free of charge where necessary to clients of the Family Court Counselling Service. (paragraph 3.54)

Response: The Government notes that the Family Court was provided in 1992-93 with funds to provide an interpreter service in those cases in which one was required. Any further funding would need to be considered in the Budget context after appropriate evaluation of the interpreter service.
8.The Family Court ensure that counsellors are provided with adequate cross cultural awareness training. (paragraph 3.54)

Response: The Government agrees that counsellors should have adequate cross cultural awareness training but that the funding of the counselling services is a matter of competing priorities that needs to be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

9.The Family Court investigate the most cost effective means of ensuring that parties who file for voluntary pre-filing conciliation counselling under s15(1) of the Family Law Act 1975 and who subsequently fail to notify the counselling service of their intention not to attend, are prevented from using repeat applications for counselling as a means of harassing their ex-partner. (paragraph 3.76)

Response: The Government notes the difficulties created when parties who file for voluntary pre-filing conciliation counselling and subsequently fail to notify the counselling service of their intention not to attend. This issue has been raised with the Chief Justice who is mindful of the need to ensure that parties do not use repeat applications to harass their former partners and has informed the staff of his Court accordingly.

10.All clients ordered to attend conciliation conferences, or reportable conferences for the purpose of family reports, should be offered the option of having separate interviews if domestic violence has occurred in the relationship. (paragraph 3.91)

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that a statement of Family Court policy was issued by the Chief Justice's Direction dated 15 January 1993 which states that provision is to be made for alternate conciliation procedures for parties in fear of violence. The Government understands that these procedures have been implemented in all Family Court registries.

11.The Director of Family Court Counselling take all necessary steps to ensure that the statements of policy included in the Family Court's revised domestic violence policy statement dated May 1992 be translated into consistent practice in all registries. (paragraph 3.90)

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the statement of policy referred to by the Joint Select Committee in this recommendation was in draft form and the matter is now covered by the statement of policy issued by the Chief Justice on 15 January 1993.

12.Detailed fact sheets on the role and nature of various types of counselling offered by the Family Court, with a strong recommendation that clients attend in-house induction sessions, be sent to all couples upon the initial filing of papers seeking dissolution of a marriage. (paragraph 3.97)

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that to an extent the Court is already doing this through the provision of detailed information sessions. The Family Court is currently resourced to disseminate detailed information on the Courts' services.
13.There be increased provision of information sessions in registries and other centres where demand exists. (paragraph 3.97)

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Court is currently extending its program of information sessions, which parties are required to attend, to all Registries. The information sessions form an integral part of the Court's case management system as extended by its proposed simplified procedures. The Court is also exploring the possibility of providing videos of information sessions which will be available to people in remote areas.
14.The Family Court Counselling Service monitor demand for grief, post-decision and post-settlement counselling. (paragraph 3.125)

Response: The Government believes that it is not an appropriate function for the Family Court to provide on-going grief or post-decision or settlement counselling services. Such services should be, and currently are, provided through community agencies, such as the marriage counselling organisations or in public health facilities and the Court's role is at the time of decision. The Family Court may then act as a referral agency to direct people to these services.

15.Sections 61B and 16A(1) of the Family Law Act 1975 be amended to require that the Family Court and legal practitioners direct the attention of clients to the facilities and procedures referred to in those sections. (paragraph 3.125)

Response: Section 61B (a) and 16A (1) require the Family Court, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under the Act and any legal practitioner acting in proceedings to have regard to the need to direct the attention of the parties to the facilities provided by courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act in the area of post decision counselling. As post decision counselling is carried out to a far greater extent in the community (see recommendation 14), the facilities will not exist in these courts to any significant extent although the Family Court may act as a referral agency to direct people to the services provided by community organisations.

16.The Family Court Counselling Service play a more active role in educating its clients as to the availability and potential value of complementary counselling services available within approved marriage counselling and mediation organisations. (paragraph 4.50)

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation but believes that the Family Court Counselling Service should not duplicate, or compete for, services available elsewhere in the community unless there is demonstrable advantage in the Court service being active in that area. The primary responsibility of the Court Services is the provision of counselling related to potential or pending proceedings, and it is valid for the Court service to be active in pre-application proceedings. However, there is a strong argument for referring many cases back to agencies within local communities and for the role of the community-based agencies to be actively promoted by the Court's service. The Court does play an active role in referring clients to other approved marriage counselling and mediation organisations where it is unable to offer the service itself.
17.The Family Court actively promote short term interchange of its counsellors between the Family Court Counselling Service and approved agencies. (paragraph 4.50)

Response: The Government accepts the principle that there should be short-term interchange of counsellors which would provide opportunities for cross-fertilisation of ideas, some standardisation of skills among counsellors and promote inter-agency relations. The Government recognises that the exchange should involve appropriately qualified and experienced persons.
18.Diploma and post-graduate courses in mediation be established as soon as possible in at least one higher education institution in each State. (paragraph 4.59)

Response: The Government agrees that there should be appropriate training for mediators practising in family law and the basis for implementing the recommendation has been referred for the consideration of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The Government notes, however, that educational institutions are free to set their own priorities within their broad teaching profiles and their base level of student load and funding.
19.A diploma, with appropriate practical experience, be required as the base level qualification for mediators. (paragraph 4.59)

Response: The Government agrees mediators practising in family law should be appropriately qualified and the basis for implementing the recommendation has been referred for the consideration of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The Government notes, however, that educational institutions are free to set their own priorities within their broad teaching profiles and their base level of student load and funding

20.Until such courses are established and a sufficient number of graduates have completed the courses, only those organisations that meet standards currently required by government be publicly funded. (paragraph 4.59)
Response: The Government accepts that only those organisations which meet standards set by the Government should be publicly funded.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 21.Sufficient funding be provided to approved marriage counselling organisations to enable the prompt provision of appointments to potential clients, and to improve the accessibility of marriage counselling to those living in rural and remote areas. (paragraph 4.97)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts that counselling services should be resourced to ensure that the appropriate quantity of high quality service is provided and notes that additional funding for counselling services provided by marriage counselling organisations was provided in 1991/92 and in 1992/93 as well as three 008 lines for marriage counselling in remote and rural areas of Queensland, Western Australia and Victoria. Additional funding, including targeted funding for rural and remote areas, will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 22.The Commonwealth Government take steps to raise the awareness of private employers of potential cost-benefits of making available to their employees the use of counselling services. (paragraph 4.97)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts that employers in both the private and public sectors should be aware of the significant costs of family breakdown and the consequent lost productivity. The Government will examine ways to raise the awareness of private employers of potential cost-benefits of making available to their employees the use of counselling services but any funding will need to be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 23.Appropriate steps be taken to promote community understanding, and use of, counselling, mediation and other related services. (paragraph 4.97)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that there should be greater community understanding of counselling, mediation and, following consideration of the most appropriate methods of achieving greater community awareness, will examine ways to ensure the development of appropriate education programs. Proposals for funding will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 24.Appropriate funding be provided for effective community education about counselling and mediation. (paragraph 4.97)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that there should be greater community understanding of counselling, mediation and, following consideration of the most appropriate methods of achieving greater community awareness, will examine ways to ensure the development of appropriate education programs. Proposals for funding will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 25.The Commonwealth Government substantially increase funding for community education in relation to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 25.1. the rights and responsibilities of marriage and parenthood; 25.2. effective parenting; 25.3. communications and dispute resolution skills; and 25.4. anger management. (paragraph 4.97)

Response: The Government accepts that there should be appropriate community education in the areas of marriage, parenthood, communications and dispute resolution skills and anger management. Funding is currently provided for group programs in these areas through the marriage education and family skills training programs and also for some services in the form of group programs conducted by community organisations:
. Pre-marriage education programs attended by about 12% of the target population include the development of relationship, communication and dispute resolution skills;
. The Family Skills Training program ($1.5m in 1993/94) aims to increase effective parenting and improve skills in communication, dispute resolution and anger management.

. Community education in the area of communications and dispute resolution skills and anger management is currently being addressed as part of the curriculum of the pre-marriage education and family skills programs.
Proposals for increased funding of community education will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 26.Particular attention be given to the further development of schools-based education programs which provide basic education in the areas set out in recommendation 24 above. (paragraph 4.97)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts that the earlier the community is exposed to education in the areas of marriage, parenthood, communications and dispute resolution skills and anger management, the greater the likelihood that the incidence of family disputes will be reduced and, when they do occur, be resolved with less emotional and financial cost. The recommendation has been referred for the consideration of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, but matters relating to secondary education are the joint responsibility of Commonwealth and State Governments.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 27.The concept of guardianship be retained in the Family Law Act 1975. (paragraph 5.54)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government is aware of the concern that the current terminology in the Family Law Act in relation to children encourages concepts of ownership and parental "rights" concerning children, when the focus should be towards the best interests of the child. It has given rise to a situation in which many individuals do not fully understand their respective roles as parents after separation. The Government has formed a preliminary view that there should be a move away from guardianship, access and custody terminology to focus on responsibilities of parents rather than their rights, along the lines of the system currently in operation in the United Kingdom.

The Government has asked the Family Law Council to provide further advice on the operation of the Children Act 1989 (UK) to assess whether there is sufficient justification for the adoption of principles embodied in that Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 28.Every order for custody/access made by the Family Court specify the guardianship rights and responsibilities of both parties, and particularly of the non-custodial parent, and the extent of these rights and responsibilities. (paragraph 5.54)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: As noted in the response to recommendation 45, the Government accepts that guardianship responsibilities should be specified, but the Family Court believes this should not be part of the order of the Court. As noted in the response to recommendation 27, the Government has asked the Family Law Council to provide further advice on the operation of the Children Act 1989 (UK) to assess whether there is sufficient justification for the adoption of principles embodied in that Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 29.There be no change to the terminology of the Family Law Act 1975 in relation to custody and access, until such time as there is clear evidence that a change would be advantageous to the settlement of custody and access disputes. (paragraph 5.55)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government has accepted, in principle, the desirability of a move away from the terminology of the Family Law Act 1975 in relation to children and, as noted in the response to recommendation 27, the Government has asked the Family Law Council to provide further advice on the operation of the Children Act 1989 (UK) to assess whether there is sufficient justification for the adoption of principles embodied in that Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 30.The Family Court provide to parties who apply for dissolution of marriage or who initiate proceedings in the Family Court an information leaflet on the meaning of the above terms, the arrangements that may occur in practice and the rights and responsibilities of parties to each other in their parenting role. (paragraph 5.54)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government has accepted, in principle, the desirability of a move away from the terminology of the Family Law Act 1975 in relation to children but accepts the desirability of an information leaflet for those parties with children setting out the responsibilities of parties in their parenting roles. As noted in the response to recommendation 27, the Government has asked the Family Law Council to provide further advice on the operation of the Children Act 1989 (UK) to assess whether there is sufficient justification for the adoption of principles embodied in that Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 31.The Family Court develop a more systematic and intensive program of judicial education in relevant non-legal matters, and particularly in factors, such as domestic violence and child abuse, which can influence the welfare of the child. (paragraph 5.64)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation in principle and notes that it has provided funding for judicial education and any proposals for increased funding will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 32.Judges of the Family Court give clear and adequate reasons for decisions and/or orders made by them in matters relating to children. (paragraph 5.64)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that it reflects the existing situation in which the Family Court has upheld appeals in all cases where reasons are inadequate. The Government also notes that the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration is developing induction courses for new judges, part of which covers the writing of reasons.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 33.Interim custody orders only be made where there are firm grounds for intervention to protect the welfare of the child concerned. (paragraph 5.70)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that it reflects the existing situation. The Government also notes that detailed implementation will depend on the further advice by the Family Law Council on the operation of the Children Act 1989 (UK), as noted in the response to recommendation 27.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 34.Where necessary, the Family Court contract out the preparation of family reports. (paragraph 5.83)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with this recommendation and notes that the Court already contracts out the preparation of a proportion of family reports to appropriately qualified persons.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 35.Organisations and individuals be approved by the Family Court for the preparation of such reports. (paragraph 5.83)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that only properly qualified persons should prepare family reports but notes that under the existing arrangements, the approval of organisations and individuals outside the Court is a function of the Attorney-General. The Government does not propose to change this approval function as it ensures proper scrutiny of those in the community sector who are working in the family law system.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 36.A separate representative for a child be appointed where:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 36.1. there are allegations of child sexual abuse; or 36.2. where, in the opinion of the Family Court, the circumstances of the case are such that the welfare of the child is seriously at risk. (paragraph 5.102)

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that it accords with the usual practice of the Court whereby separate representatives are appointed in child abuse cases. The Government also notes that the Family Law Council is preparing a report on the role of the separate representative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 37.The role of the separate representative be to assist the court in the provision of evidence relevant to the welfare of the child. (paragraph 5.102)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation but notes that the role of the separate representative, as developed in the cases before the Family Court, includes putting the wishes of the child to the Court, making appropriate applications on behalf of the child and adducing evidence relevant to the welfare of the child for the consideration of the Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 38.Information on the existence and purpose of parenting plans be made available to separating parents and professionals in the family law area. (paragraph 6.24)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation in principle and believes it is important for all reforms relating to children be considered together. As noted in recommendation 27, the Government has asked the Family Law Council to provide further advice on the operation of the Children Act 1989 (UK) to assess whether there is sufficient justification for the adoption of principles espoused in that Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 39.The development of a parenting plan should not be a prerequisite to litigation. (paragraph 6.24)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation in principle and, believes it is important for all reforms relating to children be considered together. As noted in recommendation 27, has asked the Family Law Council to provide further advice on the operation of the Children Act 1989 (UK) to assess whether there is sufficient justification for the adoption of principles espoused in that Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 40.A detailed review of the jurisdiction of the Family Court in relation to child welfare be undertaken, with a view to establishing whether the jurisdiction of the Family Court be increased to include wardship and parens patriae powers. (paragraph 6.42)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Family Law Council is conducting an inquiry and, as part of that project, has released a discussion paper about sterilisation and other medical procedures on children, which examines the wardship and parens patriae powers of the Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 41.The review be undertaken by the Family Law Council. (paragraph 6.42)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Family Law Council is conducting an inquiry as detailed in the response to recommendation 40.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 42.No orders be made for the transfer of custody/access to children either inside or outside a police station unless:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 42.1. it has been positively ascertained that the police station is suitably staffed to facilitate such a change-over;
42.2. the officer in charge of that police station agrees to the police station being used as a custody exchange point; and
42.3. a copy of the order has been made available to the officer in charge of the police station at least 48 hours prior to any custody/access change-over. (paragraph 6.58)

Response: The Government does not accept this recommendation. It believes that where the relationship between parents has deteriorated to the point where access handover must be at a police station, the Court will then make appropriate orders in the circumstances of the case. The Government will give consideration to establishing a pilot project to facilitate access handover under appropriate and supervised conditions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 43.When making access orders, or considering applications for variations of those orders, the Family Court should:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 43.1. give consideration to the fairness and capacity of the custodial parent to share the costs and travelling time involved in the exercise of access rights by the non-custodial parent; and
43.2. where appropriate, include a requirement that the custodial parent contribute to such costs and travelling time in its access orders. (paragraph 6.81)
Response: The Government accepts this recommendation but notes that it states the existing law and practice of the Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 44.The Commonwealth Attorney-General request the Family Law Council to broaden its inquiry into repetitive access applications to include:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 44.1. the extent to which breaches occur; 44.2. the incidence of breaches leading to Family Court proceedings; 44.3. the `penalties' imposed; 44.4. the extent to which breaches occur after proceedings for breach of an order have taken place; and
44.5. the adequacy of the range of `sentencing options' available to the Family Court in dealing with such breaches. (paragraph 7.35)
Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Council will undertake the work, but that resource constraints may not permit it to actively pursue this work for some time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 45.The Family Court include in its custody and access orders, information about enforcement procedures, including the availability of the summary enforcement procedure established under Order 34, Rule 9. (paragraph 7.42)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that such information should be readily available and notes that the Court will include this material as an annexure to the order rather than in the order itself.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 46.Information provided by the Family Court, including information provided in its custody and access orders, should make it clear that it is not necessary to engage legal representation in order to make an application for summary enforcement using Form 49. (paragraph 7.42)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that information on summary enforcement should be freely available. The Government also notes that the existing summary enforcement process and the simplification project undertaken by the Court are aimed at making it easier for unrepresented people to prepare and present their cases.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 47.The Family Court investigate the provision of information, including that relating to the summary enforcement procedure, by way of video. (paragraph 7.42)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that the provision of information about summary enforcement could be by video and notes that the Court, as part of its review of procedures, is examining ways to provide information to those parties who come into contact with the Court, including by way of video. However, the provision of such information should be at the appropriate stage of proceedings.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 48.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to provide that in proceedings relating to non-compliance with access orders:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 48.1. proof of reasonable excuse should constitute a defence to a charge under section 70(3); and
48.2. the onus of establishing such reasonable excuse for the denial of access should lie with the respondent. (paragraph 7.47)

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Family Law Act must have sufficient flexibility to deal with the range of factual circumstances with which the Family Court is confronted. The Government recognises the concerns expressed by the National Committee for Violence Against Women, but is confident that this recommendation will not have the effect they fear.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 49.The Family Court Counselling Service continue to place high priority on the provision of early intervention counselling in cases where it appears that access is likely to be a problem. (paragraph 7.58)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that early intervention counselling will improve compliance with orders of the Court and notes that the Court places high priority on early intervention in all cases, subject to resources.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 50.Improved mechanisms for the regular exchange of information and viewpoints between Federal and State police and the Family Court with respect to the enforcement of orders made under Family Law jurisdiction be established. (paragraph 7.84)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that there should be regular exchange of information between Federal and State police and the Family Court with respect to the enforcement of orders made under Family Law jurisdiction and notes that such contact has been established.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 51.The Chief Justice of the Family Court initiate urgent discussions with the Chairman of the Police Commissioner's Advisory Group regarding the establishment of appropriate mechanisms for this purpose. (paragraph 7.84)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that appropriate mechanisms be settled between the Chief Justice of the Family Court and the Chairman of the Police Commissioner's Advisory Group and notes that such contact has been established.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 52.The Commonwealth Attorney-General give consideration to whether any amendment to section 121 of the Family Law Act 1975 is required to enable these recommendations to be implemented. (paragraph 7.84)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and the Attorney-General will examine section 121 of the Family Law Act 1975 to decide if amendments are required.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 53.The Family Court develop a suitable on-line data base, accessible by the Australian Federal Police which will contain up to date records of the contents of orders made under Family Law jurisdiction, both by the Family Court and by magistrate's courts. (paragraph 7.99)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees the existence of a suitable on line database containing up to date records of the contents of Court orders will assist Police, but believes that only those orders that are directed by the Court, of its own motion or at the request of the parties, be put on the system. Any proposals for the funding of such a database will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 54.In order to prevent the disclosure of information contained in the database to unauthorised police personnel, the Australian Federal Police nominate an officer with responsibility for accessing this system and for protecting the confidentiality of the information. (paragraph 7.99)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation but notes that, in accordance with the response to recommendation 53, only those orders that are directed by the Court, of its own motion or at the request of the parties, be put on the system and that any proposals for the funding of such a database will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 55.State police to have access to the specific information required in particular cases through the Australian Federal Police. (paragraph 7.99)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that State police have access to information in particular cases through the Australian Federal Police but notes that, in accordance with the response to recommendation 53, only those orders that are directed by the Court, of its own motion or at the request of the parties, be put on the system and any proposals for the funding of such a database will be considered in the context of the Budget

PARA.EMPHASIS: 56.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to provide that the Family Court make orders empowering police to take temporary custody of a child at the same time as a warrant is issued for the arrest of the party who is unlawfully attempting to take a child out of the country. (paragraph 7.103)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation but notes that any funding implications will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 57.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to empower the Family Court to order:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 57.1. that warrants issued for the arrest of a person who has abducted or attempted the abduction of a child may remain in force for a specified period of time, notwithstanding the execution of the warrant during that period of time; and

57.2. that a police officer, who believes on reasonable grounds, that the person against whom the warrant is directed has taken certain steps in contravention of the relevant order, may arrest the respondent. (paragraph 7.108)

Response: The Government does not accept this recommendation which calls for the issuing of ongoing warrants. But the Government recognises the desirability of meeting the intended aim of this recommendation and will amend the Family Law Act to empower the Family Court to make, at the same time as issuing a warrant for arrest, an order authorising the subsequent arrest without warrant for any attempt to repeat the abduction in the following 12 months. After arrest, the police will bring the person before the Court as soon as practicable.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 58.The Chief Justice issue a practice direction specifying that:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 58.1. penalties for the non-compliance with Family Court orders and injunctions are contained in the Family Law Act 1975;
58.2. such penalties should be used where appropriate in cases of noncompliance with orders and injunctions; and
58.3. such penalties should be consistently applied throughout the Family Court. (paragraph 7.123)

Response: The Government does not accept this recommendation because the purpose of practice directions is to deal with matters of practice and procedure. Practice directions are a matter for the judiciary. Nonetheless, the Government and the Court recognise the need for a consistent approach to these matters and propose that the aims be achieved by other means including their consideration at Judges' Conferences and Judicial Development Seminars.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 59.The Family Law Council conduct a review of penalties applied by the Family Court in cases of non-compliance with orders and injunctions which come before the Family Court. (paragraph 7.123)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the matter has been referred to the Council pursuant to section 115 (3) of the Family Law Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 60.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to clarify what is meant by `personal protection' in sections 70D and 114AA to address situations where the terms of an injunction are breached, but no actual assaults or threats are made. (paragraph 7.133)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Family Law Act will need amendment to require all courts issuing injunctions under the Act to specify when they are issued for the personal protection of a person.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 61.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to ensure police have a power of arrest which is sufficient to enforce the terms of injunctions issued by courts and to restrain the possible non-compliance with the injunction. (paragraph 7.133)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Family Law Act will require amendment to provide police with a power of arrest without warrant where a person harasses or molests another person in breach of an injunction for personal protection issued under the Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 62.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to ensure that those people in breach of injunctions be restrained from committing further breaches of an injunction before being dealt with by the courts for the initial breach. (paragraph 7.133)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with the reasoning behind this recommendation but notes that injunctions do not need to be renewed to prevent further breaches. The Government also notes that the Family Law Act will require amendment to clarify the operation of section 114AA especially for events occurring on weekends and public holidays

PARA.EMPHASIS: 63.The Commonwealth Government take urgent steps towards:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 63.1. the implementation of the Standing Committee of Attorneys'-General resolution regarding portability of domestic violence orders; and
