63.2. the extension of the jurisdiction of the Family Court to include State/Territory domestic violence legislation where parties to proceedings are also parties to proceedings under State/Territory domestic violence legislation. (paragraph 7.141)

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that there is no legislation required of the Commonwealth but that most states and territories have introduced portability legislation. The Government is also working in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General with the states and territories to ensure greater consistency between domestic violence orders and orders of the Family Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 64.The Court make the necessary amendments to the Family Law Rules to enable the issue of warrants under section 34(2) of the Family Law Act 1975. (paragraph 7.154)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with the intention of this recommendation and notes that amendment of the Family Law Rules is a matter for the Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 65.The Commonwealth Attorney-General initiate discussions with the States to amend State legislation which affects the enforcement of financial and property orders to include warrants issued by the Family Court. (paragraph 7.154)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the matter will require the agreement of the states and territories.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 66.A practice direction be issued by the Chief Justice of the Family Court stating that maintenance orders for maintenance which has been unpaid for over twelve months should be enforced according to the relevant provisions of the Family Law Act 1975. (Paragraph 7.154)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government notes that legislation may be required to replace the common law rule of non-enforcement of maintenance which has been unpaid for over twelve months. However, the purpose of practice directions is to deal with matters of practice and procedure and practice directions are a matter for the judiciary.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 67.Sections 107 and 112 AB of the Family Law Act 1975 be amended to remove restrictions upon the imposition of imprisonment for non-payment of maintenance where payment has been wilfully or fraudulently withheld. (paragraph 7.154)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that the use of imprisonment should be available for non-payment of maintenance but only be a last resort and then only for wilful and/or fraudulent non-payment of maintenance. The Government will examine section 107 and 112AB to determine what amendments are required.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 68.The Commonwealth Attorney-General examine the operation of existing mechanisms for the investigation and prosecution of perjury cases. (paragraph 7.159)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation. The present mechanism for the prosecution of perjury arises out of consultation with the Director of Public Prosecution and he will be involved with the Attorney-General's Department in a re-examination of that mechanism. The re-examination will also consider the need to create a separate offence of intentionally failing to disclose assets.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 69.The Family Court examine means of raising client awareness of the penalties for perjury, and of the options available to parties who believe that an offence has been committed. (paragraph 7.159)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees that it is important that there be an awareness of the penalties for perjury and will consider the best ways to achieve this awareness. Any proposals for funding will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 70. The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to combine relevant matters to be taken into account under Section 75(2) and Section 79(4) for the purposes of alteration of property interests.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and proposes that it be effected by amendments to the Family Law Act 1975.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 71.Equality of sharing should be the starting point in the allocation of matrimonial property.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation. Under the proposals the equality of sharing will recognise the equality of contribution in the relationship and the acquisition and preservation of matrimonial property. It proposes that it be effected by amendments to the Family Law Act l975.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 72.Where a prenuptial or subsequent financial agreement exists, that agreement should be the starting point.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts the principle of this recommendation. Where such an agreement exists the initial decision, as noted in recommendation 90, will be whether to give effect to that agreement, including to decide whether it should be set aside for fraud and duress. If effect is given to the agreement then property covered by the agreement will not constitute matrimonial property to which the equality of sharing provisions apply. It proposes that it be effected by amendments to the Family Law Act 1975.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 73.Courts should have a discretion to depart from the equality of sharing principle to take account of exceptional circumstances.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation in part and that the exercise of the discretion be governed by the circumstances set out in Recommendation 74. It proposes that it be effected by amendments to the Family Law Act 1975.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 74. Matters to be taken into account in exercising a discretion may include but should not be limited to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 74.1 the length of the marriage; 74.2 the care and control of children; 74.3 obligations incurred under the child support legislation; 74.4 the future needs of each spouse; 74.5 the financial impact on each of the parties; 74.6 the property brought into the marriage; 74.7 the home making and child rearing contribution; and 74.8 the financial contribution by each person.

Response: The Government accepts this recommendation in principle. Consideration will be given to whether any other factors should be taken into account. It proposes that the change be effected by amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 .

PARA.EMPHASIS: 75.To the extent possible within constitutional power, the Family Law Act 1975 be amended to include superannuation entitlements as property. (paragraph 9.62)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government does not accept this recommendation. Provision will be made for splitting the entitlement to superannuation of a contributing spouse as follows:
. superannuation will be dealt with as a separate and discrete asset;
. the asset will be distributed between the parties, upon breakdown of marriage, equitably by operation of law;
. the apportionment of the entitlement will be effected by reference to the period of cohabitation and the period of contribution to the fund; and
. the proposal is to be consistent with the retirement incomes policy.
A governmental working group will be established to develop a scheme within these parameters.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 76.As a general rule, at the discretion of the court, the notional realisable value of the superannuation entitlement be the value to be taken into account at the time of the hearing. (paragraph 9.62)

PROCTEXT.PARA: 77.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to empower the Family Court to order that a superannuation entitlement be split and shared between the contributing and non-contributing spouse. (paragraph 9.62)
78.The entitlement be shared between the parties in proportion equal to the length of the marriage or cohabitation by reference to the total period of contribution to the fund. (paragraph 9.62)
79.The power to divide the superannuation entitlement be discretionary and not automatic in all cases. (paragraph 9.62)
80.A court order, either a consent order or otherwise, be required to direct the trustee of a superannuation fund to divide the entitlement. (paragraph 9.62)
81.The divided funds be portable between a similar superannuation scheme or approved deposit fund. (paragraph 9.62)
82.If the above recommendations are not achievable, the notional realisable value to be introduced in legislation as the approach to value superannuation entitlements. (paragraph 9.62)

83.In the event of the notional realisable value approach being introduced in legislation the court to be empowered to have a discretion to depart from this approach where it would result in an injustice or inequity. (paragraph 9.62)
Response: See response to recommendation 75.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 84.There be no amendment to the Family Law Act 1975 in respect of de facto relationships. (paragraph 10.72)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: This recommendation is accepted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 85.The Commonwealth Government seek a reference of powers from the States in relation to the jurisdiction of de facto property disputes. (paragraph 10.72)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: This recommendation is accepted. This recommendation is already under consideration by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 86.The Commonwealth Government legislate separately in relation to jurisdiction in property disputes between de facto partners. (paragraph 10.72)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: This recommendation is accepted in principle, subject to appropriate references of powers from the States.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 87.The jurisdiction of this Act be vested in the Family Court. (Paragraph 10.72)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: This recommendation is accepted in principle, subject to appropriate references of powers from the States

PARA.EMPHASIS: 88.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to distinguish farming properties from other matrimonial property so that the Family Court, in addition to other matters, is able to consider the following: 88.1. whether the farming property was brought into the marriage by one or other party or whether it was acquired by both parties and developed after the marriage; 88.1.1. the necessity for the retention of a farming property as an income producing unit for the future needs of the separating family (paragraph 11.51)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: This recommendation is not accepted. Instead the Government proposes that one of the issues to be taken into account when sharing property is the need to retain any property or business as a functional unit.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 89.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to include the above factors as matters to be taken into account by the Family Court in making orders with respect to farming properties. (paragraph 11.51)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: This recommendation is not accepted. Instead the Government proposes that one of the issues to be taken into account when sharing property is the need to retain any property or business as a functional unit.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 90.Financial agreements be legally recognised and enforceable in the courts under the Family Law Act 1975.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and proposes that it be effected by amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 . As noted in the response to recommendation 72, financial agreements would be the starting point in property matters, but in contested cases, the Court will examine those agreements to be satisfied that they were not entered into by reason of fraud or duress

PARA.EMPHASIS: 91.Such financial agreements be in writing, signed by both parties and witnessed by independent persons.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 92.Pre- and post-marital financial agreements to contain a registration of assets and liabilities of both parties.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 93.Pre- and post-marital financial agreements to include provision for the variation of the agreement.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation, subject to such variation not resulting from fraud or duress on one of the parties.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 94.The ability to amend the register of assets to include gifts received by either party after the marriage be available.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 95.It be possible for parties to enter into such financial agreements at any time prior to or during their marriage.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 96.A standard agreement of sufficient flexibility be developed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation in principle. Provision will be made in regulations for the outline of such standard agreement.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 97.The courts have a residual discretion to intervene, notwithstanding the existence of a financial agreement, where the circumstances of the parties have so changed since the time the agreement was entered into that it would lead to serious injustice if the provisions of the agreement were to be enforced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 98.The pleadings system be abolished by the Family Court. (paragraph 13.48)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Family Court has already decided to abolish pleadings.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 99.The Family Court introduce a summary procedure for simpler matters. (paragraph 13.48)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation but notes that procedure is governed by the Court Rules which are developed by the Court in consultation with the profession and are subject to disallowance by the Parliament only. The Government also notes that the Court has already moved to introduce summary procedures in simpler matters as part of its simplification project.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 100.The provisions of the Courts (Mediation and Arbitration) Act 1991 be expanded to encourage and implement the development of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms, not within the existing adversarial system but as realistic alternatives available at any time. (paragraph 13.73)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation, and believes that its implementation will represent the most significant change of approach to the family law system since the introduction of no fault divorce in the original Family Law Act in 1975. It will shift the current emphasis on litigation to non-adversarial dispute resolution mechanisms where partners agree solutions, not have them imposed. Additional funding to ensure provision of realistic alternatives will be considered in the context of the 1994-95 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 101.Agreements made between parties using the alternative dispute resolution processes not to be subject to scrutiny or approval of the courts, prior to signature by the parties. (paragraph 13.73)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation in principle. However, provision will be made for a short "cooling off period" to enable a party to consider whether the agreement should operate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 102.The legislation provide for the review by the Family Court of any agreement reached between the parties in the event that there is a dispute in relation to agreements reached, such review to be subject to a time limit. (paragraph 13.73)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government does not accept this recommendation. It considers that the function of the Court should be to interpret and enforce, and where a mediated agreement breaks down the court may need to make orders for settling matters between the parties.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 103.The Family Court of Australia and the legal profession take an active role in identifying matters which may be more suitable for resolution by alternative dispute mechanisms. (paragraph 13.73)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with the principle of this recommendation and notes that it is desirable for matters to be settled by mediation and other forms of ADR. The Government also notes that the Court is actively pursuing alternative dispute mechanisms.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 104.As part of a move towards less formal proceedings, that the wearing of wigs and gowns be discontinued in the Family Court of Australia. (paragraph 13.77)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government does not accept this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 105.Written material on processes and procedures of the Family Court be available for those people who wish to represent themselves. (paragraph 13.86)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with the intention of this recommendation and notes that Legal Aid Commissions provide some of this material.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 106.The Family Court nominate, at each of its registries, an officer of the court to whom people can be referred for information. (paragraph 13.86)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with the intention of this recommendation and notes that the Family Court already has officers to whom people can be referred. The Government also notes that the Court is developing the concept of centralised information units.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 107.Having regard to the introduction of simplified procedures in the Family Court a new costing system be developed, structured on an event basis, similar to the previous system of basic composite amounts. (paragraph 14.42)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government has referred this recommendation to the Access to Justice Committee chaired by Professor Ronald Sackville.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 108.Cost orders to be made more often especially where one party unnecessarily forces the other party to incur legal costs, such orders to include an award for fee reimbursement of those costs unnecessarily incurred. (paragraph 14.47)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government has referred this recommendation to the Access to Justice Committee chaired by Professor Ronald Sackville.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 109.Cost orders against parties who have not complied with court directions or who have not been ready to proceed when required to be used more vigorously. (paragraph 14.47)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government has referred this recommendation to the Access to Justice Committee chaired by Professor Ronald Sackville.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 110.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to enable judges to make Rules of Court in relation to trial management. (paragraph 14.54)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 111.The Family Law Act 1975 be amended to provide that in exercising its rulemaking powers, the Family Court must have regard to the impact new rules will have on the cost to the parties, and to the effectiveness of the Family Court providing services which are accessible, affordable and understandable to the general public. (paragraph 14.54)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation and notes that this is Court policy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 112.Cost agreements be retained with an amendment to the Family Law Rules to the effect that, in order to protect litigants, in addition to existing requirements, cost agreements contain a certificate from a solicitor that the agreement has been entered into freely and voluntarily. (paragraph 14.67)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government has referred this recommendation to the Access to Justice Committee chaired by Professor Ronald Sackville.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 113.In order for a cost agreement to be enforceable, a copy of a cost agreement is to be filed in the Family Court when an application initiating proceedings is filed. (paragraph 14.67)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government has referred this recommendation to the Access to Justice Committee chaired by Professor Ronald Sackville.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 114.Given the limitations on legal aid, legal practitioners be encouraged to provide pro-bono work on a regular basis. (paragraph 14.70)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with the intention of this recommendation. The Government notes that legal practitioners presently, from time to time, undertake pro-bono family law work.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 115.There be no change in the current policy relating to the publication of proceedings in the Family Court.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 116. Section 121 of the Family Law Act 1975 be rewritten so that the intention of Parliament, ie to permit publication but without permitting any identification of parties, is clear.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 117.Section 121 (3) of the Family Law Act 1975, which specifies the particulars which may identify a person, in particular be amended and perhaps rewritten in more general terms.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation

PARA.EMPHASIS: 118.The Family Court use its media liaison personnel to promote the reporting of family court proceedings in the public interest. (paragraph 15.34)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with the intention of this recommendation, and notes that the Family Court is already doing this.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 119.The scope of publicity orders made under section 121 (9) of the Family Law Act 1975 for the purposes of locating children who have been abducted, be limited to the release of relevant information only and for the purposes of assisting to locate the children. (paragraph 15.38)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government accepts this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 120.The Family Court publicity order, as part of the order, state when the publicity order is to cease to have effect and in any case to cease to have effect once the child or children have been located. (paragraph 15.38)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Response: The Government agrees with the intention of this recommendation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This response from the Attorney-General is long awaited and, more importantly, very welcome. The response from the government is a vindication of the very hard work that members of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act 1975 put into the development of the report which was presented to the parliament in November 1992.

PARA.TAB: There were some concerns—some of which were expressed in this place—about the delay in the response. Concerns about the delay were expressed to me by my constituents in Western Australia, and also from many friends around Australia that we met during the course of this inquiry. I think the content of the government's response justifies the delay.

It would be fair to say that, in general, the government has accepted the major recommendations of the joint select committee on this very important and crucial issue to so many Australians. It is worth noting that one-third of all marriages and relationships in this country break up at some time or other. That is an indication of the numbers of people who are affected by the federal Family Law Act and by the Western Australia Family Law Act, which runs hand-in-glove with the federal act. The two acts can be taken together on some important issues.

In making the generalised statement that the government has accepted the report of the joint select committee, I point out that obviously there are areas included in the response where the government has not completely affirmed everything that the committee has recommended. That in itself is a test of the measures that the government has used to examine the recommendations that the committee put to it.

Some of the delay in the response has been caused by the intrusion of the federal election, and the subsequent delay in the appointment of a person to the position of Attorney-General. But, more importantly, one of the reasons for the delay was the consultative processes that the government undertook in testing the committee's recommendations to see whether they would be workable and worthwhile. Those tests were undertaken by a broad range of interested and informed bodies and gave the lead to the government on what it should do with this report.

Since the government's response was tabled in the other place in December we have had a chance to read it and digest its contents. It has also been subjected to some very deep analysis in the Australian media. I am pleased to record that, generally speaking, that analysis has come out in favour of the government's response to the committee's report. In his press statement that accompanied the document, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) said on 16 December that the government had initiated the most far-reaching reform processes in family law since the current act's introduction in 1975. I accept that statement. I think what the government is putting forward is ground-breaking. I wish the Attorney-General—together with his parliamentary secretary, the members of cabinet and other persons who will be involved in the process—well in delivering on the promises and the commitments that have been made in this very important document.

At the conclusion of my short contribution I have a minor criticism to make on aspects of the committee's report and the government's response. However, I briefly want to highlight some of the major features in the government's response. In regard to mediation and other forms of alternate dispute resolution the government has accepted that the system that is in place today is complex, costly and focuses too narrowly on traditional litigation. Obviously, the committee made a number of recommendations in this area, and I am very pleased to see that the government has accepted the main thrust of the committee's recommendations.

In saying that the system is complex, costly and focuses too narrowly on traditional litigation, we are not saying that it must be like that for every person whose relationship breaks up. There are ways and means in the system as it currently stands whereby people can avoid getting into complexities and the cost of litigation. But unfortunately the system sometimes drags people along. Hopefully, the new systems that will be put in place because of the government's response to the committee's report will inform people early in the piece that there are alternatives to what is happening at the moment.

The committee was critical of some aspects of the guardianship, custody and access arrangements. It is pleasing to see that the government has accepted the committee's recommendations, particularly on the enforcement of access orders. There is some criticism from a certain section of the community that the law as it currently operates in this country is perhaps biased in favour of one gender as opposed to the other. They are difficult accusations to defend, particularly when we examine the reality of what happens in the courts. We only have to look at the number of mothers of children who block access and who have been penalised because they have forcibly blocked access.

The equity of the sharing of matrimonial property, farming properties and financial agreements is another area where I welcome the government's response, although I accept that the government has not acceded to all of the committee's recommendations. We did make a specific recommendation on farming properties which the government was not inclined to accept at this stage. I think my colleague Senator Brownhill will have more to say on that. But, overall, our major thrust in getting equality of sharing in the event of a breakdown of a relationship would bring some certainty to the situation.

The government has taken the committee's recommendation on superannuation even further. I am pleased that that has happened because this is a very complex area and was one of the inadequate areas of the report. The question of property settlement is already in hand through the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Access to justice is linked with the mediation and other forms of alternate dispute resolution. Access to justice is very important and I hope it will be delivered.

My criticism deals with the committee itself as it currently operates. We had a further ongoing reference to look at the funding and administration of the family court. A number of the responses by the government to the recommendations contained in the report concern budgetary measures, and the government says that there cannot be a commitment because of budgetary controls. Some of the responses will be subject to what the committee might come up with in its ongoing investigations. Because of the work that the current committee is doing on the child support scheme, this other reference has been put to one side. I intended to raise the matter had the committee been meeting today. I will be pursuing it at some time in the future. Overall, I thank the Attorney-General and his parliamentary secretary for the work that has been put into the government's response to the report of the committee of which I was very proud to be a member.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, over the recess period, on 8 January, just 36 hours after it had first been diagnosed, a massive brain tumour led to the death of my staff member, Rob Jones, at the very young age of 42 years. Rob's death came as a terrible shock to everyone who knew him and loved him.

PARA.TAB: I think just about everyone in this place did know him as a result of the time he spent here as Parliamentary Liaison Officer from 1990 to 1992, and then again from March last year until January as the member of my staff primarily responsible for parliamentary and Senate liaison matters. I also think it is very fair to say that everyone who knew Rob had the most enormous personal affection for him because he was, from any point of view, a thoroughly lovable human being.

That affection and that respect were very much put beyond doubt by the attendance at his funeral on 11 January of people from right across all the parties in this chamber, notwithstanding, in many instances, very significant personal inconvenience in getting there. Amongst those from my side was John Faulkner, the Manager of Government Business; from the Opposition, Robert Hill and Margaret Reid; from the Democrats, Cheryl Kernot and Vicki Bourne; and Brian Harradine, Independent. That, I know, was greatly appreciated by his family, representing as it did an enormous measure of respect for the man.

Rob served his country wonderfully well: as a diplomat in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for a number of years; as a senior official in the international government division of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet; and in the parliamentary role that I have mentioned.

In addition to his career of public service, Rob was a marvellous and caring husband to Sally, his wife of 14 years, and a terrific father to his three young children—Matthew, aged nine; Christopher, aged six; and Simon, aged just five. He is also survived by his mother, Esther, two brothers and a sister.

Rob and his family had already been through one horribly stressful period three years ago when he fought, and to all apparent intents fought off, a diagnosis of cancer, to the delight and relief of everyone who knew him. That reprieve, unhappily, was not to be permanent. I simply cannot say how much distress that has caused all of us who knew and worked with him. I simply cannot say how much sadness we feel for Sally and the kids, and for the rest of the family, in their bereavement.

Unhappily, I was overseas at the time of Rob's death and could not be back in time to be present for his funeral, but I did try to convey something of what I felt about Rob in a letter that I wrote to Sally, his wife, immediately after his death, which was read out at the funeral. Perhaps I can read that now into the lasting record of Hansard as my own tribute to him. I said this:

Rob's death has come as a devastating shock to all of us who worked with him. He was unquestionably one of the nicest and most decent characters I have ever been privileged to know, regarded with enormous affection and respect by the legion of people inside and outside Parliament House with whom he had to deal.

Rob was unfailingly courteous and good humoured in coping with even the most intractable and intransigent of Senate backsliders, not to mention the most demanding of Ministers—and he was unfailingly well informed, thoughtful and creative on policy issues. Dealing as Senate leader with difficult situations, I often used Rob as my secret personal weapon: his extraordinary personal popularity around the House and his capacity to defuse all sorts of complicated problems made him someone on whom I came to rely enormously. I just cannot yet believe that come February 1st, that great lanky streak of amiability will not be there to tell me in his own infuriatingly imperturbable way about the latest twist in some plot with Cheryl and Vicki, or the latest preoccupation of Brian H, or the latest press conference of the Greens . . .

Both while working for me and in his earlier period as parliamentary liaison officer, he made heroic efforts to get the Senate to deal more effectively with its program and to an extraordinary extent, given the Herculean improbability of the aspiration, he succeeded. Although ill at the time of most of the debate itself, Rob made a particularly important contribution to the task of managing the Mabo legislation through the Senate, and I hope that will constitute at least one lasting memorial to his contribution to the public life of this country.

Rob Jones was one of those people whose absence just leaves a gaping, aching hole. He was a uniquely delightful human being—no one can take his place in our hearts or minds. I know that nothing I or anyone else could say could begin to console you and the kids for the pain and loss you are now feeling. All I can say is that my heart, and Merran's, and the hearts of everyone in the office go out to you all.

As much as I would dearly like to be there on Tuesday to do honour to Rob's life and to tell you and the family personally something of what I felt for him, I'm afraid that it simply will not be possible for me to come back from overseas. But I will be grieving then for Rob, as I am now, and as we all are. And we will all go on grieving for him for a long, long time yet to come.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to use this occasion to not only offer condolences to Rob Jones's widow, Sally, and his family but also put on the record what a fine person we found him to be and how much we appreciated the help that he gave us on this side of the chamber during his years in the difficult job of parliamentary liaison officer. I, together with Margaret Reid, was pleased to be able to tell his wife personally at the funeral how highly we regarded Rob and how sad we were at his premature passing.

PARA.TAB: I guess what I remember most is his sense of humour, the incredible spirit of goodwill, no matter how difficult the issue or how difficult the senator or senators he happened to be dealing with at the time and no matter what side of the chamber or party they came from, and also the patience with which he continually dealt with us in these varying difficult matters. I think that Senator Evans's description of a `uniquely delightful individual' is very apt and his loss will be mourned for a long time.

It was also interesting at the funeral—funerals are not generally interesting—to learn what a substantial career he had been making within the Public Service in a wide range of areas. With the experience of this parliament and no doubt the experience in Senator Evans's office, which would have been somewhat trying, as I think the minister has already acknowledged, I have no doubt that he would have risen to the highest levels of the Public Service in this country and that the substantial contribution that he had already made to public life would have been only the start of what he would have contributed had he been allowed a reasonable lifespan.

He was a fine person and we are all saddened by his death. We send our condolences to Sally and his family and at least they have now had reinforced in their minds—and I think will benefit from that—the fact that he was so well regarded and appreciated by so many people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still cannot believe that Rob has died. I still cannot believe that I cannot ring him up in a minute and have a chat or that he will not be popping around for a drink any more. He was only 42, with a very loving wife and three young boys. It cannot have been easy working for Gareth, but he loved that work and was very good at it, as has been said this evening. He was six foot five inches of always very calm, witty, charming and very funny humanity. I was very deeply shocked and distressed to hear about Rob's death.

PARA.TAB: The parliament was genuinely enhanced by his presence and his loss is a grave loss to all of us. He was a good friend. He was a wonderful source of advice and guidance. He was well known for his scrupulous honesty and for his straightforward style and trustworthiness. Rob's intelligence and high intellectual standards, his thorough knowledge of the workings of parliament—and indeed of the bureaucracy as a whole—and his calm, sensible and thoroughly charming manner were enormous assets to Australia. On behalf of all the Australian Democrat senators and staff, I send our most sincere condolences to his wife, Sally, and to his three boys, Matthew, Christopher and Simon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, share the sorrow of this occasion and remember Rob Jones and the contribution he made to this chamber and to this place. I would like to share my first impression of him, which is such an endearing one. I do so not out of any light-heartedness but simply because it demonstrates the kind of presence he had. On our very first day in the Senate, with all our raw inexperience, we were determined to meet all the different community groups. We had a whole string of appointments. My receptionist came in and said, `The PLO is outside. Do you want to see them?' I said, `Yes. We see everybody, don't we?'. We were all set to see a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organisation when in walked an enormous man with his head shaved—because he had been away for a year having cancer treatment. He seemed so gentle and lovely that I felt totally at ease.

PARA.TAB: It took quite a while before it registered that he was introducing himself as the Parliamentary Liaison Officer. We did not share that joke with Rob until a year later when George Thompson came to see us and we had met representatives of the PLO on many occasions. It will always stay in our minds as the first time we met him. I want to express how grateful we in my office are for the wonderful way in which Rob went out of his way to keep us informed in those early days when we knew nothing. I can only support the remarks that have already been made about his integrity and honesty, and his extreme helpfulness and fairness to all people, no matter what party they belonged to or what issue they happened to be squabbling about or debating at the time.

We were very pleased for him when he was able to join Gareth's staff as the principal adviser. We felt it was a recognition of his gifts and his intellectual ability. So we were thrilled for him, though sad to see him leave the position where he had been so helpful. He was always available, even when he was in that later position, when there were queries and matters where he could be of any assistance. He was always extremely helpful to all my staff. Senator Margetts knew him less well than I did because he had moved to that position before she knew him, but both of us want to mention how much we admired and respected him in his role.

I pass on the condolences of former Senator Jo Vallentine. She knew him longer than we did and she was fond of him and respected him, both in his parliamentary role and as a person. Many honourable senators knew him better than I did and knew him as a personal friend, but I want to express with all honourable senators tonight my most sincere condolences to his wife and children and share in the terrible sadness of this tragic loss.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to repeat everything that everyone else has said. Rob Jones was the PLO from 1990. He took ill in 1991 and John Croswell took his place at that stage. He returned to duty in 1992 and later after the election joined Senator Gareth Evans's office.

PARA.TAB: Rob was a great person. As the whip, I was lucky to get to know Rob not only from a work point of view but also from a very personal point of view. Rob was always available to give advice to or assist my office staff. I believe he gave the same advice and help to other whips in this place.

During the time that followed his appointment in 1990, I met with Rob every sitting day. I met with him before the daily whips' meeting. Following my meeting he would attend the whips' meeting where his advice was sought and always given.

Added to his great professionalism was the warmth of his friendship. Rob's personality showed through whenever one met him, whether it was at a meeting, in the passageway or in the chamber. Even after he became ill in 1991 and after treatment when he came to the house, he showed the same happy personality.

If one were to judge from his attitude, one would be forgiven for thinking that he was 100 per cent fit. I believe this attitude stayed with Rob right through his problems. I believe it took a superhuman effort for him to come back to this place after his first lot of treatment. It took an extra superhuman effort to join Senator Gareth Evans's staff.

Rob again proved to be of great value not only to Senator Gareth Evans but also to the new PLO, George Thompson. His experience as PLO gave him a great insight into the working of this place. I believe the insight that he had into the workings of this place was of great value particularly when working with Senator Gareth Evans.

I must tell the story about question time in this place and Senator Gareth Evans. Senator Evans would arrive back in the country and then come in for question time the same day. Question time would be a great bustle for everyone. We would be trying to get questions and answers and there would be a lot of things happening around the chamber. Rob would be sitting in the advisers' box. I walked over to Rob and said, `Do you think we should send him overseas again?' I must say that he was very loyal. He never answered but he gave me a look that made me believe that he thought we should send him overseas again.

I remember the night that the native title bill went through this place. Rob came into the chamber just before the final vote. I said to him, `You don't look well, old mate'. He said, `I'm okay'. Then I remember him later at the celebrations we had and one would not have known that anything was amiss with Rob at that stage.
To his wife Sally and his three small sons I give my deepest sympathy. Rob will be terribly missed in this place and outside.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to miss Rob in lots of ways but particularly when I look across the chamber to the advisers' box. Rob and I had a sort of secret thing going. I would look across and with my eyes ask him, `How are you?', and he would nod back to me, `I'm fine', and smile and give me a wink. I do not think it is breaking confidences to say that our relationship was special. About three years ago I saw Rob limping down the corridor—it was just a slight limp. I have been reared with physiotherapists for a number of years at Lincoln Institute and they make one develop a clinical eye. I had said to him, `You're awfully long and tall and you ought not be limping like that. Is there something wrong?'. He said, `I've just got a bit of a sore back'. I said, `Well, you should have something done about it', and left it at that.

PARA.TAB: After Christmas he was still limping and I said to him, `You know, you're still limping. You ought to have something done about that back. You ought to go out to the Institute of Sport and have the physio look at it.' Rob did go out there, the physio looked at it and unfortunately after a week of treatment he was advised to see a specialist. Rob saw a specialist and the message he got was not good.

From that moment on Rob would ring me each time he had had some form of treatment or a CAT scan to tell me how he was getting on. Whether we were here in the house or whether I was in Melbourne, he would make sure he found out where I was and give me a bulletin. I was excited each time he rang and said, `My CAT scan's clear'. One of the things he kept saying to me each time he had a clear CAT scan was, `It means I'll have that much longer with my family'. He said, `There is no guarantee, of course, when it is clear that that will mean that I am going to live'. We know that our time is limited here but he knew that more keenly because he had had that warning.

I suppose that is why that relationship for me was special and the fact that he made sure that I knew how he was going. The important thing for him was that his sons would remember him. I guess the boys might read Hansard when they grow up. I do not think many people read Hansard—but I am sure they will. The greatest compliment they could be paid, I believe, is to be told that they have grown up to be men like their father, a man of integrity, a man with a tremendous sense of humour, a man with great courage and a person who had a great love for his family. I would like to convey my condolences to Sally and to the boys.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is really an extraordinary adjournment debate this evening. Obviously the life of Rob Jones has touched very deeply a lot of people around this chamber. The extraordinary nature of this debate is a measure of the extraordinary character of this unique human being. After all, he only came on the scene in 1990 and in all he was working in and around Parliament House for about 2 1/2 years—that is taking into account the period that he was off on sick leave fighting the cancer.

PARA.TAB: He certainly touched the lives of a lot of people in this chamber and in this parliament. I take this opportunity to thank Senator Evans for the thoughtfulness of his own staff. When I was telephoned about Rob's death I was shocked, as Senator Bourne said she was. It was as though a member of the family had gone. That, on reflection, is quite extraordinary. Here is an officer of the Public Service who has suddenly found his way into the hearts of a lot of people around the place. I guess for a number of us it is not very easy to find that track, but certainly Rob Jones did.

I will not go on because most of the things that I would have liked to have said have been said. I am sure that the last thing Rob would have wanted would be for us to delay everybody by having a long adjournment debate. I can visualise Rob there in that advisers' box on the night the Mabo legislation passed. He looked pale and I do not think he had a tie on. I was a bit surprised. I said to him the next day that I hoped he would have a good break over the Christmas period.

He was a marvellous character. He had a very special gift and I believe that that special gift was this: when he was speaking to you your problem, notwithstanding all of the others matters that he must have had on his mind—not least of which might have been his health—was the only problem that appeared to interest him. That is a marvellous gift. He had that gift and we had every confidence in him.

We also respected the fact that he had a loyalty to whoever was his employer at any particular time. He had the ability and the integrity to recognise the need for that loyalty and also to deal with your particular problem or the issue that was the subject of the discussion in a very effective manner, bringing to bear his great intellect on the problem.

People have mentioned his humour. It was a bright time when he came into the office, frequently, as a PLO. We enjoyed those times. I never heard him complain once—and that is saying something. We all have a bit of a grouch every now and again, but I never heard Rob Jones complain once. I will certainly remember him and do remember him. He is a person whom his family can be very proud of. Finally, I would like to extend my condolences to his wife, Sally; his sons Matthew—who although only nine is five foot something—Christopher and Simon; and to his mother, his brothers and his sister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a very sad day today to look at the advisers' box when Rob Jones was not there. It is most appropriate that the front seats are empty today.

PARA.TAB: I was Manager of Government Business in the Senate when Rob Jones entered this place as parliamentary liaison officer. He was one of the few people, outside my own staff, who could walk into my office without so much as announcing himself. He had established that sort of relationship. As I was Manager of Government Business, Rob would be in my office four, six, 10 or 15 times a day, which is one of the reasons why I got rid of the job as quickly as I could to Senator McMullan!

In that time Rob very quickly mastered his brief on how this chamber ran. I remember that on his first round of consultation to stitch up something he left Senator Harradine off the list. Senator Harradine quickly reminded us all in the chamber of that, and I do not think Rob ever did it again—I do not think he was ever guilty of leaving Senator Harradine off the visit list for some particular issue.

In combination with me, Rob had to do some things that not everyone in the chamber liked—guillotining 62 bills through in four days would normally create hostility in the opposition—but he did it with such humour and grace that no-one bore any malice for it because they realised he was doing his job and following my orders, I guess.

Part way through his term as parliamentary liaison officer he came to see me to say how ill he was. Senator Patterson has described that today. He went through a fairly horrendous period of treatment and within a day or two of that he called back into my office just to say hello. He dealt with those circumstances with such courage and fortitude. I would have been full of self pity, full of fear and generally thinking that the world had done me badly. I never once heard him say anything of that sort. He always remained optimistic and positive.

It was with great delight that we learnt that Rob would be returning first to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet for a while and then to the parliamentary liaison job. When I had left the job of Manager of Government Business, he was of great assistance to Senator McMullan; I know that.

Following the last election, we had the normal ministerial ballot. When that was over, he dropped into my office and said, `What do you think I should do? I wouldn't mind staying here. I have made so many friends in Parliament House. I would love to work here'. I gave him some advice. I said, `There are 50 vacant jobs at the moment. In half an hour there will be none'. He said, `What should I do?' I said, `Gareth is throwing a celebration party. He has just been elected leader. There will be plenty of people down there. Why don't you go down and nose around and see what jobs are available?'. Exactly two minutes later he rang me to say that he was working for Gareth. Gareth did not let any grass grow under his feet in employing Rob Jones because he appreciated his abilities. Again, when Gareth was away it was Rob Jones's responsibility to brief me on Gareth's behalf on particular issues. He continued to do that. He really enjoyed his job there; there is no doubt about that.

Senator Patterson said something that I would have liked to have said. I am glad that we have had this opportunity tonight because, as time goes on, his young kids will start to wonder what qualities their dad had. I hope that they can read the remarks tonight and get some idea that their father was a very special person.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to associate myself with the remarks about Rob Jones that have been made tonight. It is amazing to hear so many senators speaking in exactly the same way about one individual who, as Senator Harradine said, was here such a short space of time. His wicked sense of humour was something that I cherished very much.

PARA.TAB: My time as Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate coincided with Rob's time as Parliamentary Liaison Officer. When Senator Reid and I saw that six foot five lanky creature walk into our offices, we always knew something was up and that something was about to change. There was a way in which Rob was able to put it, as Senator Robert Ray just said, so that absolutely no offence was taken and no grudge was borne against him. He had a real knack in handling that, and I know that Senator Reid and I really appreciated the way in which he handled that job.Along with all his diplomatic skills, which I suppose I have just described, his diplomacy in the way in which he would deal with everyone from all the different parties in the whips meeting, for example, was so magic that it really had to be seen to be believed.

I suppose that what disturbed me was that last year Rob was so excited at the fact that he seemed to be progressing well after his illness. Like Senator Patterson, I used to sit over here and say, `Are you okay?'. We would get the nod. Then we would catch up in the corridor and ask, `How are you going, Rob?'. `Really well', he would say.

He made the same comments to me that he made to Senator Patterson about the fact that he was so pleased that he had extra time with his boys and with Sally so that they could get to know him and he them. It seemed that the medical reports were getting better and better. During Christmas week we had a couple of conversations. I know that Rob was very tired, like the rest of us, but he was hoping to really enjoy a wonderful Christmas and holiday period with the family—only to have that cut short. I just could not believe it.

I was talking to Senator Patterson in the first week in January. It happened to be the day after his diagnosis. I said to Senator Patterson, `Do you know Rob's address?'. She said, `No, I don't, but I'm finding it out on Monday'. That was Friday. I think he had been diagnosed on Thursday. I said, `Well, I'll speak to you again on Monday and I'll get his address and I'll write to him'. By Monday it was all too late; he had died. How can someone just go like that from the time that we had had here, laughing and joking, in these very corridors only two weeks earlier, in Christmas week? I found that absolutely amazing to try to deal with.

Like so many people both here and outside the parliament, I will miss Rob. I will miss that cheeky face. I will miss his laughter. I will miss the good fun and the good times that we have had together. I will miss his professionalism. I too extend my very deep sympathy to Sally, the boys, his mother and his extended family. He will be missed by many of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the memory of Rob Jones for two main reasons. During my period as Deputy Government Whip, and as Government Whip for a short time filling Senator Jones's shoes while he was doing his duty on behalf of Australia overseas, I formed a very close relationship with Rob Jones. For obvious reasons, whips have to form those close relationships, but it was more than a working relationship.

PARA.TAB: Not only did we share our aches and pains with each other and sometimes offer each other sympathy but also did we share the joy that he experienced when he found that there was going to be another member of his family, when the pregnancy was confirmed, and later the ecstasy and exuberance when his third child was born. That was one of the memories that came immediately to me last Saturday when I heard the news.

My second reason for going on the record tonight is that, unfortunately, I did not get the news of Rob's death until Saturday of last week. I had been out of Australia and was unable to be present at the funeral or even to offer my condolences and those of my wife, who in turn got close to Rob. On the record now I associate myself with all the remarks made by previous honourable senators. I offer my and Jackie's personal condolences to Sally and the three children.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my normal practice, nor that of many other senators who have participated in this debate, to add to what has otherwise been a long adjournment debate and one in which senators are in agreement. There is really almost nothing to add, so I will not speak much in substance.

PARA.TAB: I find myself in a position very similar to Senator McKiernan. I was overseas at the time of the diagnosis and death of Rob Jones and was unable to take any of the action I would normally take to give recognition and make a proper response to the family of someone who was close to me and with whom I developed a special friendship and for whom I would like to make my respect and appreciation known. I will take this opportunity of joining with all those others who have so effectively and movingly spoken about Rob. I share the views which each of them has expressed and will not take up time unnecessarily by adding to them.

When I became Manager of Government Business in the Senate, I was deeply grateful to Senator Ray for giving me this great honour, as senators can all imagine. But it was Rob Jones's experience and calm that enabled me, however inadequately, to survive through those early periods of discharging that obligation as best I could on behalf of the government and the parliament.

I was also the Manager of Government Business when Rob left because of ill health the first time. I know many others felt the shock that I did when he advised me why he was going. What overwhelmed me was how much more calm about it he was than I was. I was devastated; he seemed entirely at peace with himself about it. I was impressed then by that immense calm and the sincerity with which he conveyed his confidence—in the short term, at least, well placed confidence—that it might well turn out to be okay. I remember the great joy I had when I saw him some time later in the parliament when it was clear that a significant recovery had taken place. He was then back working in the department and subsequently returned to work in the parliament both as PLO and subsequently for Gareth.

One of the things that Senator Reid and I share in representing Canberra is that we often get to deal with public servants who make a great and unrecognised contribution to their country. Sometimes we get the opportunity to give recognition to those individuals because they are our constituents and we are present at functions that they attend. In the list of those who have served Australia particularly well as public servants—there are many, and Australia is well served by them—Rob Jones will be considered, by all those who worked with him in the various capacities that he discharged but most particularly here in the parliament, as one of the great servants of the parliament, the public and the nation.

I have nothing to add other than to endorse the remarks of those who have spoken so effectively, and to particularly endorse the view that his family should be very proud of the contribution that he made. They should appreciate that we all share, in a very small way, the enormous loss that they must feel and that the nation has suffered because the capacity he had to contribute has been so tragically cut short.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to add my words to everybody else's contributions here tonight. Unlike most of the people who have already spoken, I did not have the opportunity to work so immediately closely with Rob. Perhaps it is interesting that I, who did not work immediately with him in terms of management of government business and so on, also had the same experience of knowing this very singular, very special and very wonderful man. I think one of Rob's remarkable qualities that come across to me tonight, from hearing others speak in very much the way I feel about him, was his capacity to make each of us feel singular and special. To pass by Rob and to smile or exchange words was a lifting occasion for the day and it made people feel something special about themselves, which was an extraordinary capacity that this man had.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine talked of what it says about all the rest of us, let alone most of the people who work around here, that this man's personality so shone. Is it that perhaps we should make a New Year's resolution to try to pick up on some of Rob's qualities? I suspect that is beyond the capacities of all of us and it is also, I suppose, to reiterate the singular qualities of Rob.

I add to the record one small example of a singular experience that I had in talking with Rob. Like Senator Patterson, I have been trained to recognise disease or something away from the normal and perhaps I also have a capacity to talk to people about it. In talking with Rob on one occasion very early on I discovered that he was like me, the parent of three sons—a category that I think is a very good measure of something; certainly it was a common point that we had.

In talking about what our sons were up to, I mentioned that, at that stage, my sons were educating me in chaos mathematics. Rob said, `Oh, yes'. We proceeded to engage in a conversation about chaos mathematics. He took it further and said that he would send me some papers about philosophy and chaos. He did so; I have that permanent record of Rob Jones.

I wanted to share that with the Senate. I can think of no better description of the skills one would need to cope with managing government business in this place than to be a master of chaos and a philosopher to wit. I add my words of sympathy to all those given to Rob's family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I came to know Rob Jones well when I was the Deputy Government Whip and he was Parliamentary Liaison Officer. I suppose that I came to know him a great deal better when I became Manager of Government Business and he was a senior adviser to Gareth Evans.

PARA.TAB: I can say that, with the exception of today, at every question time that I have been a minister, Rob Jones sat in the advisers' box not much more than a metre away from me. Unlike me, I suppose, he always behaved himself during question time. I should record that once or twice he even laughed at some of my jokes. I made a few comments to him, but he was never unparliamentary or disorderly enough to respond to any of the comments that I made.

I saw a tremendous amount of Rob during the difficult times when we had the odd crisis or problem. Of course, Rob was a person who liaised between the Senate leader's office and me as manager and those responsible for the parliamentary business program. I am pleased to say that I had many informal times with him. I am sure that both Gareth and I now treasure the many dinner discussions we had with Rob during the past year. That was a great opportunity. I can sincerely say to all senators that I owe Rob a great debt of personal gratitude. He certainly was of great personal assistance to me in the task that I have had to undertake, particularly as manager. He became a very good friend indeed.

Rob Jones was a very fine man. He made a very great contribution to this parliament. He was well liked and well respected by senators from all parties in this chamber and also by staff from all around Parliament House.

I had the opportunity at Rob's funeral to meet his wife Sally for the first time. At Rob's funeral I spoke at length with his mother, who was so rightly proud of Rob's great achievements. My deepest sympathy goes to Sally, his sons and the rest of his family. I am very grateful indeed that I had the privilege of knowing Rob Jones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I deal with the matter I wish to raise in this adjournment debate, which is the death of Frank Hardy, I would like to add my condolences to the family of Rob Jones and to say, as so many senators have said here, that he was a thoroughly decent, honourable and nice bloke.

PARA.TAB: Also, before I get to the matter of Frank Hardy, I would like to congratulate you, Mr President, on your appointment and to say welcome to the firing line which I probably helped you into at one stage today. As you know, Mr President, we seem to get each other's phone calls quite often. I do not think there is much other confusion apart from the colour of our beards, but I would not mind if perhaps our wage packets were confused.

In passing, I should also congratulate Kerry Sibraa on both his appointment and his excellent record as President of the Senate. He has been an outstanding Labor president in the very good tradition of Doug McClelland, and I feel confident that you, Mr President, will maintain that high tradition of Labor presidents. However, I am concerned about Kerry Sibraa. Someone who supports Manly cannot be all good. Kerry's departure leaves Mal Colston as the last of Labor's `75ers', those elected in the traumatic election of 1975.

Brian Archer who has resigned from our side was the last of the Liberal senators elected in 1975 following last year's departure of Shirley Walters. However, there are three senators left on our side who were originally elected to the House of Representatives and were defeated but who were then resurrected into the Senate, proving there is a life after political death and it is in the Senate. Those senators are Senator Short, Senator Chapman and me.

Senator's Archer's going not only removes one more link with that dramatic election time but also means the departure of a very decent, hardworking, honourable and able senator—a man who is totally trustworthy and a very good friend. There is no doubt we on our side will miss him very much.

I now deal with the substance of my contribution tonight, and that is about Frank Hardy. Some might find it curious that a member of the Liberal Party should be providing this epilogue to a good old commo. He was an old-fashioned commo and proud of it. He did have his disputes with the Communist Party, but he still maintained his strong views about the inequities of the capitalist system, although he did enjoy some elements of the capitalist system.

Frank and I were, if you like, old mates from the late 1960s when he was on an ABC television program with me for five years called Would you believe. He was a member of the opposing team, consisting of Frank Hardy, Noelene Brown and Len Evans, while on my side there was the late Cyril Pearl, Jackie Weaver and me. The chairman was Peter Lazar. It was an Australian history program. It gave Frank the opportunity on television to tell a lot of his Billy Borker yarns, which were certainly very Australian and which helped create a real Australian image for this very Australian program. I was very proud to be on the program during the full five years of its life.

Frank was probably Australia's worst and most obsessive punter, apart from his enormous and quite justified status as an author. In particular, Power without glory was a seminal work. Whether it was right or wrong or whether it was the best prose in Australia is another matter, but it was a book that put Frank Hardy very much on the map.

I got to know him as an obsessive punter perhaps uncomfortably well. For example, when recording our program we had screens on which various objects would be flashed as part of the program. In the down times Frank would organise the ABC technicians to put on the screen the end of whatever race happened to be running at Harold Park at the time, which was very distracting when we were trying to do a television program.

He always had a good bet. Unfortunately, of his Sydney mates, I seemed to live closest to Harold Park with the result that often on Friday nights a taxi would arrive at my front door, Frank would rush out and say, `Have you got 50 bucks? I've got a certainty on the last and I'm out of money'. Len Evans, who lived at Greenwich, was the next nearest person so when I was not at home the same thing would happen to him. I have to say that Frank always paid us the money back. I am not sure whether he got it from winnings—I never knew of him actually winning on a race—but he was a great and entertaining colleague.

He was, I might say, very determined as well. He was determined—and I have to be very careful about how I say this—to be the first Australian to use the magic word on television. He kept trying to do it on our pre-recorded program. We kept telling him, `Don't waste your time, Frank. All they have to do is edit it out'. But he kept trying.

The Senate will be aware of the fact that in the late 1960s and early 1970s the airwaves were not quite as free as they seem to be now. He tried and tried and was enraged when, on commercial television, a female—I think it was Germaine Greer—actually dropped that magic word in an interview. We consoled Frank by saying that until it was said on ABC television it did not really count. So he kept on trying, only to be beaten by, I think, an Aboriginal chap talking about Northern Territory land rights. His enthusiasm for those causes—female rights and Aboriginal land rights—seemed momentarily to diminish because of his lack of success in this area and his being one-upped by them.

The thing I recall most about Frank is his laconic method of telling Australian stories. He was, in fact, the champion Australian story teller. I remember the classic one he tried on our program—I think it is probably appropriate that we should end with such a typical Frank Hardy story—about a court case in Darwin in which the magistrate was slightly hard of hearing. The defendant, who had spent the night in the cells, was still inebriated. The crown prosecutor was asking various questions of the defendant. The magistrate could not hear anything and at one stage saw the defendant respond to a question from the crown prosecutor which related to what he was doing. The man replied that he was doing stuff all at the time. The magistrate leaned forward and said `What did he say? What did he say?' The crown prosecutor said, `He said, "Stuff all", Your Honour' to which His Honour replied, `That's very strange. I distinctly saw his lips move'. That kind of really Australian humour was what Frank Hardy was all about in those Billy Borker yarns. He created a real niche for himself in that area as well as in his more serious writing.

He certainly created a massive impact on Australian literature, Australian politics and Australian television, and in his script writing and so on. He was a lively character. I think he was very depressed after his sister died some years ago; they were very close. I would like to convey my condolences to his family and acknowledge the significance of Frank Hardy's life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with many others tonight, I wish to add my congratulations on your election to the position of President of the Senate. I rise tonight to speak briefly on the adjournment to highlight to the Senate the events in January in New South Wales when bushfires ravaged a large part of my home state. The main reason I do this is to pay tribute to the thousands of people who, in the face of adversity, were able to show incredible courage and kindness to help each other in a time of very severe crisis. At the same time, I believe it is very important not to lose sight of the incredible losses that were suffered by hundreds of people as a result of the fires.

PARA.TAB: The January bushfires raged down 800 kilometres of the New South Wales coastline, from the Queensland border to Batemans Bay on the south coast. The fires ravaged the north coast, the mid-north coast, my region of the Hunter, the Blue Mountains, the south coast and many parts of Sydney. The fires were particularly horrific on the central coast and in the northern and southern suburbs of Sydney.
On 8 January the Sydney Morning Herald reported that the Chief of the Bush Fire Service, Mr Phil Koperberg, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have an unmitigated disaster on our hands . . . We have fire so ferocious, firefighters themselves are fleeing for their lives. We are losing a lot of property and I only pray that we don't lose too many lives.

I almost came very close to the bushfires at one point when I was travelling home from Sydney. It was only due to a phone call from my wife that I delayed my trip by several hours. If I had not done that, I would have been trapped on the F3 freeway for several days, along with many hundreds of commuters who became stuck on the freeway when the fires raged to the north and the south of the points where they stopped.

PARA.TAB: Instead of driving home, I flew home. I flew over the fires. From the air, it was a truly awesome sight. At that point, the fires were moving up the Lane Cove valley. They had ravaged the national parks. As we entered the plane the pilot said to us, `But you ought to see the fires in Kuringai Chase'. At that point, these fires had not even been mentioned on the news services.

We flew north to the Hunter on what is normally probably one of the most beautiful flights in the world as it involves flying over Sydney, the Hawkesbury system and the lake system up to the Hunter. But on this evening we could see a wall of fire across Kuringai Chase that stretched from the Hawkesbury bridge across to Church Point. It is only when people look at bushfire from that aspect that they really appreciate its awesome power.

I did not really even appreciate this early in my life. I had been in two towns that were almost wiped out by fire, with me in them. But on the ground as a small boy I had a real, healthy respect for the power of bushfires. I did not realise until I saw it from the air how awesome it is and how difficult it is for people to, first, escape and, secondly, actually fight such a fire. It is a tremendous tribute to the people of the areas near the fires that they handled the situation and, particularly, how the services came in to support them. I want to spend a little time talking about that this evening.

I think there is a lesson in it for us as a nation. The lesson is that we must really come to appreciate more fully the true nature of the Australian bush, that bushfire is part of the ecology of this country and that we must learn to manage much better the interface between urban areas and bush areas in our cities. If we do not do that, the horrific costs of this fire will be repeated down the track in what is an almost inevitable bushfire cycle.

Four lives were lost as a result of this fire. The insurance bill is likely to top $100 million, and that does not include the people who lost an enormous amount of property but were not insured. The infrastructure of New South Wales took a savage beating, with electrical lines, railway tracks, public buildings and, in particular, schools being destroyed in the path of the fire. Thousands of hectares were burnt out, including 90 per cent of the Royal National Park south of Sydney, which is the second oldest national park in the world.

The stories of personal tragedy, including those of the hundreds of people who lost all their possessions, was truly heart-rending. The people of Como, Jannali and Bonnet Bay in particular were devastated by the loss of 87 homes. Some residents had been living there all their lives. A young newly engaged couples had just moved there and lost everything except the clothes on their back as they fled the firestorm. The losses, be they treasured heirlooms or new engagement presents, are irreplaceable. Yet with remarkable courage, these people, along with others affected right throughout New South Wales, looked despair in the face and fought back. They are now confronted with the unenviable task of rebuilding.

The fires would have been much worse if it had not been for the incredible work carried out by the professional and volunteer bushfire brigades. On 10 January, almost 9,000 volunteer bushfire fighters and military personnel from all over Australia fought the fires. The volunteers would normally work double shifts. During the fires, many had been working for several days without a break and most had spent days away from their homes and families. Some brigades had been out fighting fires for almost three weeks.

The national proportion of this disaster was evidenced by the fact that firefighters came to help from right around Australia from every state, as did the Royal Australian Navy and the Army. The other emergency services, such as state rescue services, the ambulance services and the police, were all stretched to the limit, but all performed tremendously well under terrific stress.

Additionally, another aspect of the bushfire emergency which is worthy of mention is the generous acts by the hundreds of people who assisted those who were caught out. A sense of community and camaraderie never fails to flourish in Australia when other people are in crisis. This was evidenced through the work of many people assisting those who were trapped on the F3. As I mentioned before, I was almost one of them.

With the major transport routes between Sydney and my area of the Hunter closed for some days, many people were stranded. They were in their cars on the freeway, in evacuation centres on the central coast or they were among the thousands of commuters who were stranded in Sydney after getting to work and being unable to get home again.

Service organisations came to the rescue, as did various charitable organisations, such as the Salvos, and even the local residents along the F3 freeway. Local businessmen donated food and drink to those who were stranded as well as to the firefighters and local volunteers. They organised themselves into working bees to make food packages, which were then thrown into the boots of cars and taken to the firefighters and the people who had been stranded.

The resilience, courage and camaraderie of the people of New South Wales cannot be underestimated. This was clearly shown during the bushfires. A tribute must also be paid to the New South Wales coalition government for developing and implementing a strategic plan which helped to minimise the impact of the disaster. Premier John Fahey and the Hon. Terry Griffiths, Minister for Police and Emergency Services, worked tirelessly to ensure that all possible government resources were directed towards fighting the fires in an effective way and then to make the following recovery as swift as possible.
