The final person I wish to mention is the chief of the firefighting service, Mr Phil Koperberg. Mr Koperberg did an absolutely outstanding job. This man coordinated the largest firefighting operation that Australia has ever seen. He directed 7,000 firefighters but still managed to think of staff on an individual level. He took the responsibility of breaking the news of the death of a firefighter personally to the dead man's wife, describing it as the hardest thing that he had ever done. Phil Koperberg and his team have performed an outstanding service for the people of New South Wales.

The fires were a terrible experience involving an incredible number of people. Our hearts must go out to those who lost their loved ones and possessions. Similarly, we must thank all those who acted so selflessly in helping others during the crisis. I trust that the Senate joins me in these sentiments.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will a copy of the Australian submission to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) regarding the United States-Mexico dispute on yellow fin tuna and the incidental kill of dolphins be provided.
(2) Will a copy of the official response of the Dunkel text presented by the Australian Government in Geneva at a meeting of the GATT panel held on 13 January 1992 be provided.

(3) Will documents which relate to Australia's official position on the establishment of a Multilateral Trade Organisation (MTO) and include any response by the Australian Government to the November 1992 submissions by the United States on changes to the Dunkel text be provided.
(4) Who currently represents Australia at Codex Alimentarius.
(5) What positions, if any, do Australian Government representatives hold at Codex Alimentarius.

(6) Has the Australian Government drawn up a discussion paper on: (a) the proposed Sanitary and Phytosanitary Standards; (b) technical barriers to trade; (c) intellectual property rights proposals; (d) investment related to the Uruguay Round of talks; and (e) the agricultural subsidy proposal and market access; if so, have any such discussion papers been circulated; if so, to which organisations.
(7) Can details of any attempts by the Australian Government to educate the Australian public on the ramifications of a successful completion to the Uruguay Round be provided.
(8) Does the Australian Government support the establishment of an MTO if the Uruguay Round is successfully negotiated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian third party submission to the Mexico/United States GATT tuna panel is included in the panel report. This report is a public GATT document (DS21/R) which will be provided to Senator Coulter.

(2) The Australian Government did not make a formal written response to the Dunkel text but it did respond verbally at the meeting of the Trade Negotiations Committee of the Uruguay Round held in Geneva on 13 January 1992. The Government's response was along the lines of the press release issued Mr John Kerin who was acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade at the time. A copy of that press release will be provided to Senator Coulter.

(3) Documents containing Australia's detailed negotiating positions are not released while negotiations are still in progress. A number of considerations make this inappropriate. When negotiations are under way, Australia's positions, need to be able to take account of changing circumstances. Results of negotiations are always made available publicly.

However, as a general point, it should be noted that the development of Australian positions on all aspects of the Uruguay Round negotiations, including the proposed Multilateral Trade Organisation (MTO) has included an extensive process of consultation within the Commonwealth Government, with the State Governments, with a broad range of private sector groups, non-governmental organisations, union representatives, and the public. On the question of an MTO this has resulted in Australia taking the basic position in the negotiations of supporting the strengthening of the GATT institutions and dispute settlement arrangements.

The Government endorsed the Draft Final Act (DFA) as a basis for concluding the Round negotiations. This was based on a judgement that smaller and medium sized economies benefit from effective rules based systems and from the consideration that the proposed Multilateral Trade Organisation (now the World Trade Organisation (WTO)) promised a stronger, more comprehensive, more balanced and equitable set of rules and dispute settlement arrangements.

(4) Australia was represented at the 20th Session of the Codex Alimentarius Commission which was held in Geneva from 28 June to 7 July 1993 by Mr Digby Gascoine, Director, Food Inspection Division, Australian Quarantine Service and Ms Gae Pincus, Chair, National Food Authority.
Australian delegations to subsidiary committees of the Commission can be drawn from a range of industry and other related organisations including:
Australian Quarantine Inspection Service
National Food Authority
Australian Government Analytical Laboratories
National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals
(5) Mr Gascoine was elected Vice Chairman of the Commission in July 1993 and is Chairman of the Codex Committee on Import and Export Food Inspection and Certification System.

(6) Much of the information which the Government holds on the negotiations relating to each of the subjects listed is confidential. Detailed consideration by the Government and its agencies has been given to formulation of Australian positions and, as far as possible, information has been shared with industry and sectoral organisations as part of a broad ranging process of consultation in the development and refinement of Australian positions.
Separately briefing kits have been prepared setting out Australia's positions on the issues involved and these have been widely distributed to the media and to members of the public.

(7) Because of the benefits which an outcome to the Uruguay Round will provide for Australia and for the global economy it has been and is a central priority for the Government. Heightened public awareness of the issues covered in the Round is accorded high priority. Ministers have always endeavoured, to take every opportunity—both formal and informal—to inform the public, industry and sectoral organisations of progress. Ministers and officials have been active in providing information through talks, lectures, press briefings and seminars to any groups or organisations which have expressed interest.

The Uruguay Round has generated an unprecedented amount of comment and debate in the Australian and international press since it began seven years ago. Issues covered in the Round have been comprehensively discussed and reported by the media. Encouraged by the positive interest which has been shown in the Uruguay Round the Government has sought to foster this by its own efforts to keep the public, industry and interest groups informed. It has also consulted widely with interested industry and consumer groups, organisations and individuals.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has disseminated information in Australia and overseas on Australian positions on Uruguay Round issues. Publications such as the DFAT Annual Report, and periodicals produced by the Department (eg Insight and the Trade Negotiations Brief) as well as specialised material such as fact sheets on specific issues or aspects of the negotiations in which there is strong local interest provide extensive and regular sources of information.

The Department also recently produced a handy guide entitled "Uruguay Round Briefing" which attempts to demystify much of the jargon and complex terminology of the negotiations. On the conclusion of the negotiations another comprehensive document outlining the results, entitled "Uruguay Round: Outcomes for Australia" has been produced and is publicly available. A copy will be provided to Senator Coulter. Finally, the Department has cooperated with outside organisations such as the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in preparing public affairs material for distribution.
(8) Please see the answer to Question 3.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What input and influence has Australia had in the setting of food standards by the Codex Alimentarius.
(2) Does the Minister have any concerns with the proposal to harmonise food standards where Codex standards under a completed GATT would become internationally recognised.
(3) Will Codex harmonised standards allow foods containing high residues of pesticides such as alar, dieldrin and DDT which has been banned in the United States for many years.

(4) If Australia decided to ban the importation of food containing levels of pesticides above the levels permitted by Codex, could another country challenge the Australian decision as a technical barrier to trade; if so, would that country win under new GATT rules.
(5) Will Australia's maximum residue levels in food be affected under the new GATT rules.
(6) Does the Minister agree that GATT must recognise sovereign standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia has actively participated in the work of the Codex Alimentarius Commission since it was established in 1962. In this time the Commission has developed over two hundred recommended international food standards, about thirty international codes of technological and hygienic practice, and over two thousand maximum residue limits for particular pesticide/commodity combinations, a number of maximum residue limits for veterinary drugs, a large number of methods of analysis, and a code of ethics for international trade in food. Responsibility for the Codex Alimentarius Commission within the Government rests with the Minister for Primary Industry and Energy.

Australian delegations have left a prominent mark on a range of issues which have been important to our food production and trade, particularly where these involve questions of good agricultural and manufacturing practice. Delegations have maintained a strong position on the application of scientific rigour throughout all Codex assessments processes and have achieved priority listing for a number of agricultural chemicals, including through re-evaluation of existing chemicals, and commodities and general issues, such as long life, ready-to-eat refrigerated products and labelling requirements for organic foods.

(2) An agreement on the application of sanitary and phytosanitary measures has been drafted as part of the GATT Uruguay Round negotiations. The draft agreement encourages the contracting parties to GATT to harmonise their food standards, guidelines and recommendations. The agreement would allow any Contracting Party to maintain more stringent standards than the relevant international standards such as those promulgated for food by the FAO/WHO Codex Alimentarius Commission. However, a country which maintains a more stringent standard may be challenged by another contracting party to justify its measure. The justification would show that the measure is based on sound science and risk management, and that it reflects a consistent approach to risk management.

Australia has participated actively in the drafting of the proposed agreement and supports its adoption as part of an overall Uruguay Round outcome. Australia's current practices for establishing and maintaining food and quarantine standards, which provide a high degree of security, are consistent with the terms of the agreement. Codex Alimentarius Commission food standards, which would become a reference point under the proposed agreement, are themselves generally conservative in their approach to management of risk. There is therefore, no need for concern that the proposed GATT agreement on application of sanitary or phytosanitary measures is in any way prejudicial to the maintenance of stringent food safety standards in Australia.

(3) No. There is no Codex-recommended maximum residue limit (MRL) for daminazide, sold commercially as Alar. Codex MRLs for dieldrin and DDT will not allow high levels of residues of those pesticides. At its September 1992 meeting the FAO/WHO Joint Expert Committee on Pesticide Residues (JECFA) noted that production of these substances is being phased out. Monitoring data provided by Australia, the Netherlands, Thailand and the USA were reviewed by the Committee, which noted that these data showed that 97 to 99 per cent of samples of food crops and animals did not contain detectable residues. However, establishment of a Codex MRL at an appropriately low level, to reflect the fact that a small proportion of production may contain trace levels of environmental contamination, was recommended by JECFA to the Codex Committee on Pesticide Residues. This recommendation will be formally considered in 1994.

(4) Australia could ban the importation of food containing levels of pesticides above the limits recommended by Codex, but in terms of the draft GATT agreement on the application of sanitary and phytosanitary measures a similar approach would have to be taken in respect to domestic produce. In such circumstances a challenge by another GATT Contracting Party to the relevant food standard could not be made.

(5) Australian maximum residue limits are established with regard to human health and safety on the basis of sound science. Therefore if they are more stringent than internationally recognised standards they can be justified under GATT rules. See also response to (2) above.

(6) The draft GATT agreement on the application of sanitary and phytosanitary measures provides that Contracting Parties have the right to take sanitary and phytosanitary measures necessary for the protection of human, animal or plant life or health, provided that such measures are not inconsistent with the provisions of the agreement. Contracting Parties may introduce or maintain sanitary or phytosanitary measures which result in a higher level of sanitary phytosaniatry protection than would be achieved by measures based on the relevant international standards if there is a scientific justification, or as a consequence of the level of protection a contracting party determines to be appropriate. Where there are no relevant international norms, contracting parties' measures will conform with the terms of the agreement provided that they are based on sound science and risk assessment and reflect a consistent approach to risk management. It is also necessary that measures are non-discriminatory in application and do not restrict trade more than is necessary for the achievement of the appropriate level of protection.

The appropriate level of sanitary or phytosanitary protection is the level deemed appropriate by the contracting party in establishing a measure. The draft GATT agreement therefore does recognise national sovereignty in establishment of food safety and quarantine standards.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 13 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: What steps are being taken to ensure that any form of right to farm legislation will not override the right in common law for action to be taken against nuisance and misuse of chemicals whether in rural or semi-urban areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the `right to farm' legislation referred to by the honourable senator relates to proposals contained in a working paper released in 1992 by the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry and Fisheries, the Honourable Robin Gray MHA. I understand that the proposals seek to protect farmers against claims made by residents in semi-urban areas in respect of such matters as pesticides and chemicals use and noise pollution.

The introduction of any such legislation would be a matter for the Tasmania State Government which I understand is currently receiving representations from interested parties on this matter. The Commonwealth Government is currently not taking any steps in relation to the proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 23 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Government received any expressions of concern regarding the operation of the Australian Centre for Furniture Design (ACFD).
(2) From where have such concerns emanated.
(3) Is the ACFD currently financially viable.
(4) What was the gross operating loss for the ACFD for the financial years: (a) 1989-90; (b) 1990-91; (c) 1991-92; and (d) 1992-93.
(5) What evidence of its own success did the ACFD offer the Federal Government when it sought additional funding of $450,000.
(6) On what basis did the Government consider that the ACFD warranted such funding.
(7) Does the Government expect the ACFD to be financially viable at the expiration of the $450,000 grant.
(8) Has the Government set performance criteria for the ACFD in relation to the receipt of ongoing grant allocations; if so, what are the criteria.
(9) Did the Tasmanian State Government support the grant of $450,000 to the ACFD; if not, why not.
(10) What was the gross operating loss for the Australian Furniture Research and Development Institute (AFRDI) for the financial years: (a) 1989-90; (b) 1990-91; (c) 1991-92; and (d) 1992-93.
(11) Has the Government received any requests for additional funding from AFRDI; if so, what is the Government's justification for not providing further funding for AFRDI.
(12) Is the Government prepared to provide the necessary financial support to ensure the future of AFRDI.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) The Australian Furniture Research and Development Institute (AFRDI) recently wrote to the Commonwealth expressing concern over the provision of additional funding for the Centre for Furniture Design (CFD).
The Commonwealth is also aware that some members of the Tasmanian Forests and Forest Industry Council have expressed concerns regarding the rate of progress by the CFD in achieving its objectives.

(3) Yes. With the assistance it is receiving from various sources, including Helsham monies, the CFD is currently financially viable. In the absence of the additional Helsham monies, the Centre would need to restructure its activities and rationalise its resources within available funds.
As with a number of other projects being funded under the Helsham Package, the long term expectation is that the Centre will become self-supporting.

(4) The CFD has advised that it did not suffer a loss in any of those years. Financial procedures within the University of Tasmania relating to expenditure of Helsham monies and other funding monies prevent overspending.

(5) In June 1992, at the time the then Tasmanian Minister for Forests requested additional Commonwealth financial assistance for the Centre, the CFD provided the Commonwealth with reports covering the Centre's progress and achievements. It also provided material illustrating a number of items of furniture designed at the CFD.

The CFD also demonstrated its capabilities in furniture design when in 1992 it received a Collaborative Research Grant of $200,000 over three years for a specific purpose project from the Australian Research Council.

(6) Continued funding of the Centre for Furniture Design within the Helsham Package was seen as an opportunity to assist the development of an innovative furniture manufacturing industry in Tasmania and encourage the use of the State's distinctive native timbers. This is consistent with the 1988 Heads of Agreement between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments concerning activities to be funded under the Helsham Package.

(7) Yes. To aid this process, an advisory board comprising representatives of the Commonwealth, the Tasmanian Government and industry is to be established to assist the CFD in meeting its objectives, and achieving financial self sufficiency.
The CFD is aware of the expectation that it will adopt a commercially oriented approach to enable it to become self-funding once the funds are exhausted in 1995-96.

(8) The CFD will be required to meet the objectives of the project and to submit progress and financial reports annually. As noted in the response to Question 7, an advisory board is being established to assist the CFD in meeting its objectives.
(9) The Tasmanian Government approached the Commonwealth in June 1992 seeking Commonwealth funding of $150,000 per annum over the following three years for the CFD.

This additional Commonwealth financial assistance was sought by the then Tasmanian Minister for Forests to ensure that "this national initiative can be maintained". The Minister strongly urged Commonwealth support for the Centre, an initiative he believed to be consistent with the vision that both Governments have for the future of the forest products industry in this country. The Tasmanian Government did not, however, wish the additional assistance to be provided from the Helsham Package.
(10) AFRDI has advised that it did not suffer a loss in any of those years.

(11) & (12) A representative of AFRDI sought additional funding for the Institute during discussions in June 1992 with officers of several Commonwealth Departments. AFRDI has also recently made direct representations to the Commonwealth Government for additional assistance.

AFRDI was advised during the discussions in June 1992 that the only source of funds available for this type of activity would be under the Helsham Package and that the arrangement for allocating Commonwealth assistance for projects under the Helsham Package is for the Tasmanian Government to approach the Commonwealth seeking approval of funding for specific activities.

No such approach for additional funds has been made by the Tasmanian Government in respect of AFRDI to date. In addition, all funds currently available under the Helsham Package are now fully committed to projects.

As well as the $1.4 million already provided for AFRDI under the Helsham Package, the Commonwealth is assisting the Institute in other ways, including by public recognition of its role and function as the national body to research, test and appraise furniture products, and the use of AFRDI by Purchasing Australia for all testing for furniture for "common use" contracts.
The long term expectation is that AFRDI will become self-supporting.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the Greek annexation of 51 per cent of the territory of Macedonia in 1913: (a) has the Greek Government, since that time, practised a policy of denationalisation and assimilation of the Macedonian people; (b) has this policy included the denial of such basic rights as freedom of religion, freedom to speak and be educated in the Macedonian language and freedom of cultural expression; and (c) has the Australian Government made representations about these issues, and with what response.

(2) With reference to human rights organisations, including Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch, and newspapers such as the Times and the Economist which have recently published reports which are highly critical of Greece's continuing suppression of freedom of expression, does the Government's own monitoring of the situation agree with concerns raised by these organisations; if so, what is its response.

(3) With reference to the conclusion of the Helsinki Watch report that "Friends of Greece around the world—and everyone concerned about freedom of expression—ought to speak up and tell the country's misguided Government to pursue its Macedonian policy through persuasion, not coercion": (a) does the Government agree with this conclusion; (b) has the Government made representations to the Greek Government in these terms and what has been the response; and (c) what influence can the Australian Government exercise with its Greek counterparts.

(4) With reference to the Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch reports which specifically mention 20 cases in which ethnic Macedonians and their friends are being charged through the Greek legal system for having done nothing more than express opinions that differ from those of the Greek Government, with 15 of these cases still being current, is the Australian Government aware of the identity of these 15 people and is it prepared to exercise such influence as it is able to bring to bear on the Greek Government with a view to having the charges dropped and the peoples' rights to freedom of expression restored.

(5) Can assurances be given that the Australian Government will use such forums as are made available through the United Nations (UNHRC, the Conferences on Human Rights and the General Assembly) to raise the issue of the Greek Government's denial of basic human rights to ethnic Macedonians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The question of sovereign rights over the area known as Macedonia is a long-running and complex one reflecting the intricacies of various rivalries, conflicts and tensions which have taken place in the Balkans. The "Macedonia" in question that existed before the 1912-1913 Balkan wars was an Ottoman Province with a heterogeneous population, and with Slavs probably comprising the largest single element. The 51 per cent acquired by Greece, ie Aegean Macedonia, was ceded to it in the 1913 Treaty of Bucharest: (a) The term "Macedonian people" is subject to very wide interpretation by the countries and communities of the region. The Greek Government regards the Macedonian people as people from the region of Macedonia in Northern Greece. The Greek authorities deny that these people have been denationalised and that the question of assimilation is not relevant as they do not recognise the existence of a "Macedonian minority". The only minority that Greece formally recognises is a "Muslim minority". (b) Freedom of speech and of the press is provided for in the Greek constitution, and is respected in practice, but there are notable exceptions. Greek law prohibits "exposing the friendly relations of the Greek state with foreign states to danger of disturbance," "spreading false information and rumours liable to create concern and fear among citizens and cause disturbance in the country's international relations" and "inciting citizens into rivalry and division, leading to disturbance of the peace". This law has been enforced on a number of occasions with respect to Macedonian issues. Organisations of Greek citizens of Slavic (Macedonian) origin are not allowed to use the word "Macedonian" in their names. Open performances of Slavic dances and the speaking of the Slavic language have also been discouraged. Education in Greece is carried out in the Greek language with the exception of that relating to the "Muslim Minority" which have the right to Turkish language education. (c) The Australian Government monitors the human rights situation in Greece through the Australian Embassy in Athens and has made representations to the Greek Government about individual cases of human rights concern including about Greek citizens of Macedonian origin.

(2) and (3) The Australian Government's assessment of the human rights situation in Greece is in general accordance with that put forward by reputable human rights non-government organisations such as Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch. As stated above, the Australian Government has made representations to the Greek authorities on individual cases of human rights concern. Moreover, the Australian Government would anticipate that the Greek Government would take note of representations made by Australia or other members of the international community concerning allegations that Greece was in breach of its international human rights obligations.

(4) As to the 20 cases of ethnic Macedonians being charged through the Greek legal system for having expressed opinions that differ from those of the Greek Government referred to in the Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch reports, the Australian Government has been aware of a number of cases and has made specific representations in relation to Mr Sideropoulos and Mr Bulis. The Australian Embassy in Athens has been following their cases closely. Mr Sideropoulos's case was raised with the previous Greek Foreign Minister. The information gathered on these cases by the Embassy is consistent with the Helsinki Watch and Amnesty International Reports. The latest information we have on their situation is that the two men were convicted on 1 April 1993 and sentenced to five months' imprisonment. However, these sentences were suspended on appeal and they were released.

(5) There is no indication of international support for raising the issue of Greece's "Macedonian minority" in international human rights forums. The Australian Government will, however, continue to monitor the situation and, as appropriate, make representations to the Greek Government on issues of concern.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tax Compensation for Sale of Government Enterprises

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the issue of tax compensation for the sale of State Government operated enterprises:

(1) Is it the case that the Tasmanian Government was provided with assurances less than 2 weeks before the last Premiers' Conference that tax compensation would be provided for the sale of the Tasmanian Government Insurance Office (TGIO) and that this position was reversed at the subsequent Premiers' Conference.

(2) (a) Has the Commonwealth yet considered a request from the Tasmanian Government for tax compensation on the sale of the TGIO; (b) why has the Commonwealth not yet responded to the Tasmanian Government on this request and when will a decision be taken on the request; (c) if a decision has been made, what was the response; and (d) what criteria were used in reaching this decision.

(3) (a) What criteria will be applied in future in determining which cases will be eligible for Commonwealth tax compensation; and (b) has the Commonwealth given a commitment to consider tax compensation for the sale of State Government operated enterprises on a case by case basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Advice provided to the Tasmanian Government prior to the Premiers' Conference reflected the policy at the time, under which the TGIO sale would have been eligible. The Government subsequently announced a change in policy at the Premiers' Conference.

(2) (a) In January 1993 the then Treasurer of Tasmania, Mr Groom, wrote to the Treasurer making a formal application for compensation for tax equivalent revenues forgone in the sale of the Tasmanian Government Insurance Office (TGIO) to the private sector. This request has been considered by the Commonwealth.
(b) The Government has responded to the Tasmanian application for income tax compensation.

(c) On 27 September 1993 the Prime Minister wrote to the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Groom. The Prime Minister noted that the Commonwealth is not prepared to reconsider its tax compensation policy outlined at the July 1993 Financial Premiers' Conference. The Prime Minister also indicated that the Commonwealth is prepared to consider claims for income tax compensation on a case by case basis to ensure that neither the States nor the Commonwealth would be financially advantaged or disadvantaged as a result of privatisation. On 30 September 1993 the Treasurer wrote to the Tasmanian Treasurer, Mr Rundle, and indicated that income tax compensation would not be paid under the old compensation policy.
(d) The criteria used in reaching this decision were the terms of the Commonwealth's new tax compensation policy announced at the July 1993 Premiers' Conference (see 3(a) below).cccccc

(3) (a) At the July 1993 Premiers' Conference the Commonwealth announced changes to its tax compensation policy for the privatisation or corporatisation of State Trading Enterprises (STEs). Each State will be compensated for the full privatisation of no more than one bank or insurance office, contingent on privatisation having begun before 1 July 1995 and in accordance with the guidelines of the previous tax compensation policy.

Beyond this the new policy provides that in the event of full or part sale or corporatisation there will be a case-by-case examination to ensure that neither the States nor the Commonwealth would be financially advantaged or disadvantaged as a result of tax compensation.
(b) Yes.

$1 million payment on completion of the sale, followed by two payments of $250,000 each to be paid on 1 July 1994 and 1 July 1995 respectively;

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 2 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What resources are currently being made available by the Federal Government to stem the alarming spread of the Northern Pacific Seastar which has infested Hobart's harbour, turning it into a marine desert, and is invading Tasmania's east coast on its march north to Bass Strait.
(2) If there are no resources currently deployed to check the progress of and destroy this virtually indestructible starfish, what plans are being made by the Government in this regard.

(3) Will the Government be providing funds for research to find ways to eradicate this foreign starfish, which is a real threat to Tasmania's vital seafood industries; if so, what is intended and will the CSIRO be involved; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1, 2 & 3) The Commonwealth has been and remains actively involved in combating this pest, the Northern Pacific Seastar (Asterias amurensis), through a range of collaborative research and other activities.

The Fisheries Research and Development Corporation (FRDC) is currently funding work by the University of Tasmania ($14,000) to find commercial uses for the Northern Pacific Seastar and the CSIRO ($18,000) has recently carried out a status report on the seastar. CSIRO scientists have also undertaken further work on a seastar data base in collaboration with their Japanese and Russian counterparts.

In addition, FRDC has approved funding for a $42,000 project by CSIRO to investigate the dispersal of seastar larvae and for a $50,000 project by CSIRO to investigate the larval ecology of the seastar. CSIRO has applied for an additional $50,000 to fund another project considering the genetic characteristics of the seastar. In addition to the funding from FRDC, CSIRO has allocated considerable in-house resources (scientists, laboratories, research boats and equipment) in the fight against the seastar and is working closely with all authorities involved with this issue.

The Australian Nature Conservation Agency (ANCA) has funded a project undertaken by the Tasmanian Museum ($64,000) to determine the present status and effect of the seastar on native and commercial invertebrate fauna of south eastern Tasmania. ANCA has budgeted a further $19,000 towards this project.

A three-year research program into marine pests has also been funded through the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS). This program which is being coordinated by the Ballast Water Scientific Working Group has provided $625,000 for research to date. The Bureau of Resource Sciences is coordinating the scientific aspects of this program, which aims to find a means that is technically acceptable, safe, cost effective and environmentally sound to minimise the risk of introducing exotic organisms.

This program includes the `Bio-Economic Risk Assessment' research project. The aim of this study is to predict the probable impact, both biological and economic, of the introduction and establishment of exotic marine organisms in Australia, including the seastar. Phase 1 of the study will consider toxic dinoflagellates (costing $85,000) while Phase 2 of the study will consider the seaweed Undaria pinnatifida and the seastar Asterias amurensis (budgeted at $73,000).

The Government has recently released a discussion paper on Coastal Ballast Water Guidelines for comment and further refinement. The guidelines are designed to put in place a ballast water management program that will minimise the risk of translocating unwanted non-indigenous species between Australian ports. While the Commonwealth will maintain its international ballast water role, the paper calls for the States to take ownership of domestic ballast water problems. The Commonwealth is taking steps to establish a National Strategy for Ballast Water Management to satisfy the needs of the many agencies, organisations and industries with a stake in the issue.

A National Seastar Task Force has been set up to control the spread of this pest and membership includes several Commonwealth specialist representatives from CSIRO, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories. The immediate focus of the Task Force is to control the impact of the seastar on local shellfish farms and other sensitive areas. The long term objective of the Task Force is to identify areas of research with a view to finding an effective biological control.

There are no simple answers to this problem. However, I can assure the honourable Senator that the Commonwealth is committed to addressing the seastar problem along with other possible problems associated with ballast water and will cooperate closely with Tasmania and other States in finding solutions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Foreign Investment Review Board able to refuse a foreign company's or individual's application to purchase land or a leasehold when that property incorporates one or more sites sacred to Aboriginal people.
(2) Is the Foreign Investment Review Board required to reject such an application.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The Foreign Investment Review Board is an advisory body to the Government on foreign investment cases and policy. It has no powers to approve or refuse a foreign company's or individual's application to purchase land or a leasehold in Australia. Under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 the Treasurer is empowered to reject foreign interests acquiring Australian assets, including land, if such an acquisition is considered contrary to the national interest. Consideration of foreign investment cases involves full consultation with relevant interests and these views are taken into account when assessing whether a proposal is contrary to the national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, upon notice, on 17 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What discretionary powers does the secretary or his or her delegate have to waive (that is, to cease the offsetting of Commonwealth benefits) negative loadings that have been applied to nursing homes.
(2) What is the source of these powers.
(3) For how long has the secretary or his or her delegate had these powers.
(4) In what circumstances can these powers be applied.
(5) On how many occasions since the inception of the new funding system in 1986-87 has the secretary or his or her delegate waived negative loadings that have been applied to nursing homes.
(6) In each of these cases, what was the amount of the negative loading that was waived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Section 70C of the Audit Act 1901 contains the general power to "write off" or to "waive" the recovery of various categories of payments, etc., in certain situations.

Legal advice was obtained from the Attorney-General's Department in mid 1992 which indicated that in most circumstances, amounts of unspent Commonwealth nursing home benefit which had been advanced to nursing home proprietors could not be legally categorised as debts due to the Commonwealth or as overpayments.

The Nursing Home Financial Arrangements Principles (the Principles), state that the Secretary "shall" take into account any loadings when determining the scale of fees for a nursing home and that the Secretary is required to impose the "negative loading" unless the unspent Commonwealth nursing home benefit can be recovered or waived by some other mechanism.
Examples of where waivers can occur are in cases of fraud or where an overpayment has occurred, such as when amounts are advanced beyond the period of proprietorship.

New legislation, the National Health Amendment Act 1992, enables payments of Commonwealth nursing home benefit, made on or after 1 July 1993, and which remain unspent, to now be characterised as "debts" or "overpayments". The National Health Amendment Bill (No.3) 1993 contains measures which are designed to further address this issue by applying retrospectively to payments of Commonwealth nursing home benefit made before 1 July 1993 so that they can also be regarded as "debts" or "overpayments" to be pursued from previous proprietors (rather than by imposing a "negative loading" on the current proprietor). This would also bring these amounts within the scope of the Audit Act provision relating to waiver and write off.

The Secretary continues to have an administrative discretion as to the length of the period in which an amount of "negative loading" is to be taken into account in the calculation of a scale of fees for a nursing home. This discretion is used in cases of proven financial hardship resulting in a smaller amount being recovered in each financial year until the full amount of unspent Commonwealth nursing home benefit is recovered.
(2) Section 70C of the Audit Act 1901 provides that the Minister for Finance has the power to:
". . . write off:
(a) losses or deficiencies of public moneys;
(b) irrecoverable amounts of revenue;
(c) irrecoverable debts and overpayments;
(ca) amounts of revenue, or debts or overpayments, the recovery of which would, in the opinion of the Minister, be uneconomical; and
(d) the value of lost, deficient, condemned, unserviceable or obsolete stores."

Accordingly, if the payments of Commonwealth nursing home benefits are able to be legally characterised as "debts" or "overpayments", this power can be used to "waive" or to "write off" the amount if the other conditions contained in the above provision are satisfied. Payments of Commonwealth nursing home benefit made on or after 1 July 1993 which are "unspent" are now able to be characterised as "debts" or "overpayments", thereby enabling the power in section 70C to be used in appropriate cases.
(3) The powers of the Minister for Finance under section 70C of the Audit Act 1901 have been delegated to various officers in the Department, with the Secretary having unlimited power since 1979.

(4) See the answer to (2) above. These powers are used where there is a substantial risk that a nursing home may close in circumstances which would then result in no Commonwealth benefit being otherwise recoverable.
(5) Investigations of records currently indicates that there were two occasions before May 1992 where the Department recovered a lesser amount than might otherwise have been determined.

(6) Section 135A of the National Health Act 1953 precludes the disclosure of information about a person or individual nursing home acquired in the performance of duties or in the exercise of powers or functions under that Act. Provision of the specific information requested may enable identification of the individual nursing homes concerned and I am therefore unable to provide the details of the amounts waived.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Division 13 of Part III of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (International Profit Shifting) which confers wide discretions on the Commissioners, and also to the recent release of draft ruling TR 93/D40, and in view of the fact that many taxpayers may feel aggrieved if the Australian Taxation Office insists that taxpayers should be pursuing their pricing arrangements along the lines in the draft ruling at times when the views of the ATO on the application of Division 13 were not publicly announced, can the Minister give an assurance that ATO Auditors will consider carefully the approach they take in pursuing audit enquiries, particularly when those enquiries cover income years and arrangements that occurred prior to the date of release of draft ruling TR 93/D40.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I am assured that ATO Auditors will consider carefully the approach they take in pursuing audit enquiries covering income years and arrangements that occurred prior to the date of release of Draft Ruling TR 93/D40.

It should be emphasised that the Draft Ruling is saying what the Commissioner considers the law to be and does not make new laws. The Draft only deals with the basic concepts behind the international transfer pricing provisions of the Income Tax law, whereas the practical application of those provisions will be dealt with in more detail in a future Ruling.

There is nothing in the Draft Ruling which is intended to restrict ATO Auditors from exercising their discretion, although the Draft Ruling can be expected to be used as a guideline for auditors to follow in respect of audits.

In respect of the standard of documentation sought by the ATO, where prices set in the past do not accord with the arm's length principle, or with the approaches outlined in Draft Ruling TR 93/D40, it would seem incumbent upon auditors (as it has been incumbent upon them since the legislation was introduced in 1982) to take all reasonable steps to establish what would have been the arm's length consideration based upon the information available to them—and to make any adjustments accordingly.

the environmental impact assessment for the project will adequately take into account the possible impacts the project may have on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park;

The AFP currently uses Outward Bound as a part of its Management of Serious Crime (MOSC) course. The MOSC course is designed to enhance the skills and abilities of senior managers of law enforcement agencies to manage complex and protracted multi-jurisdictional, multi-agency inquiries. Emphasis is placed on the use of multi-agency teams in the investigation of major criminal activity and highlights the co-ordination role of the investigations manager. The Outward Bound course plays an important role in enhancing a knowledge of team and group dynamics and the personal development of course participants.

The MOSC course is of four weeks duration. Participants come from within the AFP, other Australian police forces, international police forces and Commonwealth investigative agencies. A charge is levied on course attendees from outside the AFP.

It is anticipated that up to three MOSC courses will be held in 1994, each involving 15 participants. The Outward Bound component of the course is being retained at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 24 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: In what circumstances, if any, is it a fit and proper action for the chairman of a commission established under federal legislation to write to a minor party asking the leader to vote in a particular way on a motion before the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Whether it is a fit and proper action for the chairperson of a commission established under federal legislation to write to a minor party asking the leader to vote in a particular way in a motion before the Parliament will depend on the following considerations:
(a) the general nature and any particular provisions of the legislation establishing the commission in question;
(b) any particular provisions in the legislation relating to the role of the commission's chairperson; and
(c) the content of the motion in question and its relationship (if any) to the powers and functions of the commission in question.

It is conceivable, for example, that where a commission has powers and functions to represent particular interests, or to develop and implement policies and programs in cooperation with those interests, it would be appropriate for the commission chair to make contact with political parties.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 24 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has the NSW government been offered any federal funding for the regional assessment of wilderness areas and areas of old-growth forest by the Federal Government which has been refused; if so, please explain the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: On 22 December 1992 I wrote to the Hon Chris Hartcher MP, NSW Minister for the Environment, indicating that funding was available from my portfolio for assessments of old-growth forests and wilderness and inviting him to advise on priorities for assessment in NSW. Mr Hartcher's reply of 18 May 1993 indicated that he was not in a position to provide advice on priority for assessment in NSW as such priority could only be developed following extensive consultation with his colleagues. He further indicated that the matter had been taken up through a Premier to Prime Minister letter. On 24 August 1993 the Prime Minister wrote to the NSW Premier indicating that the Commonwealth considered the survey of old-growth forests and wilderness a matter of high priority and that substantial funding was available to do this. I wrote to the Hon George Souris MP on 31 May 1993 asking him to consider giving support for the undertaking of old growth studies as a matter of high priority. I also wrote again to Mr Hartcher on 9 September 1993 stating that the Commonwealth would welcome substantive assessment proposals from NSW. To date, I am still to receive proposals or old-growth forest and wilderness surveys from the NSW government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders: Retrieval of Remains of Bodies from Overseas

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 13 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to each instance where the Government or the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has funded, either in part or in full, efforts to retrieve remains of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander ancestors:
(1) What was the purpose of the trip.
(2) What were the dates of travel.
(3) What were the destinations involved.
(4) What was the number of persons involved, their city or town of residence, and their role in the exercise.

(5) Please provide a breakdown of the amounts of money expended in each case on: (a) air travel; (b) accommodation; (c) meals; and (d) other miscellaneous costs (please provide a description of any miscellaneous costs).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: During the period of the present Keating Government I am advised there has been one instance where the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided financial assistance to retrieve remains of an Aboriginal ancestor from overseas.

This occurred when, during October 1993, the embalmed body of an Aboriginal person was placed in the care of a coroner in Cleveland, United States. The body was of a Palm Island man who, along with at least eight others, had been removed from Australia during the early 1880s by an American travelling circus to tour North America and Europe. The man, who was a member of the Manbara Aboriginal peoples of Palm Island and known by the circus as Tambo, had died of influenza on 23 February 1884 but had not been buried in the United States.

Arrangements for the body to be returned to Australia were made with the full co-operation of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The traditional funeral of the Manbara man will take place on Palm Island on 23 February 1994, exactly 110 years after his death.
(1) The purpose of the trip to the United States was to accept custody of the body, and to accompany it on its return to Townsville, and subsequently in 1994 to Palm Island.
(2) The trip took place between 5—10 December 1993.
(3) It was a return trip to Cleveland, United States.

(4) Three members of the Manbara Aboriginal peoples, including two who were known to be direct descendants of the Palm Island man, travelled to Cleveland to perform an appropriate traditional mortuary ceremony at the time of accepting custody of the body. These men originated from Palm Island, and two now live in Townsville.

(5) Because of the currency of this trip, and the standard ATSIC requirement that the grant (of $17 500) for this purpose be acquitted within three months, I am unable to provide at this time the details which the honourable senator requested. These may be obtained in due course directly from ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is a heavy duty personal insect repellent being marketed throughout North Queensland and Brisbane under the brand name Bushman.
(2) Is the product based on a formula containing diethyltoluamide, or DEET, invented in 1956 for use by the United States military as an insect repellent at a strength of 5 to 16 per cent.
(3) Does Bushman contain diethyltoluamide at concentrations of 80 per cent.

(4) Is it a fact that around 56 per cent of all DEET applied to the skin is quickly absorbed by the skin and can only be partially absorbed by the kidneys and liver with some of the chemical remaining in the body for up to 2 months.

(5) Is it a fact that symptoms caused by diethyltoluamide poisoning include nausea, swelling of the brain, cardiac and respiratory arrest, skin lesions and rashes, muscle cramps, fits, irritability and lethargy.
(6) What approval is necessary, and has been given, to allow the marketing of this product, and what warning information is required.
(7) Does the Minister endorse the product for use by children and families over the summer holidays.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I understand a personal insect repellent with a brand name "Bushman Water Resistant Insect Repellent" is marketed in Queensland.

(2) Yes. According to authoritative monographs the insect repellent properties of DEET, or N,N-diethyl-m-toluamide, were discovered in 1955 although the chemical was first synthesised in 1929. I am unaware of the composition of the formulation used by the US military in 1956. Issue 692 of The Medical Letter on Drugs and Therapeutics, citing a 1983 source, states that the insect repellents long used by the US armed forces include 75 per cent DEET.
(3) Yes.

(4) While various studies have yielded slightly different results, reports indicate that there is variable penetration into the skin of from 9 to 56 per cent of a topically applied dose of DEET, and absorption into the circulation of approximately 17 per cent has been reported in humans. Studies in animals and humans indicate that DEET is extensively metabolised by the liver and excreted in the urine via the kidneys. According to a WHO report on DEET, human studies indicate that most of absorbed DEET is excreted unchanged within one hour with the remainder being metabolised.

(5) Like many commonly available products, DEET is capable of causing poisoning if a sufficient quantity is absorbed. Poisoning by DEET has resulted in both dermatological and central nervous system effects including some of those identified by the honourable senator. The spectrum of effects seen varies from case to case and is dependent on such factors as the route and dose absorbed and individual sensitivity.

(6) Personal insect repellents must comply with the requirements of poisons legislation in the individual States and Territories. I understand that current State and Territory legislation requires products containing 20 per cent or less of DEET to contain a label statement "WARNING—this product contains diethyltoluamide, which may be dangerous when used in large amounts or for a long period." Products containing more than 20 per cent diethyltoluamide are listed as Schedule 5 poisons which, should contain the following wording: "WARNING—may be dangerous when used in large amounts or for a long period" and "WARNING—KEEP OUT OF REACH OF CHILDREN".

(7) Ministers do not endorse the use of particular products. The National Health and Medical Research Council has stated publicly that DEET is considered to be safe and effective with normal use but has highlighted the dangers of over use. All registered insect repellents on the Australian market, including those containing DEET, may be used safely provided they are used in accordance with approved label directions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 14 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fringe benefits requirements of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 as they relate to Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel:
(1) Is temporary rental accommodation to be regarded as a fringe benefit for ADF personnel.
(2) Are loans provided through Service Relief Trust Funds to be regarded as a fringe benefit for ADF personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Under the revised Department of Social Security (DSS) provisions, ADF members residing in temporary rental accommodation will be treated as though they were residing in Defence housing. Temporary Rental Allowance (TRA) is payable in respect of this accommodation and that subsidy is to be regarded as a fringe benefit for DSS purposes. Basically, TRA is the sum difference between what the member would have paid for Defence housing (ie Group Rental Scheme contribution), if it was available, and what the member is required to pay for privately rented accommodation. As with members in Defence married quarters the Group Rental Scheme contribution paid by the member will be compared with the DSS Notional Rent for assessment purposes.
(2) No. Service Relief Trust Funds are self funding schemes established by members of the ADF. They are therefore not regarded as an employer provided fringe benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 14 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) purchase a home, are they entitled to removal at Commonwealth expense.

(2) Has it ever been practice in the past that when members purchased their own home they were entitled to removal expenses; if so, when did the change in policy occur and what was the reason for the change.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. There is no automatic entitlement for any ADF member who purchases a home to be provided with a removal at public expense.

(2) There may be situations where a Service requirement, for which there is a removal entitlement, coincides with the purchase of a member's home. However, policy has never provided for a removal at public expense when the decision to purchase a home is one of personal choice and not related to a Service requirement for the member to relocate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to question on notice No. 379 (Senate Hansard, 30 August 1993, page 622) regarding the use of depleted uranium ammunition by the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) as part of the Phalanx weapons system:
(1) From which country was the depleted uranium ammunition purchased.
(2) What quantity was purchased and where, and under what circumstances was the ammunition used by the RAN.
(3) Given that the Phalanx system is still in use, on what basis did the RAN decide to discontinue use of the ammunition.
(4) What is the difference in cost to the RAN between the purchase price per round of depleted uranium ammunition and the sintered tungsten ammunition now being used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A quantity of 20mm Phalanx ammunition incorporating a depleted uranium (DU) penetrator was purchased from the United States (US) as part

ANSWER.PARA: of the Phalanx Close-In Weapons System (CIWS) fitted to the RAN FFGs.

PARA.TAB: (2) A quantity of 10,000 rounds was shipped to Australia in 1984 by HMAS Sydney, 8000 rounds were retained by Sydney as the ship's outfit and the remainder was made available for trials following the installation of CIWS in the three earlier FFGs. HMAS Darwin returned to Australia in 1985 with an outfit of DU ammunition. No other shipments of DU ammunition have been identified but confirmation that there were none cannot be given without extensive research into archived records. All DU ammunition has been expended in firings during trials of CIWS Phalanx systems and in naval exercises.

(3) The use of locally manufactured ammunition was planned, for reasons of self-reliance, from the inception of the CIWS project. Procurement of the DU ammunition from the US was a stop-gap measure until a local production capability was established.

(4) The cost to the RAN of Australian manufactured tungsten ammunition is approximately $70 per round. The cost of DU ammunition is not available as the US has discontinued its manufacture and is using a similar round to the Australian one.
